input: Fearful Creatures: Woman marries man-eater, or other non human being, without knowing it.
target: Bebet efreyan: Fam, san ki li kone ki li pe fer, marye zom ki manz dimunn, ubyen li marye ar enn lot bebet.

input: Man-eater coming home smells human meat and cries out.
target: Zom ki manz dimunn sati laser imen e kriye.
Zanfan mars-marse ariv kot lakaz zean.

input: Ogre gets man in a basket, in a trap, to be his servant.
target: Zean may zom dan gro tant, dan pyez, pran li kuma servant.

input: Man makes a one—eyed giant blind with an arrow.
target: Zom Servi fles pu fer zean kannwa vinn aveg.

input: Ogre is eaten, whipped to death, burned to death, tricked into hanging himself.
target: Manz zean, swa fwet li ziska li mor, swa met dife ar li, swa kuyonn li pu li met pandi.

input: Wife or mistress of ogre gives help.
target: Fam ubyen metres zean donn kudme.

input: Woman held by ogre gives help.
target: Fam ki zean finn gard prizonye donn kudme.

input: Relative or animal helps person get free from ogre.
target: Fami ubyen zanimo aport led dimunn pu sove depi move zean.

input: Stories about Foolish and Wise Persons.
target: Zistwar dimunn bet ek dimunn saz.

input: A husband hunts three persons as foolish as his wife.
target: Enn mari lasas trwa dimunn osi bet ki so fam.

input: Something laughable somebody does with plants or crops, such as putting cooked dholl in the ground.
target: Kiksoz ridikil ki dimunn fer ar semans ubyen pye, kuma met dal kwi dan later.

input: A foolish woman gives a dishonest man money for her father and mother in heaven.
target: Fam bet donn zom malonet larzan pu so papa mama dan lesyel.

input: Someone tries foolishly to act in the same way as someone else.
target: Dimunn sey azir kuma enn lot dimunn, me dan fason ridikil.

input: Someone gets wisdom from experience or from hearing a story or from a dying father.
target: Kikenn vinn saz atraver lexperyans ubyen atraver enn zistwar ubyen li gayn sazes depi so papa kan li agonizan.

input: A greedy person or one who judges too hastily.
target: Enn dimunn avar ubyen enn ki ziz dimunn tro brit.

input: Someone who is clever at finding out the truth.
target: Kikenn ki malen dan dekuver laverite.

input: Someone finds those who have stolen food.
target: Kikenn depiste kisannla finn kokin manze.

input: Someone who finds a clever way of getting out of punishment.
target: Kikenn telman malen pa reysi pini li.

input: Many folktales have thieves, dishonest persons, or tricksters as their main characters.
target: Personaz prinsipal dan buku folktel li kuyoner, voler, dimunn malonet, eskro.

input: Since such persons also are known in real life, ask for stories about real experiences of this kind.
target: Dan lavi tulezur ena kuyoner parey, alor li vo lapenn dimann dimunn rakont vre zistwar osi.

input: People have a contest in dreaming and lie about the dreams.
target: Ena enn konkur rev e dimunn koz manti lor zot rev.

input: Someone wins a fight by changing one weapon for another.
target: Kikenn gayne dan lager akoz li sanz zarm.

input: Person will not give back something he has borrowed.
target: Kikenn refiz rann enn zafer li finn pran prete.

input: Exchanging things of little value to pay for some damage.
target: Rann kikenn enn zafer ki pena valer pu dedomaz li.

input: Trickster asks his guest to give back food he has just eaten, and gets something in payment.
target: Kuyoner dimann so invite rann manze li fek manze an esanz pu kiksoz.

input: Thiefs and cheats: Thief makes himself look or sound like someone else, or pretends to be dead in order to steal.
target: Voler ek eskro: Voler degiz li kuma enn lot dimunn, imit lavwa enn lot, deklar mor pu li kokin.

input: Thief makes his way into a closed room.
target: Voler pas anba later pu li rant dan enn lasam ferme.

input: The tale of the hare and the tortoise at the side of the king’s pond.
target: Zistwar yek ek torti dan bor basen lerwa.

input: Long, long ago there lived in Mauritius a king who had a big pond.
target: Lontan-lontan dan Moris, ti ena enn lerwa ki ti ena enn gran basen.

input: Early each morning, the king went there to swim, because the doctor prescribed it.
target: Toulegramaten, Lerwa li ti pe al naze laba,  akoz dokter ti rekomann sa.

input: One day, when he came to the edge of the pond, what did he find there?
target: Enn zour, ler li ti ariv dan bor basen, ki li ti trouve laba?

input: He could not possibly swim in it.
target: Li pa ti kapav naz ladan.

input: The king called his caretaker and swore at him.
target: Lerwa ti apel gardien e li ti zour li.

input: The next day, the same thing happened.
The third day again the same thing.
The king grabbed the caretaker by the neck and shook him hard.
target: Lerwa ti trap gardien par so likou e ti sakouy li for.

input: He said, “Hey, you good for nothing, do you want me to get boils in that dirty water there?”.
target: Li dir li, "E, to bon pou nanye, to oule mo trap lagal dan sa dilo la?”.

input: If that pond is not clean tomorrow, you’ll see if I do not beat your behind.
target: Si sa basen la pa prop dime, to pou trouve si  mo pa pou ronfle to deryer.

input: That evening he took his rifle, and went and hid himself in the elephant ear bushes at the edge of the pond.
target: Aswar li ti pran so fizi, e li ti al kasiet dan fey sonz dan bor basen.

input: The night was very, very black.
target: Sa lannwit la ti bien, bien nwar.

input: When the bell rang to tell people that it was time to go to sleep, he heard the sound of footsteps.
target: Ler laklos ti sone pou dir dimoun ki ti le pou al dormi, li ti tann tapaz pa.

input: Before the caretaker had time to raise his rifle, the hare came right up to him and said:
target: Avan gardien gagn letan lev so fizi, yev la ti vinn drwat lor li, dir li:

input: “Hello there, Mister Caretaker! I am glad to see you!”.
target: "Alo laba, Misie Gardien! Ala mo kontan trouv ou!”.

input: I have been looking for you for a long time, because I have something good to give you.
target: Mo pe rode ou depi lontan, akoz mo ena enn bon kiksoz pou donn ou.

input: Taste this honey my family sent me from Trois Ilots.
target: Gout sa dimiel mo fami finn anvoy mwa depi Trois Zilots.

input: Now tell me if you have ever tasted such honey before.
target: Aster dir mwa si ou finn deza gout enn  dimiel koumsa.

input: The caretaker took the gourd, and tried a sip.
target: Gardien pran kalbas la, li aval enn gorze.

input: The caretaker kept tasting from the gourd, until it was empty.
target: Gardien la kontinie gout depi kalbas la, ziska li vinn vid.

input: Now, the hare had put a spell on that honey.
target: Aster, yev la ti met enn jamalgota dan dimiel la.

input: The caretaker only had time to lay himself down by the edge of the pond, then he was sound asleep and started to snore.
target: Gardien la ti nek gagn letan alonz so lekor dan bor basen, kan somey ti pran li, e li ti koumans ronfle.

input: The hare gave a great laugh, took off his clothes and dived into the pond.
target: Yev la ti kas enn gran riye, tir so linz, pik dan basen.

input: When he had had enough, he got out of the pond, broke off a long stick, stirred up the mud, and made the water in the pond brown like chocolate, and then he left.
target: Ler li ase, li ti sorti dan basen la, li ti kas enn long baton, li ti brouy labou, e li ti fer enn dilo kouma sokola dan basen la, e li ti ale.

input: Early the next morning, the king came.
He only looked at the water.
target: Li ti nek get dilo la.

input: A great anger took hold of him.
target: Enn gran lakoler ti pran li.

input: The caretaker was still asleep at the edge of the pond.
target: Gardien la ti ankor pe dormi dan bor basen.

input: The king took the same stick the hare had used to stir up the muddy water and fell on the caretaker.
target: Lerwa la ti pran mem baton ki yev la ti servi pou brouy dilo e li ti tom lor gardien la.

input: He beat him like an ox.
target: Li ti bat li kouma enn bef.

input: The caretaker ran into the woods and was never seen again.
target: Gardien la ti galoup dan bwa e zame pa ti trouv li ankor.

input: The king had the trumpet sounded, “I need a caretaker who will watch my pond”.
target: Lerwa fer sonn trompet, "Mo bizen enn gardien pou vey mo basen”.

input: Ten thousand rupees a month plus other benefits.
target: Dis mil roupi par mwa apart lezot benefis.

input: But if that caretaker lets someone muddy up the water in my pond, I will cut his throat.
target: Me si gardien la les dimoun brouy dilo dan basen, mo pou koup so likou.

input: When all the animals heard this, they were afraid.
target: Kan bann zanimo tann sa koze la, zot ti gagn per.

input: The hare continued to swim in the water.
target: Yev la ti kontinie naz dan dilo la.

input: The king no longer knew what to do.
target: Lerwa nepli ti kone ki pou fer.

input: His body was full of boils.
target: So lekor ti ranpli ar lagratel.

input: For seven days now he had not been able to bathe.
target: Depi set zour aster li pa ti kapav bengne.

input: One day, the officers of the king came to him and said someone was asking about becoming the caretaker of the pond.
target: Enn zour, ofisie Lerwa ti vinn dir li ki ena enn dimoun ki ti dimann pou vinn gardien basen.

input: The king said, “Let him come in!”.
The king saw the candidate for the post of caretaker, and became angry.
target: Ler lerwa trouv kandida pou pos gardien, li pik enn laraz.

input: You want to keep everyone from dirtying my pond?
target: To pou anpes dimoun sal mo basen?

input: Yes your Majesty, I can do it.
target: Wi Mazeste, mo kapav fer li.

input: If anyone muddies the water, I’ll cut your throat.
target: Si kikenn brouye dilo la, mo pou koup to likou.

input: No problem, I know the condition and since tortoise meat is good to eat, you would be able to make a fine curry out of me.
target: Pena problem, mo konn kondision e kouma laviann torti bon pou manze, ou va kapav fer enn bon kari ar mwa.

input: But I do not think you will be tasting me this time.
target: Me mo pa kwar ki ou pou gout mwa sannkoutla.

input: You would better tell your cook to pluck a hen.
target: Vomie ou dir ou kwizinie plim enn poul.

input: All right, chatterbox, tomorrow morning we will see.
target: Bon, mo komer, dime gramaten nou va gete.

input: He went to his friend’s house, there he had him rub his shell all over with pitch.
target: Li ti al lakaz so kamarad, laba li ti fer li frot so lakok partou ar goudron.

input: When the sun set, he came to the edge of the pond, sat down in the path the hare would take, and waited.
target: Ler soley kouse, li ti ariv dan bor basen, li ti asiz dan sime kot yev ti pou pase, e li ti aspere.

input: Step, step, step, the hare came.
target: Tak, tak, tak, yev la ti vini.

input: The hare saw something very black in the middle of the path, he stopped and looked around.
target: Yev la ti trouv kiksoz  bien nwar la omilie so sime, li ti arête e li ti get otour.

input: The tortoise’s head was hidden beneath his shell, nothing moved.
target: Latet torti ti kasiet anba so lakok, narye pa ti pe bouze.

input: Step, step, step, the hare came quietly closer, but nothing moved.
target: Tak, tak, tak, yev ti apros dousma me narye pa ti bouze.

input: The hare thought a little; he came closer, he looked closer, still nothing moved.
target: Yev ti pans inpe; li ti vinn pre, li ti get pli pre, mem sa narye pa ti bouze.

input: For quite some time, he stood there quietly.
target: Enn bon bout letan, li ti res trankil.

input: The tortoise looked like a huge rock.
target: Torti la ti kouma enn gro ros.

input: The hare’s heartbeat slowed, and he was not afraid any longer.
target: Leker yev ti bat dousma, e li napli ti pe gagn per.

input: He said, “That is just a rock there! Now I know! Hey, everybody.
target: Li ti dir, "Ros mem sa, do! Mo kone aster! E vouzot".

input: The king is such a good fellow.
target: Lerwa la enn bon dimoun sa.

input: Of course, he must have had his servant bring this bench down to the shore of the pond so I could sit here when I had to undress before swimming.
target: Bien sir, sa se enn ti ban ki li finn donn lord so domestik amenn dan bor basen pou mo kapav asize ler mo bizen tir mo lenz pou al naze.

input: The hare laughed, then he sat down on the rock.
target: Yev ti riye, lerla li ti asiz lor ros la.

input: All of a sudden the rock moved a little.
target: Toutakoup ros la ti bouz enpe.

input: The hare felt it slightly, but thought nothing of it.
target: Yev ti santi sa inpe, me li ti panse kitsoz lor sa.

input: That is just how they work here in Mauritius.
They forgot to stabilize my chair.
target: Zot finn bliye kal mo sez.

input: So he wanted to jump down in order to put a wedge under the rock that was his chair.
target: Alors li ti anvi sot anba pou kal so ros ki ti so sez.

input: But his bottom was stuck to the pitch.
target: Me so deryer ti tas lor goudron.

input: The tortoise stuck his head out from under his shell.
target: Torti tir so latet anba so lakok.

input: What do you think, old man?
Me, I think you’re stuck this time!
target: Me, mo kwar ki sannkoutla to finn zwenn!

input: But he had to try everything to save his life.
target: Me li ti bizen sey tou pou sap so lavi.

input: He said to the tortoise, “You are a fine one! Quit your joking! We are good neighbours".
target: Li ti dir torti la, "E zoli! Aret badine! Nou bann bon vwazin".

input: Do not make me lose my temper.
target: Pa fer mwa sap lor kal.

input: The tortoise began to walk, taking the hare to the king’s house.
target: Torti la ti koumans marse pou amenn yev la lakaz lerwa.

input: He said to the hare, “Keep talking if that makes you feel better”.
target: Li ti dir yev, “Koz touzor si sa donn twa soulazman”.

input: Now, what are you going to do?
Are you going to let me go or not?
target: To pou les mwa ale ou non?

input: The hare kicked him with his hind foot: the foot stuck!
target: Yev la flank li enn kou lapat deryer: lapat ti kole!

input: Now the  other foot was stuck too.

target: Torti la pa ti pran li kont.

input: He only kept on walking along the path.
target: Li ti kontinye marse lor sime la.

input: Now listen to me or I will use my front foot.
target: Aster ekout mwa, sinon mo pou servi mo lapat divan.

input: The tortoise kept on walking without a word.
target: Torti la ti kontinye marse san enn mo.

input: A blow from the left foot.
A blow from the right foot.
Now all four feet were stuck!
target: Aster toule kat lapat ti kole!

input: But the poor unfortunate had to make another try.
target: Me pov malere la ti bizen sey ankor.

input: He boasted to the tortoise, saying to him.
target: Li ti fer vantar ar torti, li ti dir li.

input: Listen to me now: I will say it one last time.
target: Ekout mwa bien: mo pou koz enn dernie fwa.

input: All my strength is in my head.
target: Tou mo lafors dan mo latet.

input: If I hit you with my head, I will crush you like a ripe pawpaw.
target: Si mo tap enn koutet lor twa, mo pou kraz twa kouma enn papay mir.

input: Let me go, I tell you, let me go!
target: Les mo ale, mo dir twa, es mo ale!

input: The tortoise kept on walking, he paid no attention at all.
target: Torti la ti kontinie marse, li pa ti pran kont ditou.

input: The hare raised his head, collected all his strength, and hit.
target: Yev la ti lev so latet, ramas tou so lafors, e tap enn kou.

input: Finally, they came to the king’s house.
target: Finalman, zot ti finn ariv lakaz lerwa.

input: The tortoise was laughing, the hare was crying.
target: Torti la ti pe riye, yev la tip e plore.

input: When the king saw the hare stuck on the tortoise’s shell, even though he was angry, he had to laugh too.
target: Kan lerwa ti trouv yev ti kole lor torti la so lakok, kamem li ti ankoler, li ti oblize riye.

input: The tortoise said to him, “Here he is, Your Majesty! It would not be tortoise you will be eating tonight, but hare stew”.
target: Torti ti dir li, "Ala li la, Mazeste! Pa torti ki ou pou manze aswar, me salmi yev”.

input: The king took out his knife, cut off the hare’s head and sent it to the kitchen.
target: Lerwa ti tir so kouto, sot latet yev e avoy  li dan lakouzinn.

input: After that he called his servant.
target: Apre sa li apel so domestik.

input: Hey, you! Now I can go swimming in my pond.
target: E twa! Mo pe al naze dan mo basen.

input: The tale of the colophane trees.
Once upon a time, there lived a great king who lived in a big castle.
target: Ti ena enn fwa enn gran lerwa ki ti res dan enn gran sato.

input: His garden was full of all sorts of trees.
target: So zardin ti ranpli ar tou kalite pie.

input: He had lots of money, and he had lots of animals.
target: Li ti ena boukou larzan, e li ti ena boukou zanimo.

input: But one thing was wrong: his pond was completely dry.
target: Me ti ena enn zafer pa korek: so basen ti sek net.

input: There was not one drop of water in it.
target: Pa ti ena enn gout dilo ladan.

input: One day, the king decided to find a solution for his water problem.
target: Enn zour, lerwa ti desid pou trouv enn solision pou so problem dilo.

input: He called his horse and said to him, “Go to Grandmother Spider’s house, and ask her what I must do to make the water flow".
target: Li ti apel so seval e li ti dir li, "Al lakaz Granmama Zaregne, dimann li ki mo bizen fer pou fer dilo koule”.

input: Give yourself the spurs and return as fast as you can.
target: Pik enn lakours e revini lor vites.

input: The horse said, “Count on me, Your Majesty”.
target: Seval ti dir, "Kont lor mwa, Mazeste”.

input: And he started off like an arrow.
target: E li demare kouma enn fles.

input: When he arrived at Grandmother Spider’s house, he said to her, “Hello, hello, Grandmother Spider”.
target: Ler li ariv kot lakaz granmama Zaregne, li ti dir li, "Bonzour, bonzour, Granmama Zaregne”.

input: The king asks what he needs to do to make the water flow?
target: Lerwa dimann ou ki li bizen fer pou fer dilo koule?

input: Grandmother Spider stood up on her legs.
target: Granmama Zaregne dres lor so lapat.

input: She looked at the horse and said to him, “Tell the king he should cut down the colophane trees”.
target: Li ti get seval la e li ti dir li, "Dir lerwa li bizin koup pie kolofann”.

input: But on the way his hoof hit the stump of a tamanicoque tree.
target: Me dan sime so lipie kogn ar enn siko tamanikok.

input: His hoof hurt so badly, he started to swear at the tree stump.
target: So lipie ti gagn dimal e li ti koumans zour siko pie la.

input: When he arrived back at the king’s house, His Majesty asked him what Grandmother Spider had said.
target: Ler li ariv lakaz lerwa, Samazeste dimann li ki Granmama Zaregne finn dir.

input: The horse could only think about that tamanicoque trees and said to the king, “Grandmother Spider said you should cut down the tamanicoque trees, then the water will flow.”
target: Seval la ti nek pe pans tamanikok e li dir lerwa, "Granmama Zaregne dir ou bizin koup tamanikok, lerla dilo pou koule".

input: He had every single tamanicoque on his estate cut down.
target: Li ti fer koup tou pie tamanikok dan so tabisman.

input: But not one drop of water flowed into his pond.
target: Me enn gout dilo pa finn koule dan so basen.

input: He called for his horse and cut off his head.
target: Li ti fer apel seval la e li finn koup so latet.

input: Then he called for the cow.
target: Lerla li ti fer apel vas.

input: The cow came, and the king sent her back to Grandmother Spider’s house.
target: Vas la ti vini, e lerwa ti anvoy li lakaz Granmama Zaregne.

input: Grandmother Spider told her again, “Cut down the colophane trees.”
target: Granmama Zaregne ti dir li ankor, "Koup pie kolofann".

input: Now, the cow was always happiest when eating.
target: Vas la ti toultan kontan kan lip e manze.

input: Everywhere she went she was looking for grass to eat.
target: Partou li ti al rod lerb pou manze.

input: So she had to eat the tender leaves of the  blackwood tree.
target: Alors  li ti oblize manz fey bwanwar tann.

input: And the leaves were bitter in her mouth.
target: E feyaz la ti amer dan so labous.

input: When she came back to the king’s house, the king asked what Grandmother Spider had said to her.
target: Ler li ti ariv lakaz Lerwa, Lerwa dimann li ki Granmama Zaregne ti finn dir li.

input: But there were only bitter blackwood leaves in her mouth.
target: Me ti ena selman fey bwanwar dan so labous.

input: She said to the king, “Grandmother Spider said to cut down the blackwood trees”.
target: Li ti dir lerwa, "Granmama Zaregne ti dir koup pie bwanwar".

input: He had all the blackwood trees cut down but the water refused to flow.
target: Li ti fer koup tou pie bwanwar me dilo refiz koule.

input: The king’s anger knew no bounds; he had the cow caught, and taken away to be cooked and eaten.
target: Koler Lerwa defons baraz; li fer trap vas, e avoy pou kwi e manz li.

input: Then came Father Hare who boasted to the king, saying, “But Your Majesty, why are you giving such idiots such an important job?”.
target: Ala papa yev vinn fer vantar ar Lerwa, li dir li, "Me, Votmazeste, kifer ou donn dimoun bet fer travay serye?”

input: I am the best man you can find.
target: Mo meyer zom ki ou pou trouve.

input: All right then, do it, if you can.
target: Tou korek alors, fer li, si to kapav.

input: He came to Grandmother Spider’s house and she told him, “Well, cut down those colophane trees, finally”.
target: Li ti ariv lakaz Granmama Zaregne e li ti dir li, "Bon, koup pie kolofann, finalman".

input: On the hare’s way back to the king’s house, he met a hunter with his rifle.
target: Ler yev ti pe retourn lakaz Lerwa, li ti zwenn enn saser avek so fizi.

input: The hare saw the rifle pointed at him.
target: Yev ti trouv fizi pwente lor li.

input: It went off, he ran into a canefield and hid down under some straw for three days.
target: Li tire, rant dan karo kann, al kasiet anba lapay e pandan trwa zour.

input: In the darkest night he left to go look for the king.
target: Dan lanwit marenwar li ti sorti pou al get lerwa.

input: But even though he scratched his head, he couldn’t remember the name colophane, so he told the king, “Cut down the almond trees.”
target: Me mem li ti grat so latet li nepli kapav rapel nom kolofann, li ti dir Lerwa, "Koup pie badamie".

input: The almond trees went down, but the water still wouldn’t flow.
target: Badamie anba, me dilo napa koule.

input: The king cut off the hare’s head.
He sent him to the kitchen, one half to be roasted, the leftovers cooked with wine.
target: Li ti avoy li lakouzinn, lamwatie pou fer roti, larestan pou kwi ar divin.

input: The tortoise came up to the king, and asked him if he could go on the errand to Grandmother Spider’s house.
target: Torti ti apros Lerwa, e li ti dimann li si li kapav al fer so komision kot Granmama Zaregne so lakaz.

input: The king was still sad but he had to laugh.
target: Kanmem Lerwa sagren, li oblize riye.

input: And you, slowpoke, when will you return?
target: E twa, Komer, kan to pou retourne?

input: I will return when I return, Your Majesty, but when I do return you will have your answer.
target: Mo va retourne kan mo va retourne, Mazeste, me kan mo pou retourne ou va gagn ou repons.

input: So the king let him go.
The tortoise walked and walked, very slowly, but always straight ahead, never dawdling.
target: Torti marse, marse, dousman dousman, me touzour li al drwat divan li, zame badine.

input: When he arrived at Grandmother Spider’s house, he asked her how the king could get water back in his pond.
target: Kan li ariv lakaz Granmama Zaregne, li ti dimann li ki manier Lerwa pou gagn dilo dan so basen.

input: But this time Grandmother Spider shouted at him angrily.
target: Me sannkoutla Granmama Zaregne ti krie ar li avek koler.

input: They keep bothering me with their stupid pond.
target: Zot kontinie agas mwaar zot basen.

input: If there’s no water, put palmwine in it.
target: Si pena dilo, met kalou ladan.

input: The tortoise spoke politely with Grandmother Spider and pleaded with her for her answer until finally she said, “Cut down the colophanes.”
target: Torti koz dousman-dousman ar Granmama Zaregne, li anbet-anbet li ziska ki finalman li ti dir, "Koup pie kolofann".

input: The tortoise set out to return.
At least three months later, the king saw him coming from far off.
target: Omwen trwa mwa pli tar, lerwa ti trouv li pe vini depi lwen.

input: He said to the queen, “Do you like tortoise meat?”.
target: Li ti dir ar Larenn, "Ou kontan laviann torti?”.

input: I think we’ll be eating tortoise meat for dinner.
target: Mo kwar nou pou manz laviann torti pou dine.

input: The king called his cook in order to lose no time.
target: Lerwa apel kwizinie pou pa perdi letan.

input: The cook came, the tortoise came.
target: Kwizinie ti vini, torti ti vini.

input: The king asked the tortoise, “Well? Well?”.
What do you have to say for yourself?
Cut down the colophanes, Your Majesty; then the water will flow into your pond.
target: “Koup kolofann, Mazeste; lerla dilo pou koule dan ou basen.

input: The king thought that this was just one more nasty liar.
target: Lerwa ti kwar ki sa  ti ankor enn move bagou.

input: He was angry and said to the tortoise, “I will have them cut down, but if no water flows into my pond, I will have a tortoise in my pot”.
target: Li ti ankoler e li ti dir ar torti, "Mo pou fer koup zot, me si dilo pa koule dan mo basen, mo pou ena enn torti dan mo marmit."

input: So the king’s woodcutter cut down all the colophane trees.
target: Alors bisron lerwa ti koup tou pie kolofann.

input: And what do you think happened?
target: E ki ou kwar ti arive?

input: From all directions of the pond, water began to flow.
target: Partou akote basen, dilo ti koumans koule.

input: The king was so happy that he said to his cook, “Kill the turkey, kill the goose, kill the guinea hen, kill the pigeon! I will give a great feast this evening to baptize our pond and it will be a great celebration”.
target: Lerwa sitan kontan ki li ti dir so kwizinie, "Touy denn, touy lezwa, touy pintad, touy pizon! Mo donn gran-gran dine aswar pou nou batiz nou basen eli pou enn gran selebrasyon”.
Zot tou ti manze, zot tou ti zot bwar.

input: But don’t you believe that they were drinking pond water.
target: Me zot pa kwar ki zot tip e bwar dilo basen.
Zot ti bwar diven ek romm.

input: I asked for just a little glass, but they gave me such a kick and I landed here.
target: Mo ti dimann zis enn ti ver, me zot ti flank mwa enn koutpie e mo ti tom isi.

input: The tale of the hare, the elephant and the whale.
One day Father Hare took a little walk.
target: Enn zour papa Yev ti pe promne.

input: He looked at the waves breaking on the shore and saw the whale swimming by.
target: Li ti pe get vag pe kraze lor laplaz e li ti pe get Labalenn pe naze.

input: That must be the king of all the animals.
target: Sa bizin enn lerwa bann zanimo sa.

input: Hey, sailor, come in a little closer here.
target: E, matlo, apros enpe par isi.

input: I have something to say to you.
target: Mo enan kitsoz pou dir ou.

input: The whale swam near the beach.
target: Labalenn la ti apros pre kot laplaz.

input: The hare said to him, “You really are huge but it is not size alone that makes strength”.
target: Yev ti dir li, "Bien sir ou gro me pa groser selman ki fer so lafors”.

input: I am really pretty small, but it seems to me that I am stronger than you.
target: Mo mo bien tipti, me dapre mwa ki mo pli for ki ou.

input: The whale looked at him and laughed.
target: Labalenn ti get li e li ti riye.

input: The hare said to him, “Listen, I will go to fetch a strong rope”.
target: Yev ti dir li, "Ekoute, mo pou al sers enn lakord ki for”.

input: You tie one end to your tail.
target: Ou amar enn bout ar ou lake.

input: I will tie the other end around my waist.
target: Mo pou amar lot bout otour mo leren.

input: Then each of us pulls from his side.
target: Apre sakenn ant nou ris so kote.

input: I will bet I can pull you up onto dry land.
target: Mo pou sir mo pou kapav ris ou dan sek.

input: Go fetch that rope, my little one, and then we will see.
target: Al sers sa lakord l, mo piti, e lerla nou pou gete.

input: There he met the elephant, and he said to him.
target: Laba li ti zwenn lelefan, e li ti dir li.

input: A huge head, but what a little tail.
target: Enn gro latet, me enn piti lake.

input: People like you can’t be very strong.
target: Dimounn kouma twa pa kapav ena gran lafors.

input: As little as I am, if I fight with you, I will bet I can beat you.
target: Tipti kouma mo ete, si mo lager ar twa, mo parie mo kapav bat twa.

input: The elephant looked at the hare, and laughed.
target: Lelefan la ti get yev la, e li ti riye.

input: You tie one end around your waist.
target: Ou amar enn bout ar ou lleren.

input: Then each of us pulls from his side.
target: Lerla sakenn ant nou pou ris so kote.

input: I will bet I can pull you like a fish on a line.
target: Mo parie mo kapav ris twa kouma enn poson lor enn lalign.

input: Go get your rope, friend, then we will see.
target: Ale al sers to lakord, mo kamarad, lerla nou pou gete.

input: The hare went to fetch a strong rope.
target: Yev ti al sers enn lakord for.

input: He gave one end of it to the whale, and said to him.
target: Li ti donn enn bout ar labalenn, e li ti dir li.

input: When I shout ‘Ready, set, go!’ then pull.
target: Ler mo kriye “Ala mo finn pare!” lerla rise.

input: We will both pull at the same time.
target: Nou de nou pou ris anmemtan.

input: The whale tied the rope around his tail, and waited.
target: Labalenn ti amar lakord otur so lake, e li ti aspere.

input: The hare took the other end of the rope to the elephant, and said to him, “Tie this tight”.
target: Yev ti  amenn lot bout lakord ar lelefan, e ti dir li, "Amar sa sere”.

input: I will shout when I am ready, then each of us pulls from his side.
target: Mo pou kriye kan mo pare, lerla sakenn ant nou ris son kote.

input: The elephant tied the rope around his waist, and waited.
target: Lelefan ti amar lakord otour so leren, e li aspere.

input: The hare went and hid in some bushes.
target: Yev ti al kasiet dan brousay.

input: Then he shouted, “I am ready, pull”.
target: Lerla li ti kriye, "Mo pare, rise".

input: The whale pulled from his side, the elephant pulled from the other side.
target: Labalenn ris so kote, lelefan ris lot kote.

input: The rope stiffened like the strings of a violin.
target: Lakord la redi kouma difil violon.

input: They both did their best, but neither was able to pull the other away.
target: Zot de ti fer zot mie, me personn pa ti kapav ris lot.

input: All of a sudden the rope broke.
The elephant lost his balance and fell.
The whale landed in the coral and cut himself.
target: Labalenn pik dan koray, li blese.

input: The hare came to the elephant, “Oh dear, my friend”.
target: Yev vinn kot lelefan: "Ayo, mo kamarad”.

input: May be you have hurt yourself.
I got you into this trouble for being stronger than you.
target: Mo finn fer twa gagn problem parski mo pli for ki twa.

input: The elephant remained quiet, what could he say?
target: Lelefan res sek, ki li pou dir?

input: The hare came to the whale at the shoreline, saw that the water was all red with blood, and called to the whale.
target: Yev ariv ar Labalenn dan borlamer, li trouv dilo rouz ar disan, e li kriye labalenn.

input: I am sorry that you’ve hurt yourself.
target: Mo sagren ki ou finn gagn dimal.

input: It is my fault for making you boast that you are as big as a ship.
target: Li mo fot parski mo finn flat ou pou dir ou gro kouman enn navir.

input: So that is why the elephant and the whale believe that the hare is stronger than they are.
target: Ala kifer Lelefan ek Labalenn kwar ki Yev pli for ki zot.

input: The tale of little John and the oxtail.
Once upon a time there was a little boy whose name was Little John.
target: Ti ena enn fwa enn ti garson ki ti apel Tizan.

input: One day, when he went out to play, he caught a cricket.
target: Enn zour, ler li ti pe zwe deor, li ti may enn sotrel.

input: He said to his papa, “Papa, Papa, look at the cricket I caught when I went out to play.”
target: Li ti dir so papa, "Papa, papa, get sa sotrel ki mo finn maye kan mo ti pe zwe deor."

input: His papa took the cricket from him and gave him an arrow instead.
target: So papa ti pran sotrel la e ti donn li enn fles.

input: He found his mother, and said to her, “Mummy, Mummy, look at the arrow I got from Papa, when he took my cricket, the cricket I caught when I went out to play.”
target: Li trouv so mama, e li ti dir li, "Mama, mama, get fles mo finn gagne ar papa, kan  papa finn pran mo sotrel, sotrel mo finn maye kan mo ti pe zwe deor."

input: So his mummy took the arrow, and gave him a coconut instead.
target: Alors so mama ti pran fles la, e li ti donn li enn koko.

input: At the side of the river he found a woman who was trying to drink water with her hands, and he said to her, “Woman, woman, you must be silly to drink water with your hands! Here is a coconut”.
target: Dan bor larivier li ti zwenn enn madam ki pe bwar dilo avek so lame, e li ti dir li, "Madam, madam, ala to bet pou bwar dilo dan lame! Ala enn koko”.

input: You can eat it and then use the shell to dip water.
target: Ou kapav manz li e apre servi so lakok pou plonz dan dilo.

input: The woman took the coconut, broke it and ate it.
target: Madam la ti pran koko la, ti kas li e ti manz li.

input: Little John began to cry, saying to the woman, “Woman, woman, that is not what I meant!”
target: Tizan ti koumans plore, li ti dir madam la, "Madam, madam, mo pa dakor!”

input: Give me back my coconut, the coconut I got from my mummy, when Mummy took my arrow, that I got from my papa, when Papa took my cricket, the cricket I caught when I went out to play.
target: Rann mwa mo koko, koko ki mo finn gagne ar mo mama, kan mama ti pran mo fles, fles ki mo finn gagne ar papa, kan papa ti pran mo sotrel, sotrel ki mo ti maye kan mo ti al zwe deor.

input: The woman gave him a handful of lentils instead.
target: Madam la ti donn li enn pogne lanti.

input: He came to a wide road, where he found a pigeon that was trying to pick at the rocks laying about on the ground, and he said to it, “Pigeon, pigeon, you must be silly to try to eat the rocks laying about in the middle of the road”.
target: Li ti ariv enn gran sime, kot li ti trouv enn pizon ki pe manz ti ros lor later, e li ti dir li, "Pizon, pizon, kouma to bet pou esay manz ti ros omilie sime”.

input: Here are some lentils, pick them up and eat them.
target: Ala inpe lanti, ramas zot e manze zot.

input: He scattered the lentils on the road in front of the pigeon, and the pigeon ate them.
target: Li ti fann lanti la lor sime divan piz on la, e pizon la ti manz zot.

input: Little John began to cry, saying to the pigeon, “Pigeon, pigeon, that’s not what I meant”.
target: Tizan ti koumans plore, li ti dir pizon, "Pizon, pizon, mo pa dakor”.

input: !Give me back my lentils, the lentils that I got from the woman, when she took my coconut, the coconut that I got from my mummy, when she took my arrow, that I got from my papa, when he took my cricket, the cricket I caught when I went out to play.”
target: Rann mwa mo lanti, lanti ki mo finn gagne ar madam la, kan madam la ti pran mo koko, koko ki mo ti gagne ar mo mama, kan li ti pran mo fles, ki mo ti gagne ar papa, kan li ti pran mo sotrel, sotrel ki mo ti maye kan mo ti al zwe deor."

input: The pigeon gave him a feather.
target: Pizon la ti donn li enn plim.

input: He came to a school, and there he found a schoolboy who was trying to write on his paper with a little piece of wood.
target: Li ti ariv kot enn lekol, e li ti trouv enn zelev ki pe ekrir lor papie ar enn ti bout dibwa.

input: He said to him, “Schoolboy, schoolboy, you must be silly”.
target: Li ti dir li, “zelev, zelev kouma to bet”.

input: You are trying to write on your paper with a little piece of wood.
target: To pee say ekrir lor to papie ar enn bout dibwa.

input: Here is a feather, sharpen it, and use it.
target: Ala enn plim, tay li,  e servi li.

input: So the schoolboy took the feather, sharpened it, and used it instead.
target: Alors, zelev la ti pran plim la, li ti tay li, e li ti servi li.

input: Little John began to cry, saying, “Schoolboy, schoolboy, that’s not what I meant”.
target: Tizan koumans plore, li ti dir, "Zelev, zelev, mo pa dakor”.

input: Give me back my feather, the feather that I got from the pigeon who took my lentils, the lentils that I got from the woman, when she took my coconut, the coconut that I got from my mummy, when she took my arrow, that I got from my papa, when he took my cricket, the cricket I caught when I went out to play.
target: Rann mo plim, plim ki mo ti gagne ar pizon la, pizon ki ti pran mo lanti, lanti ki mo ti gagne ar madam la, kan li ti pran mo koko, koko ki mo ti gagne ar mo mama, kan li ti  pran mo fles, ki mo ti gagne ar mo papa, kan li ti pran mo sotrel, sotrel ki mo ti maye kan mo ti al zwe deor.

input: The schoolboy gave him an old notebook.
target: Zelev la ti donn li enn vie kaye.

input: He came to a blacksmith’s shop, and found the blacksmith trying to light his fire with wet straw.
target: Li ti ariv divan enn laforz, e li trouv forzron ki ape alim so dife ar lapay mouye.

input: He said to him, “Blacksmith, blacksmith, you must be silly to try to light your fire with wet straw.
target: Li ti dir li, "Forzron, forzron, kouma to bet pou alim to dife ar lapay mouye”.

input: Here is some dry paper, take it and use it to light your fire.
target: Ala inpe papie sek, pran li e servi li pou alim to dife.

input: The blacksmith took the paper, and lit his fire.
target: Forzron ti pran papie la, e li ti alim so dife.

input: Little John began to cry, saying, “Blacksmith, blacksmith, that’s not what I meant”.
target: Tizan ti koumans plore, li dir, "Forzron, forzron, mo pa dakor”.

input: Give me back my paper, the paper I got from the schoolboy, the schoolboy who took my feather, the feather that I got from the pigeon who took my lentils, the lentils that I got from the woman, the woman who took my coconut, the coconut that I got from my mummy, when she took my arrow, that I got from my papa, when he took my cricket, the cricket I caught when I went out to play.
target: Rann mwa mo papie, papie ki mo ti gagne ar zelev la, zelev ki ti pran mo plim, plim ki mo ti gagne ar pizon ki finn pran mo lanti, lanti ki mo ti gagne ar madam, ki ti pran mo koko, koko ki mo ti gagne ar mo mama, kan li ti pran mo fles, ki mo ti gagne ar mo papa, kan li ti pran mo sotrel, sotrel ki mo ti maye kan mo ti al zwe deor.

input: The blacksmith gave him an oxtail.
target: Forzron donn li enn lake bef.

input: There he buried the oxtail in the sand, leaving a little bit of the oxtail above the ground.
target: Lerla li ti anter lake bef la dan lasab, li ti kit enn ti bout lake bef la andeor later.

input: Then he ran to the king’s house, and started to cry, saying to the king, “King, King, give me fifty men to help me pull my ox from the sand, there is only a little bit of his tail above the ground.”
target: Lerla li ti galoupe pou al lakaz Lerwa, e li ti koumans plore, li ti dir Lerwa, "Lerwa, Lerwa, donn mwa sinkant dimoun pou ed mwa pou mo al tir mo bef dan disab, ki finn anter dan disab, ena zis enn bout lake andeor disab.

input: The king gave him fifty men.
target: Lerwa  ti donn li senkant dimoun.

input: They all came to the seashore, they all pulled on the oxtail until it came out.
target: Zot tou ti ariv borlamer, zot tou ti ris lake bef ziska ki li ti sorti.

input: Little John returned to the king, and starting to cry again, he said to the king, “King, King, your band of men broke the tail off of my ox, my ox that is buried deep in the sand, and now I’ve lost my ox.
target: Tizan ti retourn kot Lerwa, e li koumans plore, li ti dir Lerwa, "Lerwa, Lerwa, ou bann dimoun la ann finn kas lake mo bef, mo bef finn anter dan fon disab, e aster mo finn perdi mo bef.

input: The king was in a generous mood.
He gave Little John a cow as a present.
target: Li ti fer Tizan enn vas an kado.

input: And that day was the last time I ever saw a cricket in Mauritius turned into a cow.
target: E sa zour la ti dernie fwa mo ti trouv enn sotrel dan Moris vinn enn vas.

input: The tale of old man lazybones.
Once upon a time, there was an old man they called Old Man Lazybones.
target: Enn fwa, ti ena enn bonom apel Bonom Flanker.

input: Now Old Man Lazybones had a cow.
target: Aster Bonom Flanker ti ena enn vas.

input: And this cow was so thin, that one day it died.
target: E afors vas la ti meg, ki enn zour vas la ti mor.

input: Old Man Lazybones skinned the cow, then took the hide and hung it out to dry.
target: Bonom Flanker ti tir so lapoe met li sek.

input: When the hide was finally dry, the old man took it, put it on his head, and went to sell it.
target: Ler lapo ti finalman sek, bonom la tip ran li, met li lor so latet, e ti al vann li.

input: Old Man Lazybones went to all the houses, he went to all the shops; but noone wanted to buy his cowhide.
target: Bonom Flanker ti al kot tou lakaz, li ti al dans tou laboutik; me personn pa ti anvi  aste so lapo la.

input: Old Man Lazybones walked and walked, until he came to a large forest.
target: Bonom Flanker ti marse e marse, ziska li ti ariv dan enn granbwa.

input: His legs were so tired that he sat down to rest beneath a tree.
target: So lazam ti osi fatige ki li ti al asiz anba enn pie pou repose.

input: As he was resting there, he heard a noise – clipclop, clipclop; a band of forty thieves on their horses was coming.
target: Ler li ti pe repoze, li tanntan enn tapaz -  clipclop, clipclop; enn bann karant lor zot seval ti pe vinni.

input: Old Man Lazybones was afraid they would see him.
target: Bonom Flanker ti gagn per tansion zot trouv li.

input: So he climbed up into the tree with his hide.
target: Alors li ti mont lor enn pie ar so lapo vas.

input: The thieves came up, dismounted from their horses, and sat down under the very tree Lazybones had climbed.
target: Bann voler la ti vini, desan depi lor zot seval, e zot ti asiz zis anba pie kot Flanker ti monte.

input: They pulled out all the money they had stolen, and put it into a pile to divide it among themselves.
target: Zot ti tir tou larzan zot ti koken, e zot ti met dan enn anta pou fer lapartaz ant zot.

input: When Old Man Lazybones saw how much money the thieves had there, he could hardly believe his eyes.
target: Kan bonom Flanker ti komye larzan bann voler la ti ena laba, li pas ti kapav krwar so lizie.

input: His hands began to shake and he let go of the cowhide.
target: So lame ti koumans tranble e li larg lapo vas.

input: The dried hide made a terrible crash and landed right in the middle of the band of thieves.
target: Lapo sek la fer enn tapaz terib e li ti tom damilie bann voler.

input: The thieves had no idea what was happening.
target: Bann voler la pa ti ena okenn lide ki tip e arrive.

input: They left the money lying on the ground, jumped on their horses and fled.
target: Zot ti kit larzan ki ti lor later, sot lor zot seval e fonn.

input: Lazybones climbed down from his tree, gathered up all the money and carried it home.
target: Flanker ti desann depi lor so pie, pran tou kas e ti amenn li dan so lakaz.

input: Lazybones bought himself a grand carriage and two horses.
target: Flanker ti aste pou li mem enn gran kales ek de seval.

input: He went to the market, where he bought a crate of vegetables, for which he gave five piasters.
target: Li ti al bazar, kot li ti aste enn kes legim, li ti donn senk pias.

input: When the merchant tried to give him his change, he told him to keep the rest.
target: Ler mrasan la tie say rann li lamone, li ti dir li gard kas la.

input: The king’s servant saw all this, and returning to his master’s house he said to the king, “I saw Old Man Lazybones at the market; he bought himself a whole crate of vegetables, and paid five piasters; but when the merchant tried to give him his change, he wouldn’t take it.”
target: Domestik Lerwa ti trouv sa, e li ti retourn lakaz so met, li ti dir Lerwa, "Mo ti trouv bonom Flanker bazar; li ti aste pou li mem enn kes legim, e li ti pey senk pias; me kan marsan la ti esay rann li so lamone, li pa ti oule pran li."

input: The king was astonished, “Go fetch me Old Man Lazybones, and bring him here.”
target: Lerwa ti etone, "Al sers mwa bonom Flanker, e amenn li isi."

input: When Lazybones arrived, the king asked him, “Where did you find all that money?” Lazybones told him, “I used to have a cow; but it died; so I skinned it and hung the hide out to dry.
target: Ler Flanker ti vini, Lerwa ti dimann li, "Kot to finn gagn tousa larzan la?"

input: When the skin was dry, I sold it”.
target: Flanker ti dir li, "Mo ti ena enn vas; vas la ti mor; mo ti ekors li, mo ti met so lapo sek. Ler lapo la bien sek, mo ti vann li”.

input: And that’s how I earned a nice sum of money.”
target: E ala kimanier mo finn gagn enn bon morso larzan.

input: He thought, “But I have a huge herd of cows, if I slaughter them all and sell their hides, I will be able to earn much more money than Lazybones.”
target: Li mazine, "Me mwa ki gagn gran troupo bef, si mo touy zot e vann zot lapo, mo pou kapav gagn pli boukou larzan ki Flanker."

input: So the king had all his cows slaughtered and skinned, he had the hides hung out to dry, had them all loaded onto a cart and sent off to be sold.
target: Alors lerwa fer touy tou so bef e fer tir tou lapo, li ti met bann lapo la sek, li ti sarz zot lor enn saret e li ti anvoy vande.

input: But noone wanted to buy them.
target: Me personn pa ti anvi aste zot.

input: The cart drove and the cart drove some more, the hides began to stink, soon they stank so badly they had to be thrown away.
target: Saret ti roule e saret ti roule inpe plis, lapo ti koumans pouri, vit zot tip e santi telman pi ki ti bizin zet zot.

input: The king was furious, and went to Lazybones’ house.
target: Lerwa ti ankoler, e li ti al lakaz Flanker.

input: When Lazybones saw the king coming from afar, he quickly put a soup pot over the fire.
target: Kouma Flanker ti trouv Lerwa pe vini depi lwen, li met vitman enn marmit lasoup lor dife.

input: When the pot was boiling hot, he took it from the fire and put it out in the middle of the road.
target: Kan marmit ti bien bwi, li ti tir li lor dife e li ti met li omilie sime.

input: Lazybones took out his whip and beat the pot.
target: Flanker ti pran so fwet e li ti bat marmit la.

input: The king came, and he watched and wondered; he asked Lazybones, “What do you think you are doing, there?”
target: Lerwa ti vini, e li ti pe gete, e li li ti pe panse; li ti dir Flanker, "Ki to panse to pe fer, laba?"

input: Lazybones replied, “Your Majesty, this is how I boil my soup.”
target: Flanker ti reponn, "Mazeste, koumsa ki mo bwi mo lasoup."

input: “This is the right way to boil soup?”
target: "Eski sa enn bon fason pou bwi lasoup?"

input: “Just like this, Your Majesty! Can’t you see for yourself that the water is boiling nicely in the pot?”
target: "Koumsamem, Mazeste! Ou pa trouve oumem ki dilo la pe bien bwi dan marmit la?"

input: When the king returned to his house, he called for his cook, “Bring a pot and put all the things in it you need to make a soup.”
target: Ler lerwa ti retourn dan so lakaz, li ti apel so kwizinie, "Amenn marmit e met ladan tou kiksoz ki bizen pou lasoup."

input: The cook came and did what the king ordered him to do.
target: Kwizinie ti vini e ti fer seki lerwa ti donn li lord pou fer.

input: “Now, put the pot out in the middle of the road, take a whip and beat the pot: the soup will start to boil.”
target: "Aster, poz marmit omilie sime, pran enn fwet e bat marmit la: lasoup la pou koumans bwi."

input: The cook beat the pot; but the pot wouldn’t boil.
target: Kwizinie la ti bat marmit la; me marmit napa bwi.

input: “Whip it harder, there! Harder, harder still!”
target: "Bat li pli for, laba! Pli for, pli for mem!"

input: The cook stood up straight, and whipped and beat the pot until it tipped over: all the soup ran out into the road.
target: Kwizinie ti leve, e fwete e ti bat marmit la ziska li ti savire: tou lasoup ti tom lor sime.

input: He sent four policemen to arrest Lazybones.
target: Li anvoy kat lapolis pou aret Flanker.

input: The policemen caught Lazybones and put him in a gunny sack to bring him before the king.
target: Lapolis ti trap Flanker e ti met li dan enn sak gouni pou amenn li divan lerwa.

input: When the policemen passed by a shop, they all decided to have a little something to drink.
target: Ler lapolis ti pas divan enn laboutik, zot ti desid pou al bwar enn ti zafer.

input: They put the sack down by the side of the road, and went into the shop; each one took his turn paying for a round of drinks.
target: Zot poz sak dan bor sime, e zot ti rant laboutik; sakenn so tour pou pey so bwar.

input: Old Man Lazybones sat in the sack and pricked up his ears.
target: Bonom Flanker ti asiz dan sak e ti dres so zorey.
Li ti tann kikenn pe vini.

input: It was a shepherd with three hundred sheep.
target: Ti enn gardien mouton ar trwa san mouton.

input: When the shepherd came up to the sack, Lazybones began to cry inside, “O! God! What will I do?”.
target: Ler gardien la ti vinn kot sak la, Flanker ti koumans plore dan sak, "A! Bondie! Ki mo pou fer?”.

input: The king wants me to marry his daughter, so they have arrested me and put me in this sack.
target: Lerwa ole mo marye ar so tifi, alors zot finn may mwa e met mwa dan sa sak la.

input: But I am an old man, and the king’s daughter is so young and beautiful.
target: mo enn vie dimoun, tifi lerwa zenn ek zoli.

input: When water boils, that’s the time to put in the vegetables; my water has been cold for ages! Isn’t there anyone who can help me?
target: Kan dilo bwi, lerla ler pou met bred; lontan mo dilo finn fre! Eski ena kikenn pou ed mwa?

input: Anyone who would take my place?
target: Ena kikenn pou pran mo plas?

input: The shepherd heard all this, and said to Lazybones, “Hey, Old Man, if you want, I will take your place.”
target: Gardien mouton ti tann sa, e li ti dir Flanker, “E, bonom, si ou oule, mo pou pran ou plas.”

input: “Thank you, thank you, my friend! May God bless you! Open up the sack.”
target: "Mersi, mersi, mo kamarad! Bondie va beni ou! Ouver sak la.”

input: So he opened up the sack, and Lazybones got out.
target: Alors li ti ouver sak la, e Flanker ti sorti.

input: He put the shepherd in his place, tied up the sack, took the herd of sheep and left.
target: Li ti met gardien mouton dan so plas, li ti amar sak la, li ti pran troupo mouton e li ti ale.

input: When the four policemen came out of the shop, they picked up the sack.
target: Kan kat lapolis la ti sorti dan laboutik la, zot ti lev sak la.

input: “Hey! I would almost say this sack has got lighter, wouldn’t you?”
target: "E! Koumadir sak la mwens lour, non?"

input: It is the sugar-cane spirit that’s giving us strength.
target: Nam kann ki pe donn nou lafors.

input: When they came to the king’s house, the king said, “Tie a heavy rock to that sack and throw it into the pond.”
target: Ler zot ti ariv lakaz Lerwa, Lerwa ti dir, "Amar enn gro ros ar sa sak la e zet li dan basen."

input: Two or three days later, Lazybones passed by the door of the king’s house with his three hundred sheep.
target: Detrwa zour pli tar, Flanker ti pas divan laport Lerwa ar so trwa san mouton.

input: The king’s servant saw him, ran to the king and said, “King, King! That’s Old Man Lazybones passing by! Look at him with all those sheep!”
target: Domestik Lerwa ti trouv li, li ti galoupe al dir Lerwa, "Lerwa, Lerwa! Ala bonom Flanker pe pase! Get li ar tou so bann mouton!"

input: He asked him where he’d got all those sheep.
target: Li ti dimann li akot li ti gagn tou sa mouton la.

input: Thank you so much for having me thrown in there.
target: Gran mersi ou finn zet mwa ladan.

input: When I have finished selling these three hundred sheep, I will just go and get some more there.
target: Kan mo fini vann sa trwa san mouton la, mo pou al sers ankor laba.

input: The king said, “Not a word more! I order that you put me in a sack and throw me into the pond!”
target: Lerwa dir, "Pa dir mwa! Mo donn lord ki zot met mwa dan sak e zet mwa dan basen!”

input: So they put the king in a sack and threw him into the pond.
target: Alors zot met Lerwa dan sak e zet li dan basen.

input: The waters opened, they made huge ripples and the sack sank.
target: Dilo ouver, fer gran serk e sak la ti koule.

input: Lazybones stood at the side of the pond dancing a sega and singing:
target: Flankerti dibout dan bor basen la pik enn sega e li sante:

input: “Sheep are not fish My king! Sheep are not fish.”
target: "Mouton napa pwason Mo lerwa! Mouton napa pwason."

input: The tale of the bird that laid golden eggs.
target: Zwazo ki ti ponn dizek lor.

input: Once upon a time there was a hunter who loved to go bird hunting.
target: Enn fwa ti ena enn saser ki ti kontan al lasas zwazo.

input: One day he caught a bird with golden feathers in his net.
target: Enn zour li ti may enn zwazo ki ti ena plim dore dan so nik.

input: Early every morning the bird laid an egg.
target: Toulegramaten sa zwazo la ti ponn enn dizef.

input: The hunter sold the egg to the king’s cook.
target: Saser la ti vann sa dizef la ar kwizinie lerwa.

input: When the cook broke the egg in order to fry it, he found a lump of gold inside.
target: Ler kwizinie ti kas dizef la pou kwi li, li ti trouv enn boul lor ladan.

input: The cook was a clever fellow.
He could hold his tongue, and said not a word to anyone.
target: Li ti res trankil, e li pa ti dir sa personn.

input: I do not have to write all my thoughts on my forehead.
target: Pa finn ekrir kouyon lor mo fron.

input: And so early every morning he kept the lump of gold for himself.
target: E alors toulegramaten li ti gard sa boul lor la pou li.

input: One day the queen needed some eggs to bake a cake.
target: Enn zour larenn ti bizen inpe dizef pou fer enn gato.

input: But the cook was not there.
She took one of the eggs from the basket.
target: Li ti pran enn dizef dan pagne.

input: Of course, out rolled the lump of gold.
target: Normal, boul lor la ti roul anba.

input: The queen bent down, picked up the lump, and examined it closely.
target: Larenn ti bes anba, li ti ramas boul la, ek li ti ekzaminn li de pre.

input: The cook came back into the kitchen.
target: Kwizinie la ti rant dan lakouzinn.

input: And just where do you have this egg from, boy?
target: E akot ou ti gagn sa dizef la, mo garson?

input: That is one of the eggs I bought from a woman called Old Lady Laouret, whose husband catches birds.
target: Sa enn dizef bann dizef mo finn aste ar enn bonnfam apel bonnfam Laouret, ki so mari saser zwazo.

input: The queen said not a word, and left the kitchen.
target: Larenn pa ti dir enn mo, e li ti ale.

input: Now, the queen had a son.
target: Aster, Larenn la ti ena enn garson.

input: One day when the boy was out taking a walk, he passed by Old Lady Laouret’s house, and he went in.
target: Enn zour, kouma garson la ti pe promne, li ti pas divan lakaz bonnfam Laouret, e li ti rant andan.

input: There he found a bird, and he took a closer look.
target: Laba li ti trouv enn zwazo, e li get li pli pre.

input: This bird was more beautiful than any other bird.
target: Zwazo la ti pli zoli ke lezot zwazo.

input: Hey, Old Lady; sell me your bird.
target: E, bonnfam; vann mwa ou zwazo.

input: That bird over there is for sale.
The king’s son played for a while with the bird, turning it over and over.
target: Garson lerwa ti badinn ar zwazo la, li ti vir-vir li.

input: All of a sudden it raised its wing.
target: Enn kou li ti lev so lezel.

input: Something was written beneath the wing.
target: Kiksoz ti ekrir anba lezel la.

input: The boy read, “Whoever eats my head will receive a sack of money every morning; whoever eats my heart will receive a sack of gold every evening.”
target: Garson la ti lir, "Saki manz mo latet va gagn enn sak larzan toulegramaten; saki manz mo leker va gagn enn sak lor touleswar."

input: The boy said not a word, he left the bird, and returned to his mother’s house, and told her all he had seen.
target: Garson pa ti dir nanye, li ti kit zwazo la e li ti retourn lakaz so mama, e li ti rakont li tou seki li ti trouve.

input: Together they planned what to do.
target: Zot de ti tir enn plan k pou fer.

input: Old Lady Laouret had a young daughter.
target: Bonnfam Laouret ti ena enn zen tifi.

input: The queen said to her son, “Do you know what we need to do? You must marry Old Lady Laouret’s daughter, that way we will get her bird.”
target: Larenn ti dir so garson, "To kone ki nou bizen fer? To bizin marye ar tifi bonnfam Laouret, Koumsa nou pou gagn so zwazo."

input: The queen’s son ran to Laouret’s house, and said to her, “Old Lady, I love your daughter, and want to marry her, give her to me; what do you say?”
target: Garson lerwa ti galoupe,li ti al lakaz Laouret, li ti dir li, "Bonnfam! Mo kontan ou tifi, e mo anvi marye ar li, donn mwa li; ki ou dir?"

input: Now! Now! Don’t be funny! You are the king’s son, my daughter is just a poor little girl.
target: Aster! Aster! Drol tousa! Ou enn garson lerwa, mo tifi zis enn pov tifi.

input: How could I believe that your mother would be satisfied with such a daughter-in-law who wears gunny-sack dresses?
target: Kouma ou ole mo kwar ki ou mama pou kontan enn belfi ki met rob   gouni?

input: But it was my mother herself who sent me here to ask to marry your daughter.
target: Me mo mama mem ki finn anvoy mwa dimann pou marye ar ou tifi.

input: The old lady laughed and shook her head, “Oh sir! You’re just joking with me!”
target: Bonnfam la ti riye, li ti sakouy so latet, "E ou, misie! Ou pe badine ar mwa!"

input: The king’s son went back to his mother’s house, and told her that Old Lady Laouret thought he was just talking nonsense; they would have to go there together.
target: Garson lerwa ti retourn lakaz so mama, li ti dir li ki bonnfam Laouret kwar ki li pe kok manti; zot de bizen al ansam.

input: So the queen took up her shawl, put on her hat and her best shoes, and together they went to Laouret’s house.
target: Larenn ti pran so sal, met so sapo e so pli bon soulye,e zot ti al ansam lakaz Laouret.

input: When the queen asked the woman for her daughter’s hand in marriage for her son, the woman was very happy and praised God.
target: Kan larenn ti dimann bonnfam la lame so tifi pou so garson, bonnfam ti bien kontan e li ti dir gran mersi bondie.

input: On the day we marry, you will kill the bird with the golden feathers, and you will put aside its heart and head for me to eat.
target: Me zour nou marye, ou va touy zwazo plim dore la e ou pou met so leker ek so latet enn kote pou mo manze.

input: The day of the wedding came.
The king’s son gave the bird to the cook, and said, “Cook the heart and head and put them aside for me, but do not use any curry”.
target: Garson lerwa ti donn zwazo la kwizinie, e li ti dir li, "Kwi so leker e latet e met zot enn kote pou mwa, me pa met masala”.

input: Now, I must tell you that old Laouret also had two sons.
target: Aster, mo bizen dir zot ki bonnfam Laouret ti ena de garson.

input: And these two sons could both read since they had been to the government school.
target: E sa de garson la ti konn lir e ekrir akoz zot ti al lekol gouvernman.

input: They had also read what was written beneath the bird’s wing.
target: Zot ousi ti lir ki ti ekrir anba lezel zwazo la.

input: They were keeping watch from the corner of the kitchen.
target: Zot tip e veye dan kwen lakouzinn.

input: When the cook left, they went inside and stole the bird’s heart and head from the pot and ran away.
target: Kan kwizinie la ti sorti, zot ti rant andan e zot ti kokin leker ek latet zwazo la dan marmit e zot ti sove.

input: When the cook brought the bird to the table, there was no heart, there was no head.
target: Ler kwizinie ti aport zwazo la lor latab, pa ti ena leker, pa ti ena latet.

input: The king’s son, let me tell you, fell into a terrible rage.
target: Garson lerwa ma, les mo dir ou, ti rant dan enn move lakoler.

input: He looked everywhere for Old Lady Laouret’s sons to kill them.
target: Li ti rod bann garson bonnfam Laouret pou touy zot.

input: But her two sons fled, and it was their bad luck that they ran into the wolf’s house to hide.
target: Me so de garson ti sove, e par malsans zot ti rant dan lakaz enn loulou pou kasiet.

input: The wolf grabbed them and ate them both up.
target: Loulou la ti may zot e ti manz zot de.

input: The tale of the stupid boy.
Once upon a time there was a woman who had a son, but the poor boy was very stupid. One day, his mother sent him to the market to buy an axe.
target: Enn fwa ti ena enn madam ki ti ena enn garson, me pov garson la ti bien bet.

input: On the way home, he played with the axe.
target: Enn zour, so mama ti avoy li bazaar pou aste enn lars.

input: He slashed here, he cut there.
target: Lor sime pou al lakaz, li ti pe zwe ar sa lars la.

input: When he finally came home, his mother’s little lamb was eating grass in the yard.
target: Li ti kogne isi, li tip e koup laba.

input: He cried, “Mama, Mama, see what a wonderful axe I bought for you!”
target: Kan li ti finalman rant lakaz, so mama so ti mouton ti pe manz lerb dan lakour.

input: And he cut off the lamb’s head in one blow.
target: Li ti kriye, "Mama, mama, gete ki fame lars mo finn aste pou ou!"

input: His mother became very angry, she shouted at him and asked him why he had not put the axe in a cart with straw.
target: E li ti koup latet mouton la enn sel kou.
So mama ti bien ankoler, li ti krier ar li e ti dimann li zour li, dir li kifer li pa ti met lars la dan enn saret lapay.

input: Then the little idiot began to cry and cry and asked his mother’s pardon.
target: Lerla nanrye pa ti pou arive.

input: The next day, the woman sent him to buy some needles, and she said to him, “Now remember what happened with the axe, and do not lose those needles!”
target: Lerla sa ti idio la ti koumans plore, plore e li ti dimann so mama pardon.

input: Off he went and soon he returned.
target: Lot zour, madam la ti avoy li aste zegwi, e li ti dir li, "Aster rapel ki ti arrive a lars la, e pa perdi sa bann zegwi la!"

input: The woman asked him, “All right! Where are my needles?”
target: Li ti ale e vit li ti retourne.

input: “Don’t worry, Mama, I paid attention to what you said”.
target: Madam la ti dimann li: "Korek! kot mo zegwi?"

input: On the way back home I met Mister John with his cart, and I hid the needles in the straw.
target: “Pa traka, mama, mo finn bien ekout ki ou ti dir”.

input: The woman was so disgusted with him.
target: Lor sime pou retourn lakaz mo ti zwenn saret misie Jean avek so saret, e mo finn kasiet bann zegwi la dan lapay.

input: Why didn’t you pin the needles to your hat.
target: Madam la ti plin ar li.
Kifer to pa ti pik bann zegwi la dan to sapo. Ala mo larzan finn perdi ankor.

input: The next day his mother sent him off again to buy some butter, and she said to him, “Now remember what happened with the needles, and don’t lose that butter.”
target: Enn lot zour so mama ti avoy li aste diber, e li ti dir li: "Aster rapel ki ti arrive ar bann zegwi, e pa perdi diber."

input: Off he went, bought the butter, and pinned it to his hat.
target: Li ti ale, li ti aste diber, li ti met diber dan so sapo.

input: The sun was so hot that the butter melted.
target: Soley ti telman for ki diber la ti fonn.

input: It ran down his face and onto his clothes, so that when he got home he was as dirty as a little pig.
target: Li ti koul lor so figir ek so lenz, alors kan li ti rant lakaz li ti sal kouma enn koson.

input: His mother raised her hands in the air, “What was God thinking, to put such an idiot on this earth!”
target: So mama ti lev lame an ler, "Kifer Bondie ti panse, pou met enn bourik kuma twa lor later!"

input: A month later, his mother gave him two chickens to sell.
target: Enn mwa pli tar, so mama ti donn li de volay pou vande.

input: Since he could not buy things properly, may be he could sell something: “But you should not sell the chickens at the first price you are offered, wait for the second offer.”
target: Parski li pa konn aste kitsoz bien, kikfwa li ti pou konn vand kitsoz: "Me pa bizen vann sa volay la premie pri ki zot ofer twa, atann segon pri."

input: “All right, Mama, I will wait for the second price, do you think I am that stupid?”
target: "Bien sir, mama, mo pou atann segon pri, ou kwar mo bet?"

input: He met a cook, and the cook asked him how much the chickens cost.
target: Li ti zwenn enn kwizinie, e kwizinie ti dimann li komie so poul koute.

input: The cook took the chickens and looked them over, “Seven rupees and ten cents, if you like.”
target: Kwizinie la ti pran volay la e ti get li partou,  "Set roupi e dis sou, si ou kontan."

input: “That’s your first price, what is your second one?”
target: "Sa ou premie pri, ki ou segon?”

input: Now, the cook decided to have some fun with him.
target: Aster, kwizinie la ti desid pou trik li.

input: So he told him six rupees and five cents.
target: Alors li ti dir li sis roupi e senk sou.

input: I will take your six rupees and five cents.
target: Mo pou pran ou sis roupi e senk sou.

input: I always take the second price when I am selling something.
target: Mo touzour pran segon pri kan mo pe vann kitsoz.

input: He returned home, and told his mother what had happened.
target: Li ti retourn lakaz, e li ti rakont sa so mama ki ti arive.

input: The woman was furious and wanted to beat him, so he had to run and hide.
target: Madam la ti firye e ti rod bat li, alors li ti oblize galoupe al kasiet.

input: Another time the woman gave him a sheep to sell.
target: Enn lot kou madam la ti donn li enn mouton pou al vande.

input: But don’t do the same thing with my sheep as you did with my chickens.
target: Me pa fer parey ar mo mouton kouma to ti  fer ar mo volay.

input: People will offer you a price, let them raise that price until they can not raise it any more.
target: Dimoun pou ofer twa enn pri, les zot mont pri la ziska zot pa kapav mont plis.

input: Then you can sell them the sheep.
target: Lerla to kapav vann mouton la.

input: You heard me now, don’t forget what I have told you.
target: To finn tann mwa aster, pa bliye saki mo finn dir twa.

input: Along the way, he met a butcher.
target: Lor sime, li ti zwenn enn bouse.

input: The butcher offered him eight rupees.
target: Bouse la ti ofer li wit roupi.

input: Not high enough, you will have to go higher.
target: Pa ase ot, ou bizin mont pli ot.

input: The butcher’s son knew about the poor idiot, and tugged at his father’s sleeve, and said.
target: Garson sa bouse la ti konn sa pov idio la, e ti ris lamans so papa, e li ti dir.

input: Papa, leave this to me, I can handle him.
target: Papa, les sa dan mo lame, mo kone kouma fer zafer ar li.

input: There was a ladder leaning up against the wall.
target: Ti ena enn lesel apiye ar miray.

input: The butcher’s son climbed up on it.
target: Garson bouse la ti mont lor li.

input: At the first step of the ladder, he said, “Seven rupees”.
target: Lor premie bar lesel la, li ti dir, "Set roupi".

input: Climbing up a step, he said, “Six rupees”.
target: Li ti mont enn bar, li ti kriye, "Sis roupi".

input: Climbing up another step, he said, “Five rupees”.
target: Li ti mont enn lot bar, li ti kriye, "senk roupi".

input: And when he got to the top, with no more steps left, he said, “Two rupees, you can see that I can’t go any higher!”
target: E ler li ti ariv lao, pa ti ena okenn bar ankor, li ti dir, "De roupi, e to kapav trouve ki mo pa kapav al ankor lao!”

input: If you can not go any higher, what else can we do?
target: Si ou pa kapav mont ankor lao, ki nou kapav fer?

input: Take the sheep, and give me the two rupees.
target: Pran mouton, e donn mwa de roupi la.

input: He went back home, gave his mother the two rupees, and told her what had happened.
target: Li ti retourn lakaz, li ti donn so mama de roupi la, e li ti dir li tou seki ti arive.

input: The poor woman picked up a broom and gave him a beating.
target: Pov madam la ti pran enn balie e ti donn li enn rakle.

input: The poor idiot got such a blow on the head and he went mad.
target: Pov idio la ti gagn enn kou dan so latet e li vinn fou.

input: And that was the last time I ever saw him at the market.
target: E sa ti dernie fwa mo ti trouv li dan bazar.

input: The historic bourgeoisie was too strong economically and politically, as well as in the media, so it won.
target: Burzwazi istorik ti tro for ekonomikman ek politikman ek osi dan medya, alor, li finn gayne.

input: When, before that, the Leal, Kalachand or Ganee Moossa family businesses benefited from State support and became little empires, it was not their community that counted but the fact that Labour, through bourgeois democracy, was helping smaller capitalists by giving them “chances” to challenge the historic bourgeoisie.
target: Kan avan sa, biznes familyal Leal, Kalachand uswa Ganee Moossa ti benefisye depi sutyin Leta e finn vinn bann ti-lanpir, li pa ti zot kominote ki ti konte, me lefet ki Travayis, atraver demokrasi burzwa, ti pe ed pli kapitalis mwayen, donn zot lokazyon pu chalennj burzwazi istorik.

input: Just as right now the State is helping the Maurel’s, Gowreesoo’s and Rawat’s to get more of the blanket on their side of the bed, at a time when the sugar estates are set to rake in fortunes on their exports and from their Integrated Resort Scheme real estate deals, and when the New Mauritius Hotels is declaring over a billion rupees in profits for the past six months.
target: Parey kuma asterla, Leta pe ed Maurel, Gowreesoo ek Rawat ris dra zot kote lili dan enn lepok kot tablisman finn fini pare pu tap “windfall gains” lor seki zot exporte, lor lavant vila Integrated Resort Scheme. E li enn lepok kot New Mauritius Hotels pe deklar plis ki enn milyar rupi profi zis pu dernye sis mwa.

input: We should not befuddle our understanding of present-day history, driven as it is by economic and class forces, by handicapping ourselves through wearing, like race-horses, “race blinkers”.
target: Fale pa nu bruye nu konpreansyon seki pe arive dan listwar par met vizyer “ras” lor nu lizye, etan done ki se derulman lekonomi ek bann konfli ant klas ki pe konstitye listwar.

input: Anyway, the historic bourgeoisie is still stuck to its sugar-cane and mills, while desperately trying to cut losses by centralizing into four “clusters”, diversifying within sugar (mainly into electricity and ethanol) and delocalizing to places like Mozambique, Côte Ivoire, Tanzania and Benin.
target: Detutfason, burzwazi istorik ankor byen tase ar so kann ek so mulin, mem si li pe rod amorti so lapert dan reveni kan pri disik pe degringole, atraver santralize dan kat “klester”, diversifye alinteryer disik (sirtu dan elektrisite ek etanol) ek delokalize, al Mozambique, Tanzani, Kot Ivwar ubyen Benin.

input: It is getting the lion’s share of the billions of money called “accompanying measures” from the European Union as compensation for the end of protectionism.
target: Li pe gayn enn gro par dan “mezir akonpaynman” Linyon Eropyen kuma konpansasyon pu lafen proteksyonism.

input: Now, Government, in its attack on the historic bourgeoisie, is saying:  Hold on! Hand over 2,000 arpents of land first!
target: Aster Guvernman, kan li pe atak burzwazi istorik, pe dir Atann enn ku! Donn 2,000 arpan later avan!

input: Don’t expect a price increase for sugar sold locally!
target: Pa krwar u pu gayn enn ogmantasyon dan pri disik lokal!

input: Foot more of the bill for the laying off of workers!
target: U bizen pey plis kan u pe met travayer deor!

input: The historic bourgeoisie cries, in reply: “New conditions? Down with new conditions!”
target: Burzwazi istorik li, reponn, kriye “Nuvo kondisyon? Nu pa ule!”

input: The historic bourgeoisie also still controls a good deal of the import trade, much of it on a monopoly basis.
target: Burzwazi istorik osi kontrol enn gro par inportasyon, ek li ena monopol lor enn gran parti sa sekter la.

input: The Government threatens it with the Competition Bill: “No more controlling imports and retailing! No more one company holding too big a share of the market! No more stocking only one brand-mark!”
target: Guvernman pe menas li ar Competition Bill: “U nepli gayn drwa dan inportasyon ek komers detayan anmemtan! Nepli pu ena monopol ki kontrol marse preske net! Nepli pu les u gard zis enn mark!”

input: Rogers, Blyth and other huge companies cringe.
target: Rogers, Blyth ek lezot gran konpayni pe akiz ku.

input: The historic bourgeoisie has also still stuck to the textiles that it has invested in over the past 30 or 40 years, though the sector has gone hi-tech, delocalized to Madagascar, Bangladesh and India, and brought in contract workers from abroad to live in hostels and work work work, undercutting Mauritian labour practices.
target: Burzwazi istorik finn osi tas ar sekter textil dan lekel li finn investi dan dernye 30, 40 an, mem ki sa sekter la finn modernize, vinn hi-tech, mem si li finn delokalize al Madagascar, Bangladesh ek Lenn, e mem si li finn amenn travayer depi deor pu res dan dortwar travay, travay, travay, ziska anmemtan kas tradisyon indistriyel ki finn devlope dan Moris.

input: The historic bourgeoisie has also invested in tourism and finance.
target: Burzwazi istorik finn osi investi dan turism ek finans.

input: And it has, since converting agricultural land into rich men’s ghettoes, made windfall gains in real estate.
target: E li finn fer gro profi enn sel kut kan li finn konverti later agrikol an later rezidansyel, fer sato pu milyoner.

input: This is, as Ram Seegobin points out, a direct result of changes in Government Regulations designed to give them such windfall gains.
target: Sa li rezilta direk sanzman dan regleman guvernman, sanzman ki finn kalkile expre pu donn sa gro profi imedya la, kuma Ram Seegobin finn demontre.

input: And yet the historic bourgeoisie expects support of the State to go on and on.
target: Purtan burzwazi istorik pe atann ki sutyin Leta pu kontinye san-ses.

input: A real estate bubble is also threatening to burst on them, as even the new Governor of the Bank of Mauritius is predicting.
target: Mem kan nuvo Guverner Labank Moris pe predir gran problem kote spekilasyon lor later.

input: Because of sugar and textiles being historically so intertwined into the rest of the economy, their collapse has systemic implications.
target: Telman disik ek textil liye ansam avek tu leres lekonomi Moris, ekrulman sa de sekter la ena konsekans lor sistem la an-antye.

input: The historic bourgeoisie is often allied with French and/or South African capital.
target: Burzwazi istorik byin suvan fer lalyans avek kapital Franse ubyen Sidafrikin.

input: This external support dates back to the period of pre-1810 French colonization, and to the Apartheid era, respectively.
target: Sa form lalyans la li dat depi avan 1810 lepok kolonizasyon Franse, ek depi lepok Aparteid dan ka Sidafrik.

input: When the sugar estates have partners from the French bourgeoisie for their electricity production plans, for example, then Europe’s “accompanying money” to the Mauritian Government becomes like the payment of European money to its own “Fifth Column”, the French bourgeoisie through its joint ventures with the Mauritian historic bourgeoisie.
target: Kan tablisman fer lalyans avek burzwazi Franse pu prodiksyon elektrisite, par ekzanp, lerla Lerop so “mezir akonpaynman” a guvernman Moris vinn kumadir enn peyman a so prop “5yem kolonn”, a burzwazi Franse ki dan lalyans ar tablisman.

input: This is probably one of the insinuations Prime Minister Ramgoolam intends when he reminds the private sector spokesmen, Mr. De Navacelle, that Mauritius “isn’t a colony any more”.
target: Sa li explik an-parti seki Premye Minis Ramgoolam pe dir kan li averti M. de Navacelle ki Moris “nepli enn koloni”.

input: The historic bourgeoisie expects to continue getting the same State support is has had throughout modern history when it has been in an alliance, even though often conflictual, with the politically strong small planters, which has ensured a fairly stable ruling block.
target: Burzwazi istorik atann ki li pu gayn mem sutyin Leta ki li finn gayne tutolong listwar modern kan li finn an-alyans laplipar ditan avek ti-planter ki politikman enn klas byen for, avek lekel li finn forz enn blok istorik pu li dirize.

input: Meanwhile, the State-supported bourgeoisie continues to build smaller empires up into bigger ones with help from direct and indirect State intervention, as it has done, particularly from Labour Party Governments since even before Independence.
target: Antretan, burzwazi deta kontinye batir so bann lanpir, fer zot vinn pli gran avek led direk ek indirek Leta, parey kuma li finn fer depi bann guvernman Travayis depi avan Lindepandans.

input: See how it works:  The Labour Government, in opposing the sugar oligarchs, supports the Maurel Alcodis plant which happens to be in the back-yard of the nationalized sugar estate Rose Belle;
target: Anu gete kuma sa travay: guvernman Travayis, kan li pe opoz oligarsi sikriyer, sutenir konpayni Maurel, ‘Alcodis’, ki dan lakur tablisman nasyonalize Rose-Belle;

input: when the plant needs the same molasses the sugar estates wanted for their own energy production, Government removes the ethanol component from the clusters being set up by the Sugar Industry Efficiency Act.
target: kan so lizinn pe bizen melas ki tablisman pu bizen pu so prop prodiksyon lenerzi, guvernman retir seksyon lor etanol ki ti pe mete dan Sugar Industry Efficiency Act.

input: The Labour Government supports both the local Gowreesoo’s Samlo iron-and-steel plant and also the Murray-Roberts (South African construction firm that is in alliance with the Indian giant Mittal) as together, they wrest control over what was mainly a Rogers’ Desbro sector, again attacking the historic bourgeoisie.
target: Guvernman Travayis sutenir enn Gowreesoo so Samlo ek osi Murray-Roberts (konpayni konstriksyon Sid Afrikin ki an-alyans avek konpayni zean Indyin, Mittal) kan tulede zot lager pu gayn kontrol lor sa sekter ki ti sirtu su kontrol Rogers so Desbro, ankor enn fwa se burzwazi istorik ki su atak.

input: Labour supports the Rawat empire v/s the historic bourgeoisie in the fields of telecommunications, investment companies, private hospitals, retail trade, to name just some of the fields.
target: Travayis sutenir lanpir Rawat kan li pe lager kont burzwazi istorik dan domenn telekominikasyon, konpayni investisman, lopital prive, komers detayan, pu donn zis enn-de lekzanp.

input: The Labour Government brings in the massive Tian Li project from China, with its 17 billion-rupee investment.
target: Guvernman Travayis finn amenn sa gran proze Tian Li depi Lasinn avek so investisman Rs 17 milyar.

input: It allies CEB with a Malaysian company.
target: Li finn ankuraz CEB fer lalyans avek enn konpayni Malezyin.

input: It encourages Indian investment in the Land Based Oceanic Industry and in the petroleum products trade, creating space for Indian Oil to compete with the previous oligopoly.
target: Li ankuraz investisman Lenn dan Land Based Oceanic Industry, ek li kre lespas pu Indian Oil rant an-konpetisyon avek oligarsi ki ti ena kontrol lor sa sekter la.
