input: Even the press empires that have, over the years, in all crucial conflicts supported the historic bourgeoisie, often in the most embarrassingly abject ways, are now challenged by a press group that is close to the State-supported bourgeoisie.
target: Mem dan lapres, ena enn grup lagazet ki pros avek burzwazi deta ki pe chalennj sa seksyon lapres ki finn pandan dezane sutenir burzwazi istorik sirtu dan bann moman kle, parfwa dan enn fason abjek.

input: We note that the Labour Government has, like the MSM before it, favoured the “Eastern option” for its preferred source of foreign investment and for its challenges against the historic bourgeoisie, which continues to rely on French and South African capital, as it beats off the challenge.
target: Remarke ki guvernman Travayis, parey kuma MSM avan li, finn favoriz “opsyon Loryan” pu gayn investisman etranzer ek pu ki li chalennj burzwazi istorik ki kontinye fye lor kapital Franse ek Sid Afrikin dan sa batay la.

input: And as the two sections of the bourgeoisie go into conflict, the Prime Minister attacks the historic bourgeoisie and at the same time attacks the Unions.
target: Amizir sa de seksyon burzwazi pe lager, Premye Minis atak anmemtan burzwazi istorik ek sindika.

input: This makes it look, at least for the moment, as if it is heading for a Bonapartist form of government.
target: Sa fer li paret, dimwin pu lemoman, ase Bonapartist.

input: In the past Labour relied on some conscious working class support, but right now it attacks the working class and its Unions, which are reeling under the attack.
target: Dan lepase, Travayis ti fye lor inpe sutyin konsyan klas travayer, me asterla li pe atak klas travayer ek so sindika.

input: In the past, the Labour Party in 1953, Labour has always, in the last analysis, protected the State bourgeoisie and those specific capitalists in the historic bourgeoisie who “co-operate” in its political plan to broaden the social base of the bourgeoisie.
target: Dan lepase, Travayis finn tuzur protez burzwazi deta an-dernye lye e osi protez kapitalist dan burzwazi istorik ki “kopere” dan so plan politik pu elarzi baz sosyal burzwazi.

input: Government has in 2007 set up the “tripartite” National Pay Council mentioned earlier.
target: Guvernman finn met dibut National Pay Council “tripartit” an 2007.

input: It is charged with settling annual wage compensation bureaucratically instead of politically as has been the case since 1972, and, significantly, taking into account from now onwards “productivity” and “capacity for the employer to pay”, as well as the rise in the Cost Price Index.
target: So travay se pu regle kestyon konpansasyon saler anyel dan enn fason birokratik olye dan enn fason politik, kuma li finn ete depi 1972, ek kan li fer sa, li ena pu pran ankonsiderasyon apartir aster la “prodiktivite” ek “kapasite pu anplwayer peye”, osi byin ki ogmantasyon CPI.

input: The unions rightly boycotted this “tripartite” Council, and the Government has nominated five individual trade unionists of its own choice.
target: Avek rezon, sindika finn boykot sa Konsey “tripartit” la ek guvernman finn nom senk sindikalist de so swa.

input: As the union movement is in this important battle against Government, another battle looms on the horizon: the replacement of existing industrial relations legislation.
target: Amizir muvman sindikal dan sa batay inportan kont guvernman, enn lot batay pe aprose: ranplasman lalwa indistriyel.

input: Many of the unions are still probably in the pro-capitalist arms of the MMM, MSM and UN from the days of the recent “Platform National”.
target: Laplipar sindika pu riske ankor su lanpriz MMM ek MSM ki ti fek ansam avek zot dan Platform Nasyonal.

input: MTUC will potentially split in two since Yousouf Sooklall’s nomination to the NPC and his suspension from the MTUC.
target: MTUC riske eklate etan done ki Yousouf Sooklall finn nome dan NPC e finn sispann dan so konfederasyon.

input: GWF and FPU have been split into some five or six federations, in the midst of vitriolic fights amongst bureaucrats and trade union “controllers”, who are also often bureaucrats of the worst ilk.
target: GWF ek FPU finn morsle an senk federasyon atraver lager ant birokrat ek “kontroler” sindika ki suvan birokrat zot-mem.

input: Clearly, the systemic crisis has hit the trade union movement, itself.
target: Klerman, kriz sistemik finn rant dan muvman sindikal.

input: In addition to the working class proper being under attack, small planters and fishermen, small traders and small entrepreneurs are also under attack, both by the implacable logic of capitalism itself and as a result of specific options the Government has taken.
target: Anplis ki klas travayer su atak, ena atak kont ti-planter, peser, ti-komersan ek ti-antreprener. Zot atake par lozik kapitalism limem ek osi par desizyon Guvernman.

input: Sporadic demonstrations, some of them very creative like blocking pleasure crafts with small pirogues out at sea, take place all over, but end, so far, with offers of money compensation, in exchange for things that have more than money value, like the land and the sea and the right to work.
target: Tusala finn provok enn seri manifestasyon, timama isi timama laba, ena fwa byin kreatif kuma kan peser ti reysi blok lamer avek pirog. Me, san enn vizyon pli larz, tusala malerezman pur lemoman pe fini avek lof konpansasyon an-esanz pu kitsoz ki depas propriete prive, ki depas valer larzan, kuma later, lamer ek drwa pu travay.
Sa dezord dan lekonomi, antretan, finn fane partu.

input: Robberies and hold-ups get more audacious. Crimes more horrific.
target: Ena vol, hold-ep deplizanpli oze. Krim plis efreyan.

input: Reported cases of rape and incest rise so high that one realizes it cannot be only the reporting that is increasing.
target: Ka vyol ek insest raporte finn ogmante telman ki nepli kapav explik li par plis dimunn pe fer rapor.

input: The Government replies by threatening more and more repression.
target: Guvernman reponn tu sa problem sosyal par menas plis represyon ankor.

input: Sentences of 60 years are now being introduced.
This will, in turn, make the prisons even less manageable than they already.
target: Sa pu fer prizon vinn ankor plis difisil pu zere. Deza zot pe gayn difikilte pu zer prizon.

input: The repression used against drugs has only served to aggravate the problem.
target: Represyon ki finn servi kont ladrog finn zis agrav problem la.

input: Now prostitution, especially around drug-takers, but also around tourism, has spread into new area after new area.
target: Aster prostitisyon, sirtu ki ti santre otur ladrog ek turism, pe rant dan tu rezyon.

input: The overlapping of drug abuse with the sex trade makes the control of the HIV-Aids spread very difficult.
target: Problem ladrog ek prostitisyon fer li byin difisil pu kontrol lepidemi HIV-Sida.

input: Mini-riots tend to break out in neighbourhoods, here and there, with people burning tyres in the roads, as they express the distress of a fatal road accident or a lack of a water supply.
target: Ase suvan ena ti-lemet dan diferan landrwa, kot dimunn bril karotsu omilye sime ziska tar dan aswar apre ki finn ena enn aksidan larut ki finn amenn mortalite, uswa kan pu plizir zur pa pe gayn dilo.

input: The politics of creating a new society.
And from all this disorder, human beings have to forge something new.
target: Dan tu sa dezord la, imin bizen batir enn nuvo lord.

input: But that is the task before us.
target: Me samem travay ki divan nu.

input: Moving from where we are today, to where we can be tomorrow.
target: Nu bizen devlop enn sime ki pu ed nu buz depi kot nu ete zordi, al ver enn nuvo dime ki ansam nu pu batir.

input: That is the collective task before us.
These three essays are one of Lalit’s contributions.
target: Sa trwa papye la enn kontribisyon Lalit dan reponn a sa defi la.

input: Because part of any program for change is understanding.
target: Sa li akoz konpreansyon li form parti seki enn program pu sanzman vedir.
Sa konpreansyon la li bizen kitsoz ki partaze, ki ankomin.

input: This shared understanding must be conscious.
target: Sa konpreansyon ankomin la li bizen konsyan.

input: That is what makes our conscious actions perkitan in our history that now lies before us.
target: Zis kan li konsyan ki nu aksyon pu perkitan dan sa listwar ki nu ena divan nu.

input: Does it address the real problems?
target: Ziska ki pwen li ena lyen avek problem reel dan pei?

input: Can it do anything to solve them?
This paper doesn’t aim to give any sort of global analysis of the content of the budget.
target: Bi sa papye-la li pa ditu pu fer enn analiz global de seki ena dan Bidze.

input: That work has already been done in our initial reaction to the budget, the night of the budget speech.
target: Li enn travay ki anfet finn deza fer, dan nu premye reaksyon, mem swar ki diskur Bidze.

input: Our comments have also been published in the press, Lalit members have been on radio programs, and we have circulated documents, too.
target: Nu reaksyon finn pibliye dan lapres, mamb Lalit finn al dan program lor radyo, e nu finn sirkil bann dokiman avek analiz Lalit lor Bidze.

input: So we have already commented on the budget, as a whole.
target: Alor nu finn deza fini komante lor Bidze dan so globalite.

input: Today itself (Sunday 25th June 2006), in the Week-End newspaper, there is an interview of Lindsey Collen in which she talks about the budget globally.
target: Zordi-mem [Dimans 25 Zin], dan lagazet Week-End ena enn intervyu Lindsey Collen kot li finn koz lor Bidze.

input: What I intend to do, instead, is to analyze the budget to see how far Finance Minister Rama Sithanen’s proposals address the present economic and social crisis, and compare his supposed solutions with Lalit’s own proposals.
target: Bi sa papye-la se pu get Bidze, me par rapor a ki solisyon ki Sithanen pe propoze lor kriz ekonomik ek sosyal dan lekel nu ete, e pu konpar bann sipoze solisyon ki Sithanen pe propoze avek seki Lalit pe propoze.

input: So, we will compare this budget with our program. We launched a political program for an alternative economy quite a while ago, even before the General Elections.
target: Alor, nu pu konpar sa Bidze la avek program ki nu, nu pe amene. Nu finn lans enn Program pu enn Lekonomi Alternativ, depi ase lontan, anfet depi avan eleksyon zeneral.

input: And in our electoral campaign, it was the political program for an alternative economy, which was really the pillar of our electoral campaign, whether on radio, on television or in our indoor meetings, or public outdoor meetings we held.
target: E dan kanpayn elektoral, se sa politik ekonomik alternativ ki ti inpe lepinn dorsal nu kanpayn elektoral lor radyo, lor televisyon e dan bann renyon e miting.

input: Sithanen in his budget acknowledges the seriousness of the crisis, especially in terms of employment and unemployment.
target: Alor, Sithanen dan so Bidze li konstat kriz ekonomik, li konstat lanpler kriz-la, sirtu an term anplwa, anterm somaz.

input: But when he comes to making proposals for possible solutions, these are diametrically opposed to Lalit’s.
target: Me anfet kan li vinn propoz bann solisyon, li vinn propoz bann solisyon ki dyametralman opoze ek seki nu dan Lalit pe propoze.

input: I would like to underline that when we proposed an alternative political economy during the course of the election campaign, we made it clear that both the Social Alliance and the MSM-MMM Alliance, whichever would form the next government after the elections, would go ahead and implement ultra-liberal policies – no matter what they said in the campaign.
target: Mo fer resortir ki kan nu ti pe propoz sa politik ekonomik alternativ avan eleksyon, nu ti pe dir, a lepok, ki nerport lekel dan sa 2 blok politik, ki li Lalyans Sosyal, ki li Lalyans MSM-MMM, nernport lekel ki form prosen guvernman apre eleksyon, li pu ena enn politik ekonomik iltra-liberal.

input: That is, we predicted that either Alliance, when it came to power, would impose a “solution” to this economic crisis that would shift the entire burden of this crisis on to the backs of the poor and the working class, who are in no way to blame for the crisis.
target: Setadir nu ti predir ki zot pu rod bann solisyon a kriz ekonomik ki fer klas travayer ek dimunn mizer sarye tu fardo pu sa kriz-la.

input: In fact, the bourgeoisie and past governments, by refusing to anticipate what would quite obviously happen in the textile and sugar industries and what is now, in fact, happening, are responsible for this crisis.
target: Dayer, kriz ki anfet responsabilite burzwazi, responsabilite bann ansyen guvernman.

input: And they did not predict that the two crises would happen at the same time, either.
target: E zot pa finn antisipe ki pu arive e dan textil e dan disik, ni ki li pu arive anmemtan.

input: This double crisis is something that has been lurking around for the past 20 years, and everybody knew it was coming.
target: Sa li enn zafer ki pe vini depi 10 an, depi 20 an. Tu dimunn ti kone.

input: But neither the bosses nor the political parties that successively came to power anticipated the problem as it could have and should have been anticipated.
target: Me ni patrona, ni bann rezim politik ki finn swiv enn apre lot pa finn antisip problem-la kuma ti bizin.

input: In our electoral campaign we also warned against austerity measures, and the way they would be imposed by the State through repression.
target: Dan nu kanpayn elektoral nu ti mem met angard kont enn politik losterite.

input: These were the very words we used in our party political broadcasts on TV and radio during the electoral campaign.
target: Se bann mo ki nu ti servi kan nu ti fer nu bann program lor TV ek radyo pandan kanpayn elektoral.

input: It is quite funny really to hear the MMM and its leader Bérenger denouncing this budget as “ultra-liberal”.
target: Zordi MMM fer inpe gayn riye kan Berenger pe vinn tret sa Bidze la de “iltra-liberal”.
Berenger limem li ena enn politik iltra-liberal.

input: May be he means Sithanen’s budget is not just ultra-liberal but ultra-ultra-liberal [Laughter], which is true.
target: Kan aster li pe dir ki Bidze Sithanen iltra-liberal, mo sipoze li pe dir “iltra-iltra-liberal”. (Dimunn riye.) E sa li vre.

input: This is of course the type of demagogy we expect from a parliamentary opposition like the MMM.
target: Sa li inpe demagozi ki nu ti kapav atann depi lopozisyon parlmanter.

input: Today whatever the MMM says, it can say the exact opposite at the same time, without batting an eyelid.
target: Zordi MMM kapav dir nerport ki ete, e lerla li kapav vinn dir so lekontrer anmemtan.

input: The first thing I’ll do is to analyze what the Social Alliance Government’s budget proposes to do in the context of this economic and social crisis.
target: Enn premye zafer ki nu pu fer, se gete kimanyer Bidze sa guvernman Lalyans Sosyal propoze pu fer fas a kriz ekonomik ek sosyal.

input: We will judge this by looking at specific measures in the budget.
target: Nu pu ziz sa atraver bann mezir spesifik dan Bidze.

input: Then we can look at how we intend to continue our campaign after the budget.
target: Kimanyer apre sa Bidze-la (parski Bidze-la li la), kimanyer nu pu kontinye nu kanpayn?

input: We have already heard the Budget Speech in the National Assembly. It has been examined in the “Committee Stage”. It’s been voted.
target: Finn fini ena Diskur Bidze dan Lasanble Nasyonal, finn ena so lexamen dan “komite”, e Bidze finn vote.

input: So, the budget is now a fact.
target: Alor Bidze-la aster li enn done.

input: So, we will be looking at how, we, in Lalit, given that there’s this new budget with its own specific measures, will need to adapt our ongoing campaign.
target: Kimanyer, nu, onivo Lalit, kimanyer lefet ki ena enn tel Bidze, lefet ki ena sa bann mezir-la, kimanyer li vinn afekte manyer nu pu kontinye nu kanpayn.

input: This will also be an important aspect of today’s theoretical seminar.
target: Sa osi li pu enn laspe inportan dan travay ki nu pu bizen fer zordi pandan nu Seminar Teorik.

input: So we will look at specific measures in the budget, and at how we will modify our campaign given these new measures being brought in for the next year to come, and perhaps having effects for many years after that, too.
target: Analiz Bidze-la par rapor a bann solisyon ki finn propoze, e osi gete kimanyer nu bizen rektifye, modifye nu kanpayn par rapor a seki aster enn done pu ankor omwen enn an, e anfet pu plizir banane ki pe vini.

input: The title of the Budget Speech is “Securing the transition: From trade preferences to global competition”.
target: Tit diskur Bidze “Secure a transition from trade preferences to global competition”.

input: That is to say, how to ensure a transition from an economy based on preferential markets, especially for sugar and textiles, to an economy based on global competition.
target: vedir kimanyer pu asir enn tranzisyon depi enn lekonomi baze lor bann marse preferansyel, sirtu pu disik ek textil, a enn lekonomi baze lor konpetisyon global.

input: That is to say, the sugar and textile industries can no longer rely on protected markets.
target: Setadir lindistri kuma disik ek textil nepli ena enn proteksyon.

input: Now they will have to compete on the global market and Mauritius will have to be “competitive”.
target: Aster zot pe vinn lor marse global e Moris pu bizen “konpetitif”.

input: The Budget Title gives away a great deal on the nature on the budgetary measures.
target: Sa tit Bidze li explik buku lor filozofi ki ena dan Bidze.

input: The title of the Budget Speech refers to two things: “trade preferences” and “global competition”.
target: Tit Bidze vinn koz “marse preferansyel” ek “konpetisyon global”.

input: But “preferential trade” is an abstract concept.
target: Me marse preferansyel, li pa enn zafer abstre.

input: Whereas preferential markets for the Textiles and Sugar, refers directly to two big very, very tangible sectors of production.
target: Marse preferansyel pu disik ek textil, li 2 gro sekter prodiksyon.

input: It means loads of different real textile factories; it means 80% of our agricultural land, and 11 sugar mills.
target: Li enn ta lizinn textil, li 80% nu later agrikol, li 11 mulen disik.

input: So you can’t just hide behind the abstract words like “trade preferences”.
target: Alor pa vinn apel sa zis “Trade preference”.

input: These are the two biggest sectors of the economy. The textile industry employs 40,000 - 50,000 people, even though the numbers have decreased drastically.
target: Li 2 pli gro sekter, 2 gro sekter ki anplway dan Textil 40,000 - 50,000 dimunn malgre ki li finn bese, li ankor anplway 40-50,000 dimunn.

input: In the Sugar Industry there are still a lot of jobs, though there too jobs have decreased.
target: Dan Lindistri Sikriyer ena ankor ase buku lanplwa, laba usi lanplwa inn bese buku.

input: So when we talk of “Trade Preferences”, we are talking of two big sectors of production, which employ more than 100,000 people, directly and indirectly.
target: Alor kan u vinn koz “Trade Preferences”, u pe koz 2 gro sekter prodiktif ki anplway plis ki 100,000 dimunn, direk ek indirek.

input: Then when Government says that we are making the transition between this, “trade preferences” (which we now see means two huge sectors) and “global competition”, when they talk of “global competition”, they are not talking about production at all.
target: Lerla u dir u pu fer enn tranzisyon ant sa ek “konpetisyon global”. Kan u pe koz “konpetisyon global”, u pa pe koz prodiksyon ditu.

input: They are not saying what kind of factories they are talking about.
target: U pa pe koz ki lizinn pu ena?

input: They don’t say what will be cultivated.

target: U pa pe koz sa ditu.

input: They just talk of producing any old thing, they don’t say what, so long as it’s done cheaply.
target: U pe vinn dir kimanyer pu prodir nerport ki ete, me bonmarse.

input: So the title of the budget itself gives away the political fraud that the budget is: two specific huge sectors of production that employ thousands and thousands of people are collapsing, and instead we are heading for another economic reality where there is no hint as to what will, in fact, be produced.
target: Alor tit lamem pe gete kimanyer pu asir tranzisyon depi enn sityasyon kot 2 gro sekter spesifik ki anplway buku dimunn a enn lot sistem ekonomik kot li pa pe dir u ki sekter pu ena.

input: They don’t even bother to tell us whether there will be jobs created in this new “global competition” economy.
target: E li pa dir u si li pu anplway dimunn.

input: So the title exposes very clearly what’s in Sithanen’s head, and what’s in the mind of the Social Alliance regime.
target: Alor sa li inpe vinn expoz seki ena dan latet Sithanen e dan latet sa rezim Lalyans Sosyal.

input: But the end of the preferential market is something that has been predictable for ages, and especially since the creation of the World Trade Organisation in 1994-1995.
target: Me lafin sa bann marse preferansyel se enn zafer ki pe vini-mem sirtu depi World Trade Organisation (WTO) inn met dibut an 1994-1995.

input: It was evident where everything was heading.
target: Li ti evidan seki pe arive aster-la ti pu arive.

input: May be the time schedule was difficult to foresee, but it was certain that it was coming.
target: So tayming kitfwa dimunn pa ti kapav predir exakteman, me li ti evidan ki li pu arive.

input: What is being experienced today both in the textile and the sugar industry can be seen as an outcome of the logic inherent in capitalist globalisation.
target: E seki pe arive zordi, e dan textil, e dan lindistri sikriyer, li osi dan enn lozik, li dan sa lozik globalizasyon kapitalist.

input: It follows like day follows night.
target: Sa li vinn kuma lanwit ek lizur.

input: And when we analyse the logic inherent in capitalist globalisation in regard to what is happening now, we can see that this economic crisis is part of the very logic of the system.
target: E kan u get lozik globalizasyon kapitalist, u truve seki pe arive, anfet sa kriz ekonomik-la li dan sa lozik-la pir ek simp.

input: This budget for the first time reveals the consequences of capitalist globalisation to the people of Mauritius.
target: Seki sa Bidze pe vinn fer, li pe vinn expoz pu premye fwa, pu  lamas dimunn dan Moris.

input: In other parts of the world, the consequences have already been felt for the past three, four, five, six years.
target: Dan lezot pei, bann lefe inn fini kumans resanti ena trwa, kat, sink, sis an desela.

input: In such places as India, Latin America and Africa, they have started to witness its direct effects.
target: Kuma dan Lend, Lamerik Disid, Lafrik. Inn kumans resanti bann lefe direk.

input: When I say “direct effects”, I mean the effects on the daily lives of people.
target: Kan mo dir bann lefe direk, mo ule dir bann lefe direk lor lavi tulezur dimunn.

input: In many countries these effects have already been felt.
target: Dan buku pei sa bann lefe inn fini kumans paret.

input: This is why, in India for example, where there is a huge peasantry, millions of small planters (to give an idea of the scale, one small farmers’ association has 10,000,000 members), once GMO seeds under the control of multinational corporations were introduced, many planters were completely ruined, and as we have learnt, thousands of farmers have been reduced to selling one of their kidneys just so that they can buy seeds to plant for their next harvest.
target: Samem dan Lend u pe gayn bann asosyasyon peizan, ti-agrikilter, ti-elver, avek 10 milyon mam. Dan Lend, nu ti pe kumans gayn bann sityasyon kot agrikilter, kan finn rant dan sa langrenaz bann miltinasyonal otur bann OGM (Organism Zenetikman Modifye), zot pe bizen vann enn leren pu zot aste lagren pu prosenn rekolt.

input: This is due to the fact that the WTO is mainly responsible for the bankrupting of small planters, not only in India but also in Latin America. In France, small planters, in their association uniting peasants, together with José Bové, have for years already been reacting to the consequences of globalisation as they have felt them.
target: Sa li parski bann regleman WTO pe rwinn bann ti-agrikilter, pa zis dan Lend, me dan Lamerik Disid, mem dan Lafrans bann ti-agrikilter otur lasosyasyon paysanne, otur José Bové, fini kumans reazir a bann lefe globalizasyon.

input: But in Mauritius, to some extent, the preferential market for sugar and textiles is precisely what has protected the masses of the people. However, the globalisation logic means that for one, two or three years there can be some protection, but not after that.
target: Me dan Moris, dan enn serten mezir lamas dimunn inn inpe proteze par zisteman sa bann marse preferansyel, zot proteze pu enn an, de an, trwa an, me lozik-la pe dir ki proteksyon pu ale.

input: Now, in fact, this budget comes and reveals clearly to everyone the consequences for the people when there will no longer be any protection.
target: Me anfet, asterla Bidze pe vinn montre ki lefe sa pu ena lor lamas dimunn kan sa proteksyon-la ale.

input: This is what the budget is in fact doing.
target: Se sa ki Bidze pe vinn fer.

input: As I have said, perhaps for the first time the people will really be hit by globalisation when, for example, they go to buy bread in the morning, when they send their children off to school each week-day, when they are looking for a job for their 16-17 years old children. Wherever we turn, we will be forced to understand what a crisis is.
target: Kuma mo ti dir, kitfwa pu premye fwa lamas dimunn pu resanti, granmatin kan li al aste so dipin, kan li avoy so zanfan lekol, kan li pe rod enn travay pu so zanfan ki’nn gayn 16 an, 17 an.

input: It will be felt in the marrow of our bones what this capitalist globalisation logic is.
target: Sak instan, li pu kone ki ete kriz, li pu santi li dan so laser ki ete sa lozik globalizasyon kapitalist.

input: But in other parts of the world there have been mass movements, and the big international conferences in Mexico, in Mumbai in India, in Porto Alegre in Brazil, attended by 80,000 to 100,000 people, from all sorts of different organisations, have for years now been discussing the effects of capitalist globalisation.
target: Bann muvman dan gran konferans dan Mexik, dan Mumbai dan Lend, dan Porto Alegre dan Brezil, bann gran-gran konferans kot ena 80,000 a 100,000 dimunn prezan, depi diferan lorganizasyon, tusala finn diskite depi ase lontan. Dayer, onivo Lalit isi, ti ena enn delegasyon 4 dimunn ti prezan dan World Social Forum dan Mumbai kot ti ena apepre 100,000 dimunn prezan.

input: It was precisely these issues that were discussed two to three years ago, in Mumbai.
target: Se zisteman tusala ki ti pe diskite de-trwa an desela, dan Mumbai.

input: It is this movement, which is known as the alter-globalisation movement, that has for a number of years now been explaining exactly what is happening to the people in Mauritius today.
target: Sa muvman ki apel muvman altermondyalist, depi plizyer lane finn explik exakteman seki zordi pe ariv lamas dimunn dan Moris.

input: How Sithanen will deal with disappearing preferential markets.
target: Kimanyer Bidze Sithanen pe propoze pu fer fas a disparisyon marse preferansyel.

input: In order to cope with the disappearing preferential markets, what does the Sithanen Budget propose? How does he intend to re-launch the economy? Even in his own terms, how does he intend to attract investments? How does he intend to improve growth rates? And, more importantly, how does he intend to create jobs?
target: Pu fer fas a disparisyon marse preferansyel, anu gete ki Bidze Sithanen pe propoze pu relans lekonomi, pu atir investisman, pu retablir to krwasans, pu kree lanplwa.

input: It’s obvious that the crisis of the sugar and textile industries presents itself, in the main, as a crisis of unemployment.
target: Li kler ki kriz dan lindistri sikriyer ek dan textil, li prinsipalman enn kriz lanplwa.

input: These are two big work sectors.
Both industries have already had drastic decreases in their employment over the past five years or even more.
target: Dan lindistri sikriyer ek textil, fini kumans ena rediksyon lanplwa ase dramatik depi dernye sink an, kitfwa inpe plis mem.

input: But, now catastrophic decreases may suddenly be upon us.
target: Me asterla li kapav vinn katastrofik enn ku.

input: These are two huge sectors where no new employment will be created, and where on the contrary there will be a reduction in employment.
target: Me sirtu ki zot 2 pli gro sekter ekonomik kot pa pu ena kreasyon lanplwa. Non, pu ena rediksyon lanplwa.

input: Just to show how this is “the chronicle of a pre-announced crisis”, you will all remember how Ministers like Sushil Kushiram, Berenger, Pravind Jugnauth, ex-Finance Ministers of the previous MSM-MMM regime, were already talking first about “jobless growth” and then afterwards saying maybe they had been wrong and that it was more accurate to refer to “job-loss growth”.
target: Zis pu montre kimanyer sa lozik la, li enn lozik ki pe vini depi lontan, kitfwa zot pu rapel ansyen guvernman,  Minis kuma Sushil Kushiram, kuma Bérenger, kuma Pravind Jugnauth, sa bann Minis Finans ansyen rezim MSM-MMM, ti fini kumans koz sa langaz la, dan enn premye tan kan zot ti pe koz lanplwa.

input: So this has been a leitmotif of all the different political parties in power.
target: Zot ti fini kumans koz enn zafer ki zot ti apel “jobless growth”. Setadir krwasans ekonomik san kreasyon lanplwa. Apre inpe letan, zot dir ‘kapav nu ti ena tor’, kapav et seki pu ena se “job-loss growth” setadir krwasans ekonomik avek rediksyon lanplwa. Alor nu truv sa lozik la pe vini depi enn bon but letan. E li finn travers diferan rezim-la.

input: The logic marches on and does not flinch, no matter who wins the election in Rose-Belle and Plaine Magnien! [Laughter]
target: Lozik-la li pa gete kisannla finn gayn eleksyon dan Rose Belle! [Dimunn riye.)

input: Let’s see what Sithanen is proposing by way of attracting investment, re-establishing growth rates and creating jobs.
target: Nu get enn ku ki Sithanen pe propoze pu fer fas, ki li pe propoze pu atir investisman, pu retablir to krwasans ek pu kree lanplwa.

input: The main thrust of the Budget, from the point of view of working people and poor people, is that Sithanen proposes to decrease real wages, and worsen work conditions.
target: Gro but dan Bidze, depwindevi klas travayer ek dimunn mizer, se li pe propoz pu diminye saler reel, e diminye kondisyon travay.

input: When you read the Budget Speech, this is, from our standpoint, the central issue. Sithanen wants to attract investment, increase the growth rate and create employment by means, first and foremost, of reducing the cost of production, and he intends doing this by reducing real wages.
target: Kan u lir sa diskur Bidze-la, de nu pwindevi, se sa so pwen santral. Li pe viz pu atir investisman, li pe viz pu asir to krwasans e kree lanplwa atraver premyerman redwir kud prodiksyon, redwir saler reel.

input: I’ll come back to how he intends doing this, later.
target: Mo pu revinn lor la an plis detay lor kimanyer li pe fer sa.

input: When you close down the Development Works Corporation (DWC) which was set up to create jobs, and you are encouraging DWC workers to set up private companies so that they can then buy the DWC’s rotten old equipment so that they can run private businesses, this is a form of privatization of the construction sector.
target: Kan u pe ferm Development Works Corporation (DWC) e u pe ankuraz travayer developman met dibut enn konpayni prive e zot mem kapav aste lekipman puri depi DWC e rul li kuma enn konpayni prive, li enn form privatizasyon dan sekter konstriksyon.

input: There is also the privatization of the National Transport Authority (NTA) and the car “fitness certification” soon to be done by private firms.
target: Pe ena privatizasyon National Transport Authority (NTA), setadir fitnes pu fer par bann konpayni prive.

input: The garage for repairing the Government fleet is being closed down. Government work is being out-sourced, privatized, and given to the private sector.
target: Ena plizyer lezot ka kot ena privatizasyon, kuma garaz lapolis ki ti pe antretenir tu bann veikil guvernman. Sa usi pe ferme. Setadir pu awtsors, pu privatize, pu al dan sekter prive.

input: At first I was very worried about closing the SMF Garage because I wondered what we could then do with people like Assistant Superintendent Raddhoa! [Laughter] Where could he then be transferred to, to keep him out of contact with the public so as to curb him and his brutal team of investigators?
target: Mo finn pran enn traka, si ferm garaz SMF, ki pu fer ek dimunn kuma Raddhoa, tusala! Me sa, li inpe enn saydifek. [Lasal riye]

input: However, privatization in the budget also involves, at the same time, opening up the economy to international capital by means of taking all sorts of measures to make Mauritius look more attractive, more inviting, more seductive, to foreign investors.
target: Me privatizasyon ek an mem tan enn luvertir a kapital internasyonal, savedir pe pran enn trale mezir pu rann Moris plis akeyan, plis atiran, pu bann investiser internasyonal.

input: Not just investors, but also speculators, mafias, and fly-by-night businesses out to make a quick buck, then move on to where it is once again more profitable elsewhere.
target: Li pa zis spekilater, me ikonpri ena lamafya, tu kalite konpayni flay-bay-nayt, investiser ki pu vini pu fer seki Angle apel enn “quick buck”. Lerla zot ris zot kales byin vit, zot ale, kan zot finn fini fer zot profi.

input: And this privatization involves dismantling the provisions of the Welfare State.
target: Alor sa privatizasyon-la li inklir dematelman Welfare State.

input: That, too, is a form of privatization. Here, as anywhere else in the world, children have to go to school, people have to look after themselves when they are ill, have to organize how to live in their old age.
target: Sa, osi, li enn form privatizasyon parski kuma u kone dan Moris e dan nerport ki pei, dimunn ena pu al lekol, dimunn ena pu sweyn limem kan li malad.

input: The Welfare State starting point is that the State offers free education, free health care, and universal pensions for everyone.
target: Welfare State so pwen de baz se Leta furni swen medikal, Leta furni ledikasyon gratis, sa se fondman Welfare State.

input: But when you start “targeting”, making people pay, this too is a form of privatization, in that people will have to move into private institutions because the State is no longer providing the service as a right.
target: Kan u pe vinn koz targetinng, kan u pe vinn koz pu fer dimunn pey pu serten servis, li enn form privatizasyon dan lesans ki u pe dir dimunn pu ledikasyon li pu bizen al dan enn institisyon prive parksi Leta nepli pu provayd.

input: For health, for university education and for pensions, the State is intending to phase out the services as a right.
target: Pu swen medikal, li pu bizen al dan enn institisyon prive parski Leta nepli pu provayd gratis.

input: Now, this kind of privatization has as one of its additional aims, that it attracts foreign investors.
target: Alor li enn form privatizasyon. E sa privatizasyon-la li usi ena kom bi pu atir investisman internasyonal.

input: In education, for example, especially since the WTO and its commerce in services “GATS” (General Agreement on Trade in Services), the State has committed itself to opening up tertiary education to international investments.
target: U get kote ledikasyon, sa depi inpe letan nu pe predir ki su presyon WTO, su so aranzman pu komers an “servis”, bann “GATS” (General Agreement on Trade in Services), Leta pe uver pei a investisman sirtu dan sekter tersyer, onivo liniversite.

input: So now you have all sorts of universities from Australia and South Africa opening up here.
target: Aster u pe gayn enn kantite liniversite Ostralyin, Sid Afriken, depi inpe partu ki pu vinn uver liniversite isi.
Setadir ledikasyon tersyer pe privatize par extansyon.

input: Secondary and primary school may follow.
target: Lekol segonder parey, lekol primer parey, deplizapli u pe gayn investiser ki pe finn investi dan bann institisyon edikatif prive.

input: Already there are more and more investments in these kinds of private institutions, which means, in fact, privatizing services that were a right under the Welfare State.
target: Anfet pe privatiz seki ti lontan bann servis su Welfare State.

input: The budget is also an example of accountancy tricks.
target: Bidze ena enn gro trik kontab.

input: We know Sithanen used to work as an accountant for the Rogers Company that was not so long ago involved in the big scandal with Air Mauritius, and we know that that type of company knows about accountancy tricks.
target: Sithanen ti enn kontab kot Rogers, alor li konn bann trik kontab.

input: This budget certainly contains one big bit of “creative accounting”, as they call it these days.
target: Nu, nu kwar ena enn gro trik kontab dan sa Bidze-la.

input: Sithanen makes proposals for measures that will directly lead to land speculation.
target: Sithanen inn propoz bann mezir ki pu ankuraz spekilasyon lor later.

input: There are a number of measures which seem fair enough, like the decrease in Registration Duty when you buy a piece of land, but in Mauritius, there aren’t many poor people buying and selling land.
target: Ena enn serten nomb mezir ki paret kuma bann bon mezir, kuma rediksyon lanrezistreman kan u aste teren, me dan Moris, pena buku dimunn mizer ki ena posibilite aste teren.

input: So the measure turns out to facilitate real estate speculation and land transactions.
target: Alor, nu dir li tu sinpleman enn mezir ki fasilit tranzaksyon fonsye, tranzaksyon later.

input: Another measure encourages Integrated Resorts Scheme (IRS) projects and extends the scope of the previous IRS.
target: Lerla enn lot mezir se pu ankuraz Integrated Resort Schemes (IRS) e li pe etann so skop.

input: In the same way that the former Government invented this concept of IRS as rich ghettos, special touristy places where very rich people will buy bungalows for Rs 15 millions with a golf course, marinas with boats on beaches for their personal use.
target: IRS kuma ansyen guvernman finn invant li ti ondire bann geto, bann anklav turistik kot turis byen ris pu vinn aste kanpman Rs15 milyon. Zot pu ena golfkors, zot pu ena marina, bato, zot laplaz tusala.

input: This was the old IRS concept on the MMM-MSM model.
target: Sa ti ansyen konsep IRS stil MMM-MSM.

input: This new government is now extending the scope of the IRS.
target: Sa nuvo guvernman-la pe vinn etann skop IRS.

input: There will now be IRS projects for different income groups and they will offer different forms of residences.
target: Aster pu ena bann IRS ki pu ofer tu kalite diferan form rezidans.

input: This will also promote real estate speculation, land transactions and a lot of shady deals.
target: Sa usi pe amenn enn ankurazman a sa spekilasyon fonsye, tranzaksyon later e buku tranzaksyon lus.

input: Perhaps many of you will have read in the newspapers yesterday and even today that the Médine Sugar Estate Company, immediately after the presentation of the budget came up with a spectacular plan for the whole of the West of Mauritius. It will build new housing estates, roads, and residential projects. Even a golf course. A private sugar company will come and re-design one-quarter of the landscape of Mauritius.
target: Kitfwa bann kamarad isi inn lir dan lagazet yer ek zordi, tablisman konpayni sikriyer Medine, tutswit apre Bidze inn vini ek enn plan grandyoz. Li pu ranz bann nuvo site dan Lwes pei. Li pu ranz nuvo sime. Li ena bann proze rezidansyel. Li pu ena golfkors. Enn kanpayni sikriyer prive pu vinn re-amenaz enn-kar pei Moris.

input: It is not a coincidence that the Médine Sugar Estate Company one week after the budget speech comes up with this project.
target: Li pa enn kwinsidans ki konpayni sikriyer Medine, enn semenn apre Bidze vini avek sa proze-la.

input: This project, if you look at it closely, will transform Médine from being a sugar company (it’ll keep it’s cane, of course) into a real estate Company. Now it will make its profits through land transactions and through land conversion.
target: Me sa li enn proze, kan u examinn li, li enn proze ki pe fer Medine sorti depi enn konpayni sikriyer, li pu gard so kann wi, me aster li pe vinn enn konpayni fonsye. Aster li pu fer so bann profi atraver tranzaksyon later, atraver konverti later.

input: We should not lose sight of the fact that through the IRS projects, the Sugar Industry is being given the chance to convert its agricultural land into residential property.
target: Fode pa nu bliye ki atraver proze IRS, tablisman gayn sa privilez kot zot kapav konverti later agrikol fer li vinn later rezidansyel.

input: When agricultural land is converted to residential property, its value goes up by 10-15 times.
target: Kan u fer later agrikol vinn rezidansyel, u miltipliye so valer par 10 a 15 fwa.

input: The Government just signs a bit of paper, and the value of the land soars.
target: Guvernman nek ena pu siyn enn but papye.

input: It is this kind of financial speculation, which Sithanen is encouraging through a series of budgetary measures.
target: Se sa kalite spekilasyon fonsyer ki vremem Sithanen pe ankuraze atraver enn seri bann mezir.

input: Why is it that I call this accountancy tricks?
target: Kifer mo ti apel sa enn trik kontab?

input: What Sithanen is doing, when agricultural land value is going to be multiplied by 10 or 15 times because it is residential land, when Médine will be parcelling off more land, preparing the “sites”, because it will prepare this and that in the process, soon there will be enormous “value added” to its business.
target: Seki Sithanen pe fer, kan later agrikol so pri pe vinn enn pri ki miltipliye par 10 ubyen 15 kuma later rezidansyel, kan Medine lerla morsele ankor later, li ranz bann site, li ranz sesi, li ranz sela, tutswit ena seki u apel enn valer azute.

input: This “value added” only from an accountant’s point of view because nothing new has been produced.
target: Vedir valer azute kontab, parski u pa pe prodir nanye.

input: It is the same piece of land.
Only its nature has been modified and its value has risen by 10 to 15 times.
target: Nek u finn sanz so natir e so valer miltipliye par 10 u 15 fwa.

input: So in 4 to 5 years’ time Sithanen will come to say, “There you are!” The brave measures I took have brought us an economic growth of 4.5%, 5%, 6%.”
target: Alor lerla, dan 5 an, dan 4 an Sithanen pu vinn dir u “Alalila bolom, bann mezir ki mo finn pran, finn amenn krwasans ekonomik 4.5%, 5%, 6%”.

input: But it is a form of “economic growth” that is an accountancy trick because it is based on speculation.
target: Me li enn krwasans ekonomik kontab, parski li baze lor spekilasyon.

input: It is based on artificial land transaction values.
target: Li baze lor bann valer artifisyel tranzaksyon later.

input: So with these measures, that is the IRS, more assistance on the part of the government is being provided to new IRS projects, to make these wild plans of Médine’s come true, and thus very quickly Sithanen is going to increase “economic growth”, but in a totally artificial way.
target: Alor ek sa bann mezir-la, savedir IRS, fasilite pu nuvo kalite IRS, proze grandyoz kuma Medine ena, tutswit Sithanen pu ogmant so to krwasans, me dan enn fason byen byen artfisyel.

input: This is why I refer to this budget as containing a huge accountancy trick!
target: Se pu sa rezon-la ki mo apel sa enn trik kontab.

input: So those are the three main budgetary measures.
Then there are a number of other measures that aim to encourage SME’s (Small and Medium Enterprises).
target: Lerla ena buku mezir pu ankuraz PME (Petites ek Moyennes Entreprises).

input: What a Minister of Finance we’ve got!
target: Ala nu ena enn Minis de Finans.

input: In one and the same speech, he tells us two different things. When looking at the sugar industry he says that the 11 existing sugar mills in the country that each produces 50,000 tons of sugar can’t survive because they aren’t big enough. He says in order to survive they have to produce at least 100,000 tons in just four huge, huge production units.
target: Dan so mem diskur kan li pe get problem lindistri sikriyer, kan li pe dir u nu bizen konpetitif global, dan lindistri sikriyer li dir nu ena 11 mulen dan pei, sakenn pe prodwir an mwayenn 50,000 tonn disik, ena inpe plis, ena inpe mwens, an mwayenn sakenn pe prodir 50,000 tonn disik; dan so mem diskur Bidze kan li dir li enn grav problem ki prodir “zis” 50,000 tonn disik, li pa vyab; Kan li pe dir dan enn sityasyon de konpetisyon global, enn mulen disik ki pa prodir plis ki 100,000 tonn disik sak lane, li pa vyab; alor dan lindistri sikriyer pe vinn met artizan deor, pe vinn santralize parski pu vinn konpetitif bizen bann gro, gro inite prodiksyon.

input: But, then he also says that what will save Mauritius is 1,000, 2,000 or 3,000 tiny little small enterprises.
target: An mem tan, dan sa mem diskur Bidze la, Sithanen pe vinn dir seki pu sov Moris, se 1,000, 2,000, 3,000 tipti lantrepriz.

input: To compound his error, he does not even specify what they will produce.
target: Anplis, li pa spesifye. Li pa dir ti lantrepriz pu fer ki ete?

input: You can’t just repeat SME, SME, SME. SME has become like a kind of mantra that you chant in the hope of it creating employment. In this country SME’s have created jobs, in that country SME’s have created jobs.
target: PME, an Angle SMI, inn vinn kuma enn manntra zot nek ena pu dir PME, PME, dan tel pei PME inn prodir lanplwa, dan tel lot pei PME inn prodir lanplwa, isi usi PME pu prodir lanplwa.
Be PME ki ete sa? Ki li pu prodir?

input: Sithanen is no fool. He knows for a start that the SME’s don’t create jobs.
target: Sithanen li pa kuyon, li byen kone ki premyerman laplipar bann PME pa prodir lanplwa.

input: If you take all the SME’s started and look them up 5 years later, three-quarters will have disappeared altogether, having closed down because they didn’t work.
target: Si u pran tu bann PME ki’nn kumanse, u reget zot dan 5 an, otur 75% inn disparet parski li pa finn marse.

input: As it is, that is a waste of resources, just encouraging people to take loans, to go into debt when you know most of them will go bankrupt before five years is over.
target: Deza li enn gaspiyaz resurs extraordiner kot pe nek ankuraz dimunn pran lonn, met so later angaz, met so bizu angaz, pran lonn pu kumans enn ti-biznes e 75% ladan deklar bankrut avan 5 an.

input: The Budget doesn’t give any idea as to what the projected SME’s will make?
target: Bidze-la pa vinn dir u sa bann PME-la ki zot pu fer?

input: For what market are they supposed to produce?
target: Pu ki marse zot pu prodir?

input: Sithanen replies to none of these questions.
target: Tusala Sithanen pa vinn dir u ditu.

input: A tobacconist shop is also an SME.
target: Enn ti tabazi usi, li enn espes PME.

input: Imagine if everyone in Mauritius opens up their own tobacconist?
target: Eski u pe imazinn dan Moris, sak dimunn pu bizen uver so prop tabazi?

input: Is that the economic development that will save Mauritius from ruin?
target: Eski se sa lekonomi ki nu pe antisipe pu tir Moris kot li ete?

input: And they are putting lots of emphasis on these SME’s in his budget.
target: E zot pe met buku lanfaz anfet lor PME.

input: Any Government, when it comes to preparing its Budget, gets put under all sorts of different pressures.
target: Tu Guvernnman, nerport ki guvernman burzwa, kan li ena pu fer enn Bidze, li sibir diferan kalite presyon.

input: It is important to understand these.
target: Li inportan pu konpran kot sa presyon la sorti.

input: IMF, World Bank and WTO pressure.
target: Presyon depi FMI, Labank Mondyal e WTO

input: Institutions like the IMF, World Bank and the World Trade Organization represent one kind of pressure.
target: Li sibir presyon depi institisyon kuma FMI, kuma Labank Mondyal, WTO.

input: And this pressure will be even stronger than usual because, according to the Financial Secretary, the interim one anyway, Ally Mansoor, negotiations have already begun for a big new World Bank Loan.
target: E la pu ena plis presyon ankor parski nu fini kumans tande depi enn Sekreter Finansye, enpe par interim pa kone si li lor kontra ubyin li pe ranplase, apel Ally Mansoor, inn fini kumans negosye enn gro lonn avek Labank Mondyal.

input: When you are negotiating a World Bank loan, you are not just under pressure, but your two thumbs in a veritable vice, being squeezed.
target: Kan u negosye lonn avek Labank Mondyal, pa zis presyon ki u sibir, me u de “zorey” pu dan leto.

input: So, that is one kind of pressure.
Local pressure from the bosses side.
The Government is under pressure from the local bourgeoisie and from international financial advisors.
target: Guvernman sibir presyon osi depi patrona lokal ek bann finansye internasyonal.

input: Perhaps people present have read the long interviews of a person called Percy Mistry (he is very much a “mystery”)?
target: Kapav-et bann kamarad finn lir enn seri bann long-long intervyu par enn bug apel Percy Mistry (li inpe enn mister, “very mystery”)?

input: He is a banker, an investment banker, in a group based in Oxford in the UK.
target: Li enn bankye, enn bankye investiser dan enn grup bankye ki baze dan Oxford dan Langleter.

input: For a long time, he has been given these long interviews, especially in Mauritius Times, and he clearly has a vision, a political project, an economic projection of what he would like Mauritius to become.
target: Depi enn bon but letan, li pe ekrir bann long-long intervyu dan Mauritius Times, e li klerman ena enn proze, enn proze politik, enn proze ekonomik pu Moris.

input: And then when we hear the budget being discussed, we keep hearing the name Percy Mistry coming up.
target: E kan u ekut deba lor Bidze, suvan tann nom Percy Mistry fer sirfas.

input: Sithanen himself says, “Go and see what Percy Mistry had to say on this or on that.”
target: U pu tann kikenn kuma Sithanen dir “al gete ki Percy Mistry inn dir”.

input: As though the man is an oracle.
target: Ondire seki Percy Mistry dir, li enn levanzil.

input: He may well be an oracle for finance capital, but we certainly don’t have to take his advice.
target: Li kapav enn levanzil pu kapital finansye, me nu pa forse ekut seki Percy Mistry dir.

input: Then there are other ideologues like the firm De Chazal Du Mee, or consultancies like Kemp Chatteris, who are always giving their opinions on everything, including on things like the budget.
target: Lerla ena ideolog, bann ideolog dan firm kuma De Chazal Du Mée, bann firm konseltennsi, Kemp Chateris, u ena sa bann ideolog, konsiltan ki tultan pe donn zot lopinyon lor nerport ki zafer sirtu lor enn zafer kuma Bidze.

input: There are ideologues in the press.
target: Ena usi ideolog dan lapres, dan lagazet.

input: In some newspapers we now have a new kind of “press attachés” who don’t work for government Ministers but for a section of the economy, that is to say for a section of the private sector.
target: Ena enn serten nomb zurnalist zordi ki zot pa zis zurnalis, zot plis enn espes press atache pa pu Minis guvernnman me pu bann sekter ekonomik, pu sekter prive.

input: There is one journalist, for instance, that speaks as if she is the MSPA, the sugar oligarchs. Her opinion is that of the sugar bosses.
target: U pu gayn enn zurnalis ki li so travay se pu defann pwendevi MSPA, tablisman.

input: Another defends the interests of the free zone.
target: Enn lot zurnalist, li so travay se pu defann pwindevi gro patron zonn frans.

input: When you read the newspapers, you learn to recognize them.
target: Kan u lir lagazet, u truv sa enn sel ku.

input: So anyway, it is clear that the Government is under pressure from different international institutions, local forces or various kinds, and bourgeois ideologues.
target: Alor Guvernman li su presyon sa bann diferan institisyon internasyonal, institisyon lokal e ideolog patrona.

input: There is, however, a counter pressure from the trade union movement and from consumer associations.
target: Ena enn kont-presyon depi muvman sindikal, e depi lasosyasyon konsomater.

input: But it has for a long time now been very weak.
target: Me li enn kont-presyon ki depi enn bon but letan enn kont-presyon ase feb.

input: It is weak for various reasons. The present Government has had clear mandates in three successive elections, general elections, the municipals and village elections.
target: Li feb pu buku diferan rezon, li feb parski sa guvernman ki nu ena zordi-la, li finn gayn enn mazorite telman kler dan 3 eleksyon ki finn fek fer, mwens ki enn an desela. Eleksyon Zeneral. Eleksyon Minisipal. Eleksyon Vilaz.

input: This makes the regime feel it doesn’t need to concede to this pressure, or any pressure from the masses of the people.
target: Alor ena enn rezim ki santi li pa oblize sede a presyon lamas dimunn.

input: It would, however, not hesitate to “concede” to pressures from its own bank-rollers, the bosses.
target: Li pu sede ase fasilman a so bayerdefon, a patron.

input: Its clear mandate was a mandate to “democratize the economy” and to “put people first”.
target: E so manda-la sete pu demokratiz lekonomi, so manda sete “put people first”.

input: This is the type of slogan that, in fact, gave the government its clear electoral victories.
target: Se sa ki finn donn li sa mazorite-la.

input: But that is not what it is putting into practice in the Budget.
target: Se sertennmann pa seki li pe fer dan Bidze ki’nn donn li sa mazorite-la.

input: But the counter-pressure of the unions is also rather weak because unions find it notoriously difficult to think or act outside of the bosses’ logic.
target: Me kont-presyon depi muvman sindikal li osi feb, dan enn sertenn mezir, parski dan muvman sindikal li ase difisil pu sindika dan diferan sekter sorti andeor enn lozik. Pu enn sindika sorti premyerman andeor lozik so prop sekter, so sekter travay e dezyemman pu sorti andeor lozik prodiksyon kapitalist, parski bann sindika zot opere a-linteryer sistem kapitalist.

input: In general, a union aims to get a better treatment for workers, but within the existing system. Unions have difficulty challenging the system itself.
target: E anzeneral seki zot vize se pu gayn enn meyer tretman pu travayer me alinteryer sistem-la. Sindika gayn buku difikilte pu chalenj sistem-la.

input: The second part of my paper aims to look at the budget while asking the question “What choice is there?”
target: Dernye parti mo papye se pu get Bidze e poz kestyon “Ki swa ena?”

input: What kind of transition could there have been, given the world situation?
target: Ki kalite tranzisyon ti kapav ena par rapor a seki pe arive onivo mondyal?

input: What kind of transition could there have been, in relationship to the crisis, in relation, particularly, to employment?
target: Par rapor a sa kriz, ek par rapor a lanplwa sirtu?

input: In relationship to the crisis in the sugar industry and textiles?
target: Par rapor a kriz dan lindistri sikriyer ek textil?

input: The choice was either to re-establish “growth” and “create employment” through the re-establishment of the rate of profit.
target: Swa ki ti ena se premyerman retablir krwasans e kree lanplwa par retablir to profi.

input: There is a crisis looming. Unemployment is increasing drastically. There are more and more lay-offs, and more and more people seeking work.
target: Ena kriz ekonomik pe vini, ena kriz lanplwa, ena lisansiman buku, ena dimunn pe rod travay.

input: So, you try to re-launch the economy, as the budget does, by making existing companies make more profits.
target: Pu fer fas a sa, u sey truve kimanyer pu relans lekonomi. Enn de bann fason pu fer li, e Bidze sey fer li, se pu retablir krwasans ekonomik ek kree lanplwa, me atraver retablir to profi, setadir par fer bann konpayni, bann biznes vinn plis profitab.

input: This is supposed to increase growth.
On the other hand, there is an alternative. A budget can put forward the basis for a new productive apparatus.
target: Dezyem swa, se atraver enn Bidze, u kapav pronons u-mem anfaver etablir baz pu enn re-oryantasyon dan laparey prodiktif.

input: The crisis is in the productive apparatus of textiles and sugar.
target: Sa li inportan, parski kriz dan Moris zordi se kriz dan laparey prodiktif textil ek disik.

input: And this means that the Budget must face up to this, and suggest alternative sectors, alternative ways of creating employment, of keeping jobs secure, and of how to create jobs fast.
target: Ek dan enn Bidze kumsa si u pe sey rod fer fas a sa kriz-la, u oblize vinn propoz bann alternativ kot pu ena lanplwa. Bann sekter alternativ, prodiksyon alternativ kot ena lanplwa, kot ena sekirite danplwa, kot ena buku lanplwa byen vit.

input: The budget had an obligation to do this.
target: Li ena enn obligasyon pu fer sa.

input: Our campaign, unlike Sithanen’s budget, takes up this second, real alternative.
target: E nu kanpayn ki nu pe amene evidaman li baze lor dezyem swa e seki Sithanen ek sa guvernman la finn swazir, finn swazir premye swa.

input: Now let us examine the option Sithanen has taken.
target: Asterla, nu pu get sirtu sa opsyon ki Sithanen finn swazir.

input: What are the concrete measures he proposes? He proposes to facilitate business, in particular to do this through deregulation.
target: So bann mezir konkret ki li pe propoze, se pu fasilit biznes, me par dereglemantasyon.

input: This means cutting out any controls and rules that slow down business.
target: Savedir pu abandonn tu reglemantasyon ki ena lor biznes pu akseler prosedir.

input: The Government has brought about deregulation, even from the point of view of the environment.
target: Guvernman finn amenn enn dereglemantasyon, mem dipwendevi lanvironnman.

input: Long ago, before setting up a business, you had to get an Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) to ensure that the environment was not being negatively impacted on.
target: Lontan avan u kumans enn lantrepriz, u ti bizen enn Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) pu gete si sa lantrepriz-la pu afekte lanvironnman.

input: Just start up, wait 3 days, and if you don’t hear any objection, there you go.
target: U nek kumans enn lantrepriz, u pa bizen atann plis ki 3 zur, u nek kumans li.

input: Only afterwards, when the factory has already polluted the river that goes past or poisoned everyone in the neighbourhood, only then will the government step in with controls.
target: Nek apre ki pu gete si sa lantrepriz-la pe rwinn larivyer akote, ubyen pe anpwazonn vwazen. Apre Guvernman pu get sa.

input: This way, they also say, and I’ve mentioned this before, that they will be also helping SME's.
target: Kuma mo ti dir avan, sa li osi viz pu ankuraz bann PME.

input: This ultra-liberal option is what Sithanen and the Social Alliance in power have chosen.
target: Sa opsyon iltra-liberal ki Sithanen finn swazir.

input: They have also chosen to decrease the taxes on the rich.
target: Li finn swazir osi pu diminye to taxasyon lo bann ki ris.

input: Sithanen argues that he is decreasing taxes on business and on companies so that they can make more profit, because they are paying less tax.
target: Sithanen pe dir ki bann biznes, bann konpayni pu fer plis profi parski zot pu pey mwens tax.

input: In the long run, he promises in the Budget that, however much you earn, as an individual or a company, you will only be taxed at the rate of 15%.
target: Finalman dan propozisyon Sithanen, konpayni ek individi alalong pu pey mem tax, tu pu pey zis 15%.

input: This means he is decreasing company tax so that the companies become more profitable.
target: Setadir pe diminye tax konpayni buku pu rann konpayni, antrepriz pli profitab.

input: But it means a reduction that is at the direct expense of State revenue.
target: Me pe rann zot pli profitab par rapor a enn rediksyon dan reveni bidzeter.

input: Which means it is all of us that are paying for the boss to get a higher rate of profit.
target: Setadir nu tu, nu pe pey pu sa ogmantasyon profi-la.

input: He is also reducing income tax for the rich.
target: E osi pe diminye Innkom Tax lor dimunn byen ris.

input: The range that used to pay 25-30% tax will soon disappear.
target: Sa barem 25-30% ki ena lor bann dimunn byen ris sa usi pe disparet.

input: So, even those earning Rs200,000 a month, not mentioning any names [laughter, as the newspapers that day referred to one such person] will pay at the rate of 15%, the same rate as a teacher earning Rs10,000-15,000 a month.
target: Alafen enn dimunn ki gayn Rs200,000 par mwa, san nom okenn nom, (Dimunn riye, akoz dan lagazet ena enn lexanp mem zur) li usi, li pu pey mem to 15% ki enn ti-profeser ki li, li pe gayn Rs10,000-15,000 par mwa.
Zot tu pu pey mem tarif tax, 15%.

input: The same rate as IBL, Rogers or Harel Mallac.
target: Zot pu pey parey kuma IBL u Rogers u Harel Mallac.

input: Everyone will pay the same rate.
target: Tu dimunn pu pey mem tarif Innkom Tax.

input: As I mentioned, there are measures that will cause land speculation. Speculation will be done relative to land conversion (one type of use to another), parceling, and through opening the land market to international buyers.
target: Kuma mo ti dir avan, sa bann mezir pu ankuraz spekilasyon later par konversyon, par morselman, par uver marse fonsye dan Moris a aster internasyonal.

input: Mauritian land will be re-zoned, parceled and sold off on the international market.
target: Setadir u pu morsele e vann later Moris me lor enn marse internasyonal.

input: The Budget also has measures that really aim to make Mauritius a country where labour is cheap.
target: Bidze ena bann mezir ki sirtu viz pu fer Moris vinn enn pei ek mindev bonmarse.

input: Today Mauritius is not one of the countries where labour is as cheap as in others.
target: Zordi Moris li pa enn pei ek enn mindev osi bonmarse ki lezot pei.

input: In the past, because Mauritian wage levels were not the lowest, we saw the bosses “delocalising” and moving out to Mozambique, Madagascar, Tanzania and elsewhere, where labour is cheaper.
target: E dan lepase parski Moris so mindev pa osi bonmarse, nu ti truv patrona delokalize, al Mozanbik, al Madasgaskar, al Tanzani, al kot mindev pli bonmarse.

input: In this Budget, Sithanen is taking measures that will bring Mauritian wages down to these lower levels. This is being done so as to re-establish competitiveness on the global market.
target: Me aster dan Bidze, Sithanen pe vinn pran bann mezir ki pu fer mindev Moris osi bonmarse ki mindev dan tu lezot pei, sa pe fer sa sanse pu retablir konpetitivite global.

input: But whatever their reason for doing this, the result is that the working class and the poor will be getting lower real wages than they used to get for the same amount of work.
target: Me sa pu nerport ki rezon ki zot pe fer li, so rezilta seki klas travayer ek dimunn mizer pu gayn mwens saler reel pu mem travay ki zot ti abitye fer.

input: Let’s study these measures aimed at lowering the cost of production by lowering wages:
target: Anu get bann mezir ki pe propoze dan Bidze pu fer kud prodiksyon bese par fer mindev vinn bonmarse:

input: Annual wage compensation is what allows workers to face price rises.
target: Konpansasyon saler ki ti ena enn fwa par an, li la pu permet travayer fer fas a tu ogmantasyon pri.

input: But there is another aspect that is not often mentioned.
target: Me ena enn laspe dan konpansasyon saler ki nu pa tann koze buku.

input: When prices increase in Mauritius, it is mainly because of the depreciation of the rupee.
target: Se ki, kan ena ogmantasyon pri dan Moris, li prensipalman lakoz ena depresyasyon rupi.

input: Depreciation is what brings most inflation to Mauritius.
So the increase in prices comes along with depreciation.
target: Alor ogmantasyon pri li vinn ansam ek depresyasyon.

input: What depreciation means is that there are windfall gains, windfall profits, for enterprises that export.
target: Depresyasyon li ule dir windforl profi pu bann lantrepriz.

input: A factory making T-shirts sells one for US$1.
target: Si u get enn lantrepriz ki prodir T-shert, li vann so T-shert pu US$1.

input: Before depreciation the T-shirt brings the boss US$1, which he goes to the bank and changes for Rs28.
target: Avan depresyasyon sa T-shert-la kan patron-la gayn so US$1, li al sanz li dan labank li pu gayn Rs28.

input: After some years of depreciation, the boss takes the same T-shirt money that is US$1 but this time round the bank gives him Rs32.
target: Lane apre ki ena depresyasyon, patron vann enn T-shert parey a mem pri US$1. Me sa kut-la kan patron al labank, labank donn li Rs32.

input: This is for the same T-shirt, with depreciation.
target: Sa pu mem T-shert-la akoz depresyasyon.

input: So the boss has this windfall profit from a sales price of Rs28 up to one of Rs32.
target: Alor patron-la fer enn winndforl profi sorti Rs28 vinn Rs32.

input: With wage compensation, the philosophy is that the government and unions say to the boss, “You had to a windfall profit, while the workers are having to pay more for buying the same necessities. You have to share that windfall gain with workers.”
target: Ek konpansasyon saler, so filozofi sete pu dir patron u finn fer enn winndforl profi akoz depresyasyon, depresyasyon inn rann travayer pli mizer, seki nu pe dimann patron fer par konpansasyon se pran sa winndforl profi-la donn enn parti ladan travayer.

input: What is important about this way of looking at workers is that we are seeing them as “producers” and not just as “consumers”. But without wage compensation, workers’ real wages will get lower year after year.
target: Setadir sa laspe kot nu get travayer kuma enn prodikter, pa get travayer zis kuma enn konsomater, sa enn laspe inportan. Me kuma fason nu pe ale, setadir lane apre lane travayer so saler reel setadir seki so saler kapav aste pu diminye ankor pli vit.

input: NRB and PRB to be replaced.
target: Bidze anons ki pu aboli NRB ek PRB.

input: In the Budget, Sithanen clearly announces that institutions such as the National Remuneration Board (NRB) and Pay Research Bureau (PRB) will disappear, and be replaced by one called the “National Wages Council”.
target: Dan Bidze, pe anons klerman ki bann institisyon kuma National Remuneration Board (NRB), Pay Research Bureau (PRB) pe disparet, ek pu ranplase par enn National Wages Council.

input: And in particular the Awards or Remuneration Orders that the NRB and PRB come up with so as to determine minimum wages for each sector at any time, will be done away with.
target: Me sirtu bann award, NRB e PRB, dan enn serten mezir zot determinn saler minimem dan diferan sekter.

input: These “awards” determine minimum work conditions for different grades of workers in many, many different sectors.
target: Bann award zot determinn kondisyon danplwa dan diferan sekter pu diferan grad travayer.

input: The bosses do not want this.
They want all workers to be “multi-skilled”.
This way, when there is no work in the factory, when, say, orders have dropped, they can send you out to sweep the yard.
target: setadir kan ena travay dan lizinn u travay, kan pena komann dan lizinn, donn u enn balye dir u al balye lakur.

input: That’s the kind of multi-skilling the boss wants.
The boss also wants to be able to benefit from unemployment.
target: Patron usi ule kan ena somaz, li ule profite.

input: He wants to be able to offer an unemployed person less money and lesser conditions than the worker he already employs. He knows that unemployed workers will work for less, because otherwise they risk dying of starvation.
target: Patron ule kapav ofer lanplwa mwens ki saler minimem parski dimunn pe krev de fen.

input: The bosses will tell you, “Look! You’re dying of starvation as it is. Why not come work for me for Rs 12 a day?” and if your children are going hungry, you will end up working for Rs12 a day.
target: Patron pu dir u, “Get sa, u pe krev defen mem, abe vinn travay, mo donn u Rs12 lazurne”. E si u zanfan pe krev de fen, u pu al travay pu Rs12 lazurne.

input: The existence of the Awards or Remuneration Orders did not allow this.
target: Me award zordi pa permet sa.

input: What Sithanen is doing will introduce this kind of practice.
target: Seki Sithanen pe fer, li pe permet ki sa arive.

input: The bosses will be free to offer Rs12 a day.
target: Patron pu kapav ofer travay pu Rs12 lazurne.

input: The Budget is proposing to link wages to “productivity”, and also the bosses “capacity to pay”.
target: Bidze pe vinn propoz pu amar tu saler avek prodiktivite, e avek kapasite pu patron peye.

input: This means in order to get a wage increase, you will have to produce more.
target: Savedir pu u gayn enn ogmantasyon saler, u pu bizen prodir plis.

input: If you can’t, then your wage will remain unchanged.
target: Si u pa kapav prodir plis, u saler pu res parey.

input: Even while the same wage buys you less staples.
target: E sa mem saler la pu aste mwens rasyon.

input: And as you know in our country, no boss ever has the capacity to pay.
target: Dan Moris isi, tu patron pa kapav pey nanye!

input: So when they come along with this “capacity to pay”, they are really bluffing, because they know that on principle the bosses can’t pay.
target: Alor kan vinn koz “capacity to pay”, u pe kuyonn dimunn parski an prensip patrona pu dir li pa kapav peye.

input: On principle, all bosses have been running at a loss all along.
target: An prensip tu patron fer lapert.

input: If you walk along La Chaussée Street, you can see them queuing up to beg!
target: Kan u marse lari La Chaussée u truv zot pe dimann sarite!

input: On principle, they are very poor. [Laughter.]
target: An prensip zot mari mizer! Fransman zot pa kapav peye! (Lasal riye).

input: Another measure in the Budget that we judge to be important is that the government is to bring in a law to decrease the notice a boss gives before sacking you.
target: Enn lot zafer dan sa Bidze-la, enn laliyn dan sa diskur Bidze-la ki nu truv byen grav. Zot pe vinn propoze pu sanz lalwa travay pu diminye preavi.

input: Today, if you have so many years service, the boss has to give you notice of one month, two months or three months, before sacking you. Government is changing this.
target: Zordi si u ena tan banane servis, patron oblize donn u enn preavi, enn mwa, de mwa u trwa mwa avan li lisansye u.

input: They intend to decrease the amount of Severance Allowance that the boss has to pay to dismiss a worker.
target: Guvernman pe propoz pu sanz sa.

input: In the budget speech, if it were not tragic, you would have to laugh at how they say this.
target: Zot pe propoz pu sanz kantite Severenns Alawenns ki enn patron oblize peye kan li lisansye enn travayer.

input: They say that they will decrease the “cost of separation”, meaning a boss gets “separated” from his worker, as if the sacking were a divorce.
target: Dan diskur Bidze, manyer ki zot dekrir sa (si li pa ti usi dramatik, si li pa ti usi trazik, u ti preske kapav riye).

input: So, Government says that the “cost of separation” should not be too high.
target: Dan diskur Bidze, manyer zot dekrir diminye preavi ek diminye Severenns Alawenns, se zot pe amenn bann mezir dan Bidze seki zot apel diminye “cost of separation”, setadir seki li kut patron pu li separ limem depi so travayer. Ondire enn espes divors, enn separasyon.

input: And this when it is the worker who is losing his job, his income, and his means to feed his family.
target: Alor Guvernman pe vinn dir ki fode pa separasyon-la kut tro buku a patron.

input: To Rama Sithanen, that is just a “cost of separation” to his boss.
target: Zot apel sa “cost of separation” kan enn travayer pe perdi so plas travay, pe perdi so mwayen pu li nuri so fami.

input: He only sees this as the price it will cost the boss to separate himself from his worker.
target: Pu Rama Sithanen, sa li enn “cost of separation”. Li get li dipwendvi ki sa pu kut patron pu li separ limem depi so travayer.

input: And of course, there is the postponement of the retirement age to 65.
target: Lerla evidaman, ogmant laz retret sorti 60 an pu vinn 65 an.

input: It is now, as everyone knows, 60.
That’s when they have to start paying you your pension.
target: Sa asterla kan zot bizin pey ou pansyon.

input: From 2008 and until 2018, the change will be effected.
With this measure, I’ll never get to retirement.
target: Avek sa mezir la zame mo pa pu gayn pansyon.

input: Every time I get there, they’ll add on 2 months!”.
target: Sak fwa mo pu ariv laz pansyon zot pu azut ankor 2 mwa.

input: Anyway from the year 2018, retirement age is 65.
target: Setadir apartir 2018, retret pu vinn laz 65 an.

input: I mentioned at the Forum organized by the Federation of Civil Service and Other Unions that when you take the postponement of retirement together with the Budget’s introduction of seasonal labour and casual work, it is very serious.
target: Mo ti mansyonn sa dan enn Forum FCSOU, kan u pran ogmantasyon laz retret u azut li avek seki Bidze pe dir ki travay pu vinn travay sezonye, pu vinn travay preker, pu vinn travay bat-bate, li grav.

input: Take the example of a 61-year-old bricklayer.
target: Mo ti pran lexamp enn mason 61 an.

input: He will have to wait four years before he gets his pension at 65.
target: Li bizen atann 4 an avan 65 an.

input: But who is the employer that will take on a 61-year-old bricklayer on his worksite to lay bricks and plaster ceilings?
target: Kisannla pu anplway enn mason 61 an pu poz blok, pu krepi plafon?

input: The last measure to crown it all is when Sithanen announces that there will now be just a single job market, free zone and non-free zone.
target: Dernye mezir pu kuronn tusala, Sithanen vinn anonse ki aster pu ena enn sel marse travay, zonn frans ek non zonn frans.

input: We all know what that means.
target: Nu tu kone ki sa ule dir.

input: When the entire budget is aimed at lowering wages, it means “single” in the sense of lowering the non-free-zone sector to the level of the free zone.
target: Kan u ena enn Bidze ki pe rod enn nivelman par leba, kan u vinn dir pu ena enn sel marse travay pu zonn frans ek pu non zonn frans.

input: Everyone knows that work conditions in the free zone are inferior to those in other sectors.
target: tu dimunn kone ki kondisyon dan zonn frans e zot bann kondisyon netman inferyer.

input: And we remember when Government finally respected the demand for equal work for equal pay for women and men, they lowered the men’s wages to the level of the women’s. Then there was “equality”. The same thing will be happening again.
target: Nu rapel kan Guvernman ti dir pu egaliz saler dan zonn frans ant zom ek fam, tu dimunn gayn mem saler ki fam. Alor tu dimunn ti gayn sa ti saler. Mem zafer pu arive ankor.

input: Lalit’s campaign for an alternative political economy.
target: Kanpayn Lalit pu enn lekonomi alternativ.

input: To end with, let us look at our campaign, the one we have been running since before the general election, the campaign for a political struggle towards an alternative to the present economy.
target: Pu termine, nu get nu kanpayn, kanpayn ki Lalit pe amene depi avan eleksyon zeneral. Kanpayn pu enn lekonomi alternativ kot bann nuvo sekter prodiksyon kapav kree lanplwa byen byen vit.

input: We are campaigning so that the compensation money (for the fall in the price of sugar) that Europe is offering to pay is put to good use. What is being done with that money? Is it just going to the sugar estate bosses for them to sack workers? Is it going to be used to develop new work sectors?
target: Nu pe amenn kanpayn pu ki sa larzan ki sipoze gayne depi Lerop akoz rediksyon dan pri disik, servi byen. Ki pu fer ek sa larzan-la? Eski pu donn sa tablisman pu li lisansye dimunn? Eski pu servi sa larzan-la pu devlop bann nuvo sekter?

input: We are campaigning for unemployment benefit.
target: Nu pe amenn kanpayn pu alokasyon somaz.

input: We are campaigning for labourers and artisans who are laid off to be given land to plant on.
target: Nu pe amenn kanpayn pu donn later bay a laburer ek artizan ki lisansye.

input: We are campaigning so that foreign exchange gets taken out of the hands of the private sector because they have been using their recent access to foreign exchange so as to intentionally provoke depreciation in the value of the rupee, thus raking in money, and thus also causing the prices everyone pays for every-day goods to go up.
target: Dan nu kanpayn ena osi lor deviz etranzer, zordi pri depann lor depresyasyon. Depresyasyon depann lor misye-la, parski patron ki kontrol deviz etranzer. Alor nu dan nu kanpayn nu pe dir non, sa kontrol lor deviz etranzer bizen nepli dan lame patron.

input: Now that the Government has announced its Budget, in what way will this affect the campaign we are already running?
target: Aster ki ena enn Bidze, kimanyer sa afekte kanpayn ki nu amene?

input: Clearly the Budget has exposed the boss’s agenda very clearly.
target: Me klerman Bidze-la vinn expoz azanda patrona.

input: The budget has exposed the agenda of the economic and political ruling class and also of the local and international ruling class.
target: Li vinn expoz azanda klas dirizan ekonomik ek politik, klas dirizan lokal ek internasyonal.

input: Never before has their agenda been exposed so nakedly as it has been by the Sithanen budget.
target: Zot azanda inn expoze, zot azanda vremem zame inn expoze kuma inn expoze dan sa Bidze Sithanen-la.

input: In our campaign we must denounce this.
target: Dan nu kanpayn nu bizen denons sa.

input: In our campaign we must also denounce the incapacity of the political regime to protect employment and workers’ standard of living, and expose how this is as a result of their having adopted the bosses’ agenda.
target: Dan nu kanpayn, nu bizen denons inkapasite rezim politik aktyel pu protez lanplwa ek protez nivo de vi parski li pe adopte azanda burzwazi.

input: We must also evidently put into question the very logic of capitalist globalization.
target: Nu pu bizen osi klerman met an kestyon lozik globalizasyon kapitalist.

input: At the moment it is more appropriate than it has been until now, that is to say it has become relatively easy, to put into question the logic of capitalist globalization, and the logic of capitalism, itself.
target: Aster lepok inn vini kot li buku plis apropriye, buku plis fasil pu nu met an kestyon lozik globalizasyon kapitalist, lozik sistem kapitalist limem.

input: This is because the Sithanen budget exposes the cruel face of the capitalist system.
target: Parski sa Bidze-la pe vinn expoz sa fas kriyel ki ena dan sistem kapitalist e dan nu kanpayn nu bizen expoz sa lozik kapitalist.

input: We must now convince other organizations, the trade unions, and associations, to join us in our campaign because it has become a life-or-death struggle for ordinary people.
target: Nu bizen konvink bann lezot lorganizasyon, muvman sindikal, bann lezot lasosyasyon dan pei pu zwenn dan sa kanpayn-la parski li pe vinn enn kanpayn lavi-lamor pu lamas dimunn.
