input: And it will become urgent now that we aim (together with other organizations and other people) at setting up a political program, not just for the sugar industry and the free zones, but at setting up a political program that aims to bring about a thorough change in the whole of society – economic, political and social.
target: E sirtu li pe vinn irzan ki nu kanpayn viz pu ansam, avek lezot lorganizasyon, ansam avek lezot dimunn, etablir enn program politik pa zis pu lindistri sikriyer ek zonn frans, enn program politik ki viz pu amenn enn veritab sanzman sosyete, onivo ekonomik, onivo politik, onivo sosyal.

input: We are developing this kind of political program that aims at this real change, that is to say, a socialist change.
target: Enn program politik ki viz sa veritab sanzman, enn sanzman sosyalis.

input: We shouldn’t forget that although we are running this campaign here against Sithanen’s budget and against the local bourgeoisie, the struggle we are embarked on goes beyond this.
target: Nu pa bliye ki sa travay-la malgre ki nu oblize fer li isi fas a Bidze Sithanen, fas a patrona lokal, me sa lalit ki nu pe propoze, sa muvman ki nu pe propoze la.

input: It is a regional struggle with others in the region, and an international struggle with others worldwide.
target: li usi enn lalit rezyonal ansam avek bann pei dan larezyon, e onivo internasyonal.

input: In Lalit we already have many international contacts.
target: Dan Lalit nu ena buku kontak avek bann lorganizasyon internasyonal.

input: That is how we see the struggle ahead.
target: Ala kuma nu pe truv kanpayn ki nu pe amene.

input: I would like to thank Lalit for inviting me to be here during the process of developing a common understanding of the situation in the country, and to share ideas as to what Lalit as a political party is doing in terms of developing a new political economy.
target: Mersi pu finn invit mwa pu partaz ar zot mo konpreansyon seki pe arive dan pei, e sirtu mo konpreansyon seki Parti Lalit pe sey fer dan sityasyon aktyel dan Moris.

input: I’ve had the opportunity to read the proposals and demands put forward by Lalit to tackle the crisis that is hitting Mauritius.
target: Mo finn gayn lokazyon pran konesans bann demand, bann revandikasyon, ki Lalit pe met divan dan kriz ki pe fwet Moris.

input: In fact, the crisis is affecting the population already, and doing so violently.
target: Anfet kriz la pe fwet tu dimunn dan enn fason byen vyolan.

input: It is a situation that is becoming dangerous.
target: Li enn kriz, nu kapav sir, pu vinn deplizanpli pli grav.

input: We do not know how it will evolve.
target: E nu pa konn so lafen.

input: We might be led to believe that it is a “containable” crisis, as Sithanen clearly believes it is when he says that in two or three years’ time everything will be just fine.
target: Setadir nu pa kapav dir ki li enn kriz ki nu kapav mezire, kuma Rama Sithanen fer, kan li dir ki dan 2-3 an tu pu revinn korek.

input: He has no idea where the present crisis is leading.
target: Li mem, li pa futi kone kot sa kriz kot nu finn rantre-la pu al fini.

input: As comrade Ram Seegobin explained, the crisis is imminent.
target: Kuma Kamarad Ram inn explike avan mwa, kriz-la pe vini.

input: Even if we didn’t call it a crisis, the structural problems in the Mauritian capitalist system and the problems of the Mauritian economy in its relationship with the world economy – which used to give the appearance of being protected from the consequences of changes in the world economy – make it abundantly clear for everyone to see that the Mauritian economy and even the whole of Mauritian society are already undergoing massive upheavals.
target: E mem si nu pa ti apel li “kriz”, problem striktirel dan sistem kapitalist Morisyen, problem dan lekonomi Moris ek so lyen avek lekonomi mondyal, mem si li ti paret nu ti pe gayn enn sertenn proteksyon depi konsekans developman dan lekonomi mondyal, mo kwar aster li pe vinn deplizanpli evidan, flagran mem, ki lekonomi Moris, lasosyete Moris an zeneral, pe travers dan bulversman.

input: And it is working people and the poor who are suffering the worst effects of these upheavals.
target: E sirtu, se travayer e dimunn mizer ki pe sufer sa bann bulversman-la dan enn fason pli pir.

input: I know that comrades in Lalit and those present today have already started to discuss many of the aspects of this crisis.
target: E mo osi panse ki bann kamarad dan parti Lalit e dimunn prezan zordi inn deza fini kumans diskit plizir laspe sa kriz-la.

input: Today is not the beginning of this work.
Today my talk won’t be a blow-by-blow commentary on each of the 12 demands that Lalit put forward.
target: Donk zordi dan mo papye, mo pa pu fer komanter ubyen al diskit enn-par-enn sa 12 demand, sa 12 revandikasyon ki Lalit inn fer.

input: I will discuss them globally as being Lalit’s response to its accurate identification of the gravity of the crisis.
target: Mo pu get zot dan enn fason global kuma enn risponns a sa kriz ki Lalit finn idantifye korekteman kuma enn kriz grav.

input: I hope to refer to one or two of the demands in some detail, as I proceed with my speech.
target: Mo espere mo resi pran enn-de demand ladan an plis detay, amezir mo fer mo diskur.

input: In particular, I will explain what flows from the Lalit demands: What kind of ideology?
target: Avan tu, mo pu explike ki dekul de sa bann revandikasyon la: Ki kalite ideolozi?

input: That is to say, when we struggle for these demands, where is it likely to lead us?
target: Setadir, kan nu pu lager pu sa bann revandikasyon-la, kot sa kapav amenn nu?

input: Where ought it to lead us?
And what outcome can we expect from a political campaign on the basis of these demands?
target: Ki kapav debuse atraver enn kanpayn politik lor baz sa bann revandikasyon ki finn met an avan?

input: I will not go into much detail, I will just touch on things like: What does capitalism in its present form show us about the real, deep-seated nature of capitalism itself?
target: Mo pa pu rant dan tro detay, mo nek pu tus li inpe: Ki sistem kapitalist a lepok aktyel-la pe montre nu lor so natir profon?

input: How does this expose the sorry state that capitalism is actually in?
target: Dan ki mezir li pe montre nu dan ki leta li ete?
Dan ki leta de fayit li ete?

input: How does capitalism in its present form affect people, people in their thousands.
target: Dan sa kondisyon-la, kimanyer li afekte dimunn, dimunn par milye?

input: Let’s take the two sectors, sugar and textiles.
target: Mo pu pran 2 sekter, Disik ek Textil.

input: They clearly show that a large part of our economy is in deep, deep trouble.
target: Zot montre klerman ki enn gran parti nu lekonomi finn dan beze.
Sa li byen inportan nu realiz sa.

input: The economic history of Mauritius has been dominated by the sugar sector.
target: Moris so listwar ekonomik domine grandman par Disik.

input: Since Independence this has continued unchanged.
target: Depi Lindepandans vini mem, li finn parey.

input: After Independence, one of the emerging sectors that created jobs was the textile industry.
target: Enn bann nuvo sekter ki ti kree lanplwa se sekter Textil.

input: Today we can see both sugar and the textile industry struggling in something like death throes.
target: Zordi nu kapav dir ki sekter Textil finn ariv dan so lagoni.

input: This is affecting the entire Mauritian economy.
All its structures are affected, and the production apparatus as a whole is affected by it.
target: Tu bann striktir afekte, tu laparey prodiksyon afekte.

input: This is why these shocks have brought, are bringing, and will go on bringing all sorts of problems.
target: Samem ki sa bann bulversman finn amenn, pe amenn e pu kontinye amenn, ankor plizir problem.

input: The first problem is the loss of jobs.
This is forcing the capitalists and the Government in power to take decisions to re-organize the Mauritian economy.
target: Sa pe amenn kapitalis e Guvernman o-puvwar pran desizyon pu re-organiz lekonomi Moris.

input: They are re-organizing the economy, precisely because the way it was, isn’t working anymore.
target: Zot pe re-organiz lekonomi parski seki nu ti ena nepli marse.

input: However, they are re-organizing it in a way that puts the whole burden of the re-structuring and re-orientation on to the working class and the poor.
target: Me zot pe fer li dan enn fason kot se klas travayer, se dimunn mizer ki pe bizen pey leku sa re-organizasyon-la, sa re-oryantasyon-la.

input: The Government and the employers are not looking at what will happen to the hundreds of thousands of people directly concerned when these two main sectors of the economy are collapsing and heading for bankruptcy.
target: Guvernman ek anplwayer pa pe get problem ki divan zot an term ki pu ariv sa santenn milye dimunn kan 2 sekter importan lekonomi fware, al fer fayit.

input: They are principally concerned with setting up new sectors in a way that ensures the continuation of their profit and their capacity to continue making profit, whatever the social cost and despite the cost to the ordinary people.
target: Zot pli interese pu kone kimanyer pu met nuvo sekter dibut dan enn fason ki zot profi, zot kapasite fer profi, kontinye malgre ku sosyal, malgre ki sa pu kute a bann dimunn.

input: It looks like something straightforward, but it is important that we understand this.
target: Li paret enn zafer byen sinp, me li inportan pou nu bizen konpran li.

input: This leads us to pose the question: What is to be done in a situation like this?
target: E sa fer nu poz la kestyon:Ki bizen fer dan enn sityasyon kumsa?

input: Should we restrict ourselves to defending workers’ interests, as the Unions do, and as Unions are supposed to do?
target: Eski nu pu kontant nu defann lintere travayer kuma sindika fer, e kuma sindika bizen fer?

input: That is to say, when there is a threat of job losses, do we just fight job losses?
target: Setadir eski kan ena menas pert danlpwa, lager kont pert danplwa?

input: When there is a rise in the cost of living, do we just fight to try to get, say, a 10% wage rise?
target: Kan lavi vinn ser, sey lager pu gayn kitfwa pu 10% ogmantasyon saler?

input: Do we only fight against the boss’s policy of “hire and fire”, of their taking people on and sacking them at will?
target: Lager pu pa permet patron nek “hire and fire”, nek pran dimunn e met dimunn deor lor kondisyon ki patron anvi?

input: Do we fight only against the destruction of legal frameworks like the Labour Act, institutions like the NRB, PRB etc, when they come under threat?
target: Lager pu pa aboli kad legal kuma Labour Act, so bann institisyon kuma NRB, PRB, etc ki zordi pe menase?

input: Should we restrict the struggle to just protecting acquired rights, when they come under attack or should we go to the heart of the problem?
target: Eski nu pu lager sinpleman pu prezerv bann aki, ubyen eski nu pu rant dan leker-mem problem-la?

input: I would like now to look at Lalit’s demands.
target: Mo ti anvi zordi get enn ku revandikasyon ki Lalit pe fer.

input: What political dimension do these demands have?
A political party like Lalit is not the same thing as a workers’ organization like a trade union.
target: Enn parti kuma Lalit li napa mem zafer ki enn lorganizasyon travayer kuma enn sindika.

input: A trade union’s very function is to defend workers’ rights.
target: Sindika  so fonksyon se li bizen defann travayer.

input: However, in a period of crisis, a political party like Lalit has other responsibilities.
target: Divan enn sityasyon byen byen grav, enn parti kuma Lalit, ena lezot responsabilite.

input: In my opinion, a party like Lalit has three responsibilities.
target: Dapre mwa, enn parti kuma Lalit ena 3 responsabilite.

input: The first responsibility of a political party like Lalit is analysis. It must accurately analyze the economic crisis. It must analyze both the local and the international dimensions of the crisis.
target: Premye responsabilite enn parti politik kuma Lalit se pu analiz byen sa kriz ekonomik-la dan so dimansyon lokal e dan so dimansyon internasyonal.

input: That means understanding the contradictions and weaknesses inside the Mauritian economy, and how these structural weaknesses are affected by the changes in the world economy.
target: Setadir konpran byen kontradiksyon ek febles andan lekonomi Moris, e kimanyer sa bann febles dan so striktir afekte par seki pe arive dan lekonomi mondyal.

input: Mauritius is not only small geographically, but also economically; relative to the world economy, it is insignificant.
target: Nu bizen realize ki Moris li pa zis tipti zeografikman me ekonomikman osi li tipti pu lekonomi mondyal.

input: If Mauritius disappeared tomorrow, it wouldn’t be a great loss to the world economy.
target: Si Moris disparet dime, li pa pu enn gran pert dan lekonomi mondyal.

input: But if a country like the USA, India, China, or the European Union were to disappear, the world economy would find itself drastically altered.
target: Me si enn pei kuma Lamerik, si bann pei kuma Lend, Lasinn, Lerop al disparet, lerla lekonomi mondyal transforme enn sel ku net.

input: But, although the Mauritian economy might be insignificant to the global economic system, the people who live in Mauritius are important, the men, women and children living here are important.
target: Si lekonomi Moris pa inportan dan sistem ekonomik mondyal, me imen ki viv dan Moris inportan, dimunn ki viv dan Moris, zom, fam, zanfan,  zot inportan.

input: They are important to us, but they are not important to the Mauritian capitalists or to international capitalists.
target: Zot kapav inportan pu nu, me zot napa inportan pu kapitalis Morisyen ni pu kapitalis internasyonal.

input: This again seems to be a simple fact, but it is very important for workers, workers’ organizations and trade unions to realize this simple fact.
target: E sa li paret enn zafer sinp me li byen inportan pu travayer, pu lorganizasyon travayer, pu sindika konpran sa.

input: Human beings living in Mauritius are not important as human beings for the Mauritian capitalists or the international capitalists.
target: Bann imen ki viv dan Moris napa inportan pu kapitalist Morisyen antan ki imen.

input: They are only interested in you as workers because you can work for them, and through you and your work, they can enrich themselves.
target: Li interese ar u, par lefet ki u kapav travay, par u kapav fer larises, e par eski li kapav fer profi lor travay ki u fer.

input: They are interested in you so that they can make profits from your labour.
target: Apart sa li pa interese ar u.

input: What’s serious about this last Budget is that this Government has, in it, accepted the capitalist logic.
target: Seki grav avek sa Bidze, seki sa Guvernman-la finn aksepte lozik ki kapitalist pe dir.
E sa li inportan nu konpran sa.

input: Because the Government that prepared this budget came out of the social democratic movement, supposedly.
target: Parski sa Guvernman ki finn fer sa Bidze-la, li enn guvernman ki sorti dan muvman sosyal demokrasi sipoze.

input: It is a Government that originated in the workers’ movement, and indeed its name is literally “the Labour Party”, to remind us.
target: Li enn guvernman ki sort dan muvman travayer, so nom dayer se le “Parti Travailliste”.

input: So that you can follow my argumentation later, I’d like to say that it is not normal that a Labour Government comes up with a budget like this one.
target: E bann muvman kumsa, pu u konpran inpe lor seki mo pu vini pli tar, u bizen konpran ki li pa normal pu enn guvernman Travayis vinn avek enn tel Bidze.

input: It is not an ordinary event for anyone who studies history, for anyone who knows Labour’s history.
target: Li pa enn zafer ordiner pu dimunn ki konn listwar, pu dimunn ki konn muvman Travayis.

input: Because the social base and the electoral base of Labour are in the working class and the poor. It has always tried to set up, within the Mauritian State, certain sections of the State itself, that protect workers, sections that are in favour of workers.
target: Parski Travayis so baz sosyal, so baz elektoral li dan travayer, dan dimunn mizer, li finn tuzur seye met dibut sertenn seksyon andan mem Leta Morisyen ki protez travayer, ki anfaver travayer.

input: For example, free education, free health services, subsidizing certain costs of education, free transport for pensioners and students.
target: Par examp, ledikasyon gratis, servis medikal gratis, pa peye pu serten fre dan ledikasyon, transpor vinn gratis pu bann vye e pu bann etidyan.

input: One finds these kinds of measures not only in Mauritius, but also abroad.
target: Bann mezir kumsa u pu truve pa zis dan Moris me deor, a letranze.

input: For example, in European countries, where a Government born out of the workers’ movement, like the British Labour party or the French Socialist party, came to power, in the normal course of history, they have created institutions within the State, within the capitalist system, that, to some extent protected workers, and they have conducted their politics so as to give a certain degree of protection to working people.
target: Par examp dan pei Lerop, kan ena bann guvernman ki sort dan muvman travayer kuma Parti Travailliste Angle, Parti Socialist Franse, zot normalman dan zot listwar met dibut dan laparey leta, andan lekonomi kapitalist, zot met anplas bann institisyon e zot ena enn politik ki ondire donn enn sertenn proteksyon klas travayer.

input: So, when we use the word “ultra liberal” to describe this budget, we must follow the logic we’ve just set out.
target: Donk kan nu pe servi mo iltra-liberal pu dekrir sa Bidze, nu bizen swiv sa lozik-la.

input: We must analyze the Labour Party’s trajectory, and take a hard look at its propaganda since the General Elections, to see whether Labour will be continuing to protect the downtrodden as it says it is doing.
target: Nu bizen poz lakestyon e analiz byen sa propagann Travayis depi eleksyon zeneral ki li pu kontiyn sa lalit Travayis pu protez malere.

input: Can we still in 2006 maintain this same analysis of the Labour Party?
target: Eski nu kapav kontinye dir an 2006 ki nu pu kontinye gard nu analiz lor Parti Travayis?

input: We must look at the Labour party’s membership and where it comes from.
target: Nu bizen gete kisannla mamb Parti Travayis e kot so bann mamb sorti.

input: We must also closely analyze the politics the Labour party has systematically followed for the past 15 years, making sure we do not only look at what they said in public meetings and during electoral campaigns.
target: Nu bizen osi get byen depi dernye 15 an ki kalite politik Parti Travayis finn sistematikman amene, pa zis seki li koze dan miting, dan kanpayn eleksyon.

input: For how long, despite its history as a working class movement, will we be able to continue regarding the Labour Party as a social democrat political organization, one that still has links with the working class movement?
target: Pu komye letan ankor nu pu konpran Parti Travayis, malgre so listwar, kuma enn lorganizasyon ki nu kapav apel sosyal demokrat ki ankor ena lyen ek muvman travayer?

input: In fact, the answer to this question may be of primary importance for our future strategies.
target: Anfet repons a sa kestyon-la li pu kapav byen byen inportan dan tu stratezi dan lavenir.

input: Any future political strategies will involve political struggles.
target: Tu stratezi politik dan lavenir pu ena pu amenn enn konba politik.

input: When I say that the first task of a political party is to analyze the situation, I don’t mean just the economic situation, but also the political situation.
target: Nu pe dir premye responsabilite enn parti se analiz sityasyon, e pu mwa, pa zis sityasyon ekonomik me osi sityasyon politik.

input: This means we need an analysis of the entire political scene, what parties there are, analyzing the MMM whose trajectory we’ve understood only too well, Labour Party and also the other parties like Mouvement Republicain (MR) and other left organizations like Muvman Premye Me.
target: Get byen dan peizaz politik ki diferan parti ena, sirtu MMM ki nu finn byen konpran ki li'nn devini, Travayis, e mem lezot parti kuma Muvman Repibliken  me osi lezot lorganizasyon de gos ki ekziste kuma Muvman Premye Me.

input: We should analyze all the political actors, all the political movements, all the political organizations and all the trade union organizations.
target: Nu bizen get tu, bann akter politik, bann muvman politik, bann organizasyon politik ek bann organizasyon sindikal.

input: We must analyze them and evaluate their potential, whether to help or hinder the workers’ struggle.
target: Nu bizen analiz zot e kone ki potansyel zot ena.

input: Will they contribute to advancing the workers’ struggle, or are they part of the problem workers have to face?
target: Eski zot pu kapav donn enn kudme ubyen zot form parti problem ki travayer ena?

input: This means identifying who is in Government, who is in which party, from the PMSD to the MR, we have to analyze the whole lot of them.
target: Donk pu mwa, rode kisannla dan guvernman, rode kisannla mamb dan bann parti politik, depi so PMSD, depi so MR, zot tu.

input: We have to be conscious of their real role, not just what they say they are doing.
target: Pu bizen get byen ki zot veritab rol, e pa zis seki zot dir.

input: I believe Lalit has already undertaken this task.
target: E mo panse sa travay-la, Lalit fini fer li.
Met an avan enn program revandikasyon.

input: The second task of a political party is to put forward a program based on demands.
target: Dezyem responsabilite se met an avan enn program revandikasyon.

input: Lalit has already undertaken this, when it puts forward these 12 demands.
target: Lalit inn deza fini fer sa osi kan li met an avan sa 12 revandikasyon-la.

input: However, this is not Lalit’s complete program.
target: Me pa dan enn fason konplet.

input: As Ram Seegobin said in his paper earlier, there is a need to develop a program not only on the economy, not only on difficulties facing workers, but also on all the other social aspects of the crisis, as it unfolds.
target: Kuma Ram Seegobin inn dir dan so papye avan, bizen devlop enn program pa zis lor problem ekonomik, lor problem travayer me lor lezot laspe sosyal ki sa kriz-la pran.

input: I won’t go into too much detail here, but it is evident that there are problems of all kinds: violence in society; difficulties for women; problems students face; difficulties old people face; the drugs problem.
target: Mo pa pu rant dan bann detay isi, me li kler ki ena: problem vyolans; problem pu fam; problem pu etidyan; problem pu vye dimunn; problem ladrog.

input: So, naturally, we need to develop a program that covers all these social problems.
target: Alor bizen devlop enn program ki natirelman bizen osi kapav reponn a tu sa bann problem sosyal-la.
Popilariz ek devlop u program revandikasyon dan klas travayer ek lamas dimunn.

input: The third task of a political party like Lalit is, after an analysis has been made of the situation, after a program of demands has been outlined, to find the best ways of popularizing the program and the demands.
target: Trwazyem responsabilite se ki enn fwa finn ena sa analiz-la, inn ena sa program-la, gete ki bann meyer fason popilariz li, e osi devlop kapasite pu popilariz sa analiz-la, sa bann revandikasyon-la.

input: This implies communicating your Program, making it known in working class milieus, amongst workers and the poor, until the entire country knows what your positions are, what you are demanding, why you demanding it, and how the demands will lead to genuine solutions to the crises in society.
target: Setadir pu bizen kapav kominik u program, fann u program dan milye uvriye, parmi bann travayer, parmi bann dimunn mizer e pu ki tu pei antye kone ki u pozisyon ete, ki u pe revandike, kifer u pe revandike e kot sa bann revandikasyon-la pu amenn nu pu truv veritab solisyon a bann kriz.

input: This work of popularizing your Program, from the very moment when you put it forward, is totally different from the way parties like the MMM and Labour proceed. Their leaders just stand up on a lorry, give a speech, and the people are left to stand and listen, applaud and cheer, and set off firecrackers.
target: Sa travay, letan mem u pe met avan u program, li pa enn kestyon pu enn parti kuma bann parti kuma MMM, Travayis, fer, u nek dibut dan enn miting, u koze, dimunn ekute, tap lame, tir petar.

input: You don’t just put forward your program in the course of an electoral meeting.
target: Sa kalite travay-la, kan u pe met u bann revandikasyon divan, u pa met li zis pu fer miting elektoral.

input: You have to discuss it with trade unionists, discuss it with members of associations, and as discussion begins, you will notice that you start to develop your program further.
target: Me u diskit li avek sindikalist, u diskit li avek dimunn dan lasosyasyon e kan u pe kumans diskit li, u pu truve u program pu kumans sanze.

input: It is not the kind of program the party drafts here in GRNW and then goes out and tells other people about.
target: Se pa enn program ki u finn ekrir isi dan GRNW e apre u rakont li tu dimunn.

input: In the process of being discussed, you will find the program will be enriched, broadened, it may also narrow down, but what is important is that you, as a party member, as you talk to other people, you all begin to share a common understanding, and to develop a common understanding.
target: Ler u pe diskit li, u pu truve ki li pu anrisi, li pu ogmante, li kapav diminye me seki inportan seki u ek dimunn avek ki u pe diskite, u pe kumans konpran mem zafer, u pe devlop li.

input: And this may just be the most difficult task of all.
target: E sa ki kapav travay plis difisil ki ena la.

input: In the tradition of the working class movement, the demands like those being put forward by Lalit are known as “Transitional Demands”.
target: Sa bann revandikasyon ki Lalit finn met an avan la, dan listwar muvman uvriye apel zot demand tranzisyonel (an Angle, “transitional demands”).

input: To explain a bit better, I will talk a bit about the particular period of the worldwide crisis in the capitalist system at the time this idea of “transitional demands” was born.
target: Pu explik sa pli byen, mo pu fer enn ti digresyon dan sa peryod kriz grav sistem kapitalist dan lemond antye.

input: Transitional Demands were made consciously for the first time in 1938 on the eve of the World War II (WWII).
target: Demand tranzisyonel ti fer pu premye fwa an 1938, lavey 2yem Ger Mondyal.

input: They were put forward just before war was declared, at a time when the fascist movement in Germany and in Spain was causing such terrible destruction to the workers’ movements and organizations, that eventually the working class movements in these countries were crushed physically through killings, assassinations, imprisonment, and these defeats were the precursor to WWII.
target: Ti fer dan enn lepok zis avan lager deklare, dan enn lepok kot muvman fasist dan Lalmayn e dan Lespayn ti pe fer ravaz byen grav kont muvman travayer, kont lorganizasyon travayer, ziska a enn serten lepok ki evantyelman dan sa bann pei-la inn kraz muvman travayer fizikman, par tuye, asasine, ferme e sa ti debus lor 2yem Ger Mondyal.

input: In this period, just before the beginning of the WWII, Leon Trotsky with the help of his other comrades developed a program called a “Transitional Program” (In French it is usually known as “Programme Transitoire”, but in Lalit we understand you use the term “Program tranzisyonel” because transposition from French into Kreol gives the idea that it is ephemeral).
target: Dan sa lepok-la, zis avan 2yem Ger Mondyal eklate, Leon Trotsky an kolaborasyon avek so bann lezot kamarad, ti devlop enn program apel “Program Tranzisyonel”. [Parfwa, kote Frankofonn, zot apel li “Program Tranzitwar”, me dan Lalit nu truve ki an Kreol si transpoz li, li donn lide ki li efemer, plito ki li reprezant enn tranzisyon.]

input: The full name of the Trotsky Program is “The Death Throes of Capitalism and the Tasks of the 4th International”.
target: Program-la so ful nom ti apel “Lagoni sistem kapitalist, e Bann Responsabilite Katriem Internasyonal”.

input: The 4th International is an organization, which Trotsky created on the basis of this program.
target: Katriem Internasyonal li enn lorganizasyon ki Trotsky ti kree lor baz sa program-la.

input: The Program on the Death Throes of Capitalism also spoke of the mass mobilization around a transitional program as the preparation for taking power.
target: Sa program lor lagoni sistem kapitalist ti usi koz mobilizasyon lamas otur enn program tranzisyonel pu prepar konket di puvwar.

input: It’s on this last aspect mentioned that I would like to lay stress, that is to say on popular mobilization, the mobilization of workers and poor people on the basis of the demands, as a process that prepares the way to taking power.
target: Lor sa dernye but ki mo ti anvi met lanfaz, lor mobilizasyon lamas popiler, travayer, dimunn mizer otur bann revandikasyon, bann demand pu prepar konket dipuvwar.

input: Obviously, in the Trotsky book at the time, there was a series of demands for that period of history, but even now, some of the demands are still up-to-date.
target: Natirelman dan liv-la ti ena enn seri revandikasyon pu sa lepok-la e sertenn sa bann revandikasyon-la zot ankor valab antanki revandikasyon azordi.

input: As I will be explaining later, a demand can be valuable, but not necessarily valuable at a particular time in history.
target: Kuma mo pu explike plitar, enn revandikasyon li kapav valab me li pa neseserman valab pu nerport ki moman.

input: If there is not an analysis of what is actually happening in the country, of the particular economic conditions that are prevailing, and of the condition the working class finds itself in, then we might say that this is a “good demand” and go ahead and fight for it, when in fact it can be a “good demand”, but we also have to be sure that when we raise the issue, when we explain the demand, it will, in fact, be capable of mobilizing people around it.
target: Si u pa gete ki pe arive dan pei, ki sityasyon lekonomi ete, dan ki sityasyon klas travayer ete, u dir sa enn “bon revandikasyon”, nu al delavan, nu dimann li. Li kapav bon, me fode kone, kan u pu sulev li, kan u pu explik li, fode kone kan u pu kapav mobiliz dimunn otur li.

input: I will come back to this point later.
target: Mo pu vinn lor la plitar.

input: What is important is that the trade union movement already has a list of demands put forward for the workers.
target: Seki inportan, deza dan sindika ena enn lalis revandikasyon pu travayer.

input: However, a transitional demand is directional, it gives an orientation to workers towards the seizing of power.
target: Me revandikasyon tranzisyonel li al dan enn direksyon, li met travayer dan sime, pu al ver pran puvwar.

input: But, if today you go and say to the working class in Mauritius, “We are in crisis, lets go and seize power”, workers will think you are crazy.
target: Me, si zordi u pu dir klas travayer Moris, “Nu dan kriz, nu al pran puvwar”, zot pu kwar u fu.

input: And they will be right to think you’re crazy [laughter].
target: E zot pu ena rezon pu kwar u fu! [Lasal riye].

input: Transitional demands have to start from where workers actually are, and from there, put forward the path towards seizing power.
target: Revandikasyon tranzisyonel bizen kumanse kot travayer ete, e depi sa plas la, tras enn sime ver priz puvwar.

input: We need to understand that many people are angry.
target: Nu bizen konpran ki buku dimunn amerde.

input: Bérenger for instance is saying, “The mood out there in the country is not good”.
target: Mo truv Berenger pe dir “Mood pa bon ditu deor la”.

input: We have to look at why it is that, despite the fact that people see it is an unacceptable budget, and even before the presentation of the budget when people knew they were becoming poorer and poorer, despite the fact that many workers are being sacked, despite many factory closures over the past 2 or 3 years, despite so many people loosing their jobs in the sugar industry, despite all the suffering due to price rises, why is it that despite all this, people are not saying, “Let’s go and take power, these ministers don’t know how to govern”?
target: Kifer, malgre ki dimunn truv Bidze-la pa bon, e mem avan bidze malgre dimunn pe truv li pe apovri, malgre travayer pe gayn lisansye, komye lizinn inn ferme depi dernye 2-3 banane, komye dimunn perdi travay dan lindistri sikriyer, komye dimunn pe sufer akoz pri pe ogmante, malgre tusala kifer dimunn pa pe dir “Nu al pran puvwar, bann-la pa konn guverne”?

input: On the contrary we hear people saying, “Chuck Bérenger out, chuck Pravind Jugnauth out as Minister of Finance, Ramgoolam is telling us that he will ‘put the people first’ and we are the people, so they will put us first, so let us vote for Ramgoolam.
target: Okontrer, nu truve dimunn pe dir “Nu met Berenger deor, nu met Pravind Jugnauth deor kuma Minis de Finans,” Ramgoolam pe dir nu li pu met “people first” e nu, nu “people”. Pu met nu “first”, be nu vot Ramgoolam.

input: And if we are not careful in 5 years’ time, we will hear people saying, “Ramgoolam lied to us. Bérenger is saying ‘Put people really first’, Bérenger is finally talking sense. Let’s vote for Bérenger!” [Laughter] If we aren’t careful, this is what is going to happen once again.
target: E si pa fer atansyon, dan 5 an, nu pu dir “Ramgoolam inn kuyonn nu, Berenger pe dir “met people really first”, Berenger pe koz enn bon koze anfen. Nu al vot Berenger!” [Lasal riye] Si nu pa fer atansyon u pu truv sa pu revini.

input: In fact, if we look at the last four elections, we find that this is exactly what happened. If we can’t go beyond replacing one politician by another, and if people think we’re crazy when we say, “Let’s take power ourselves”, the question is “What is to be done?”
target: Dayer si u get byen 4 dernye eleksyon, u pu truve ki li finn arive, li pe arive. Si li pa posib pu nu sorti la, nu fer pake miting e dan sak miting nu dir “Abe si kumsa nu al pran puvwar”. Si li pa posib pu fer sa, nu pu al pas pu fu, kestyon la se “Ki bizen fer?”

input: To understand the question of “What is to be done?” we should start from an initial point of departure, something which sounds very simple but is very important: We should start from the reality of daily life in a capitalist society, which means starting with all the complexity of the way in which the capitalist system is organized and the way in which a pro-capitalist government acts so that it manages to control society.
target: Pu nu konpran sa kestyon “Ki bizen fer?”-la, nu bizen pran enn pwen de depar ki paret byen sinp, me nu bizen pran nu pwend depar bann realite lavi dan enn sosyete kapitalist, e nu bizen pran nu pwenddepar sa fason konplike kimanyer enn sistem kapitalist, enn guvernman ki pro-kapitalist, kimanyer li resi kontrol sosyete.

input: How on earth does it succeed in governing the way it does, that is to say, in the interests of the bosses?
target: Kimanyer li resi guvern dan fason ki li pe guverne, setadir guvern dan lentere patron?

input: We can’t just say it’s because there’s a police force, and the Riot Police that can charge against us with tear-gas, and “batons”.
target: Fode pa nu kwar ki zis parski li ena lapolis, li ena Rayot ki kapav avoy nu kut gaz, kut baton.

input: It’s not just by means of repression that the government can govern as it does.
target: Fode pa nu kwar ki zis par represyon tusel ki li kapav fer sa.

input: It’s not only because of their capacity to repress us if we rise in rebellion or take part in demonstrations.
target: Li pa zis so kapasite pu reprim u si u revolte, si u al manifeste.

input: Of course, they can do this.
They have got their police and army.
target: Li ena so lapolis, li ena so larme.

input: But this is not the main explanation for how year in year out, they govern in ways that are against your interests and yet they stay in control of government.
target: Me se pa premyerman sa ki explike kifer lane apre lane, zot kapav amenn politik ki kont u lentere me zot res kapav kontrol guvernman.

input: In fact, the government and capitalists control the economy, and they control society.
target: Zot kontrol lekonomi, zot kontrol sosyete.

input: We need to understand a fundamental point, that it is not through violence that the bosses and capitalists control you, or that government controls you.
target: Nu bizen konpran byen enn zafer de baz, se pa par vyolans ki patron, ki kapitalist kontrol u, ubyen ki guvernman kontrol u.

input: They control you by means of manipulating you ideologically.
target: Li kontrole parski li manipil u dan enn fason ideolozik.

input: For example, they make you believe that “private property” is a good and normal thing.
target: Par examp, li fer u kwar ki “propriete prive” sa enn bon zafer.

input: They say it means you have your little bit of land or a nice wristwatch or a good pair of glasses, and that these are yours.
target: U ena enn ti teren, enn zoli mont, enn zoli linet, sa pu u sa.

input: They say our laws, our Constitution, itself, protect your right to enjoy private property.
target: E fode ki nu lalwa, nu Konstitisyon protez u drwa pu ena propriete prive.

input: That is, they mean while each of us has a watch, or a motorcycle, you own your house, they, the capitalists, have a right to own three-quarters of Mauritius.
target: Setadir sakenn, u ena enn mont, u, u ena enn motosiklet, u, u ena enn ti lakaz, e li, li gayn drwa trwa-kar Moris pu li.

input: They, unlike us, have the right to own a sugar estate.
target: Li, li gayn drwa ena tablisman.

input: They have the right to own a whole bank.
target: Li, li gayn drwa ena labank.

input: They have the right to own the things that make society function.
target: Li, li gayn drwa ena seki bizen pu enn sosyete fonksyone.

input: That means they have the right to own hundreds, even thousands, or hectares of land.
target: Setadir li bizen ena propriete lor santenn, milye arpan later.

input: They need to own their own factories.
They need property rights over what we call the means of production.
target: Li, li bizen drwa propriete lor seki nu apel mwayen prodiksyon.

input: And they put these two kinds of ownership on the same level.
target: Li met sa, sipoze lor mem pye degalite.

input: And then you end up saying, “It’s quite natural. They are owners of property and I am also an owner of property because I’ve got a motorbike, I own my house. So, it’s a just law and we have a fine Constitution”.
target: U dir “Be wi li enn proprieter, mo osi mo enn proprieter, mo ena motosiklet, mo ena enn lakaz. E li enn bon sistem, enn bon lalwa, enn bon Konstitisyon”.

input: They make you believe that your ownership and his are the same thing.
target: Li fer u kwar ki u ar li mem zafer.

input: They make you believe that “private property” is a good thing, just the same for everyone.
target: Li fer u kwar ki “propriete prive” enn bon zafer pu tu dimunn.

input: And especially they make you believe that all private property is the same thing.
target: E sirtu li fer u krwar ki tu propriete prive parey.

input: This belief is very thoroughly rooted in us.
target: Sa li enn zafer ki ankre.

input: If you go and ask a worker, he will tell you, “Everybody has the right to become a property owner. Absolutely everybody. Mr. Capitalist and I, on this matter at least, are in total agreement. It isn’t an issue.”
target: U pu dimann enn travayer, li pu dir u “Tu dimunn gayn drwa proprieter. Tu dimunn. Gran kapitalist ek mwa lor la nu dakor. Pena problem lor la.”

input: And obviously, on the question of private property, it is safe to say that the totality of the legal system protects it.
target: E natirelman sa kestyon propriete prive, totalite sistem lalwa ki protez sa.

input: And just in the same way as, if someone steals your motorbike, the police will open an inquiry, so, in exactly the same way, if you steal the bosses’ sugar mill, you will also have to be locked up, or shot at.
target: Parey kuma gard pu fer lanket si kikenn koken u motosiklet, parey si u koken mulen Misye-la pu dir “U bizen al ferme usi, bizen tir kut bal lor u parey”.

input: It is through this type of ideological manipulation that the capitalists remain in control of society.
target: Se atraver sa manipilasyon ideolozik-la ki kapitalist resi kontinye kontrol lasosyete.

input: So, this kind of control on the very way we are made to think needs to be exposed.
target: Alor, sa kalite kontrol lor nu fason reflesi bizen demaske, pu nu esap su sa kontrol la.

input: Elections and the right to vote are a good thing.
target: Eleksyon ek drwa de vot li enn bon zafer.

input: It’s a good thing for everyone.
target: Li enn bon zafer pu tu dimunn.

input: But what they succeed in making you think is that because you have the right to vote once every 5 years or in a by-election from time to time, that this is what is called “democracy”.
target: Dimunn dakor ki tu dimunn bizen gayn drwa vote. Me li fer u kwar ki parski u gayn drwa vote tu le 5 an ubyen dan eleksyon parsyel, li dir samem ki apel “demokrasi”.

input: They tell you you are living in a democratic country.
target: Li dir u, u  pe viv dan enn pei demokratik.

input: So, the politicians invite you to a public meeting, provide you with some firecrackers, a hamper of food and some drinks, and they explain that there is an electoral campaign to organize, so here are the flags, or here’s the cloth, you make the flags, and we’ll organize a big rally.
target: Li invit u miting, li donn u petar, li kapav donn u manze-bwar. Li pu dir ena enn kanpayn elektoral pu fer, ala pavyon ubyen donn u pavyon pu fer, fer parad.

input: They tell you to do all this and then say, “This is what democracy is”.
target: Li dir u fer tusala e li dir u “Ala sa vedir demokrasi”.

input: They make you believe it firmly when they tell you, “Your country is not Africa. Mauritius is not X or Y country, because here we are democrats”.
target: Li fer u kone, fer u kwar e fer u dakor kan li dir “Isi pa Lafrik, isi pa tel pei, isi nu dan Moris e isi nu demokrat”.

input: Every 5 years you vote for Jugnauth, Bérenger, and then the other Jugnauth, then the other someone else.
target: Tu le 5 an nu pe vot Jugnauth, Berenger, lot Jugnauth, lot sesi, lot sela.

input: This is what democracy is all about, they say.
One thing they don’t want you to know is who exactly they govern for, once you’ve voted.
target: Li pa ule u konpran ki letan u vote, sa bann guvernman-la pu kisannla zot guverne.

input: They tell you “You’ve got democratic rights”.
target: Li dir u, u ena bann drwa demokratik.

input: You do not really have democratic rights.
target: U pa vremem ena drwa demokratik.

input: It’s not a real democracy, when in the police you have people like Raddhoa beating up so many people!
target: Dan enn vre demokrasi, dimunn kuma Raddhoa dan lapolis kan otan dimunn gayn bate!

input: You have the right to vote, but this does not mean that you have your democratic rights in practice, in everyday life, for real.
target: U gayn drwa de vot me sa pa vedir ki u ena bann drwa demokratik reel, dan lapratik, konkretman.

input: No sooner have you cast you vote than they dish up a budget like this one.
target: Kuma u fini vote, u gayn enn Bidze kumsa.

input: No sooner have you cast your vote than the Government, instead of governing in your interests, instead of developing an economy in your interests, governs in the interests of someone else.
target: Kan u fini vote, guvernman pa guvern pei-la dan u lentere, lekonomi li pa existe dan u lentere, ni li pa rule dan u lentere.

input: What is the point of having voted for people, who will serve the interests of a handful of capitalists, a minority?
target: Ki serti u finn vote, pu bann dimunn ki u finn vote, zot dan lentere enn grup kapitalist, enn minorite dimunn?

input: Democracy does not mean the rule of the minority to the detriment of the majority.
target: Demokrasi pa vedir lentere minorite ki prime.

input: Democracy means, and should mean, that the majority interests rule.
target: Demokrasi bizen dir lentere mazorite ki prime.

input: In our “democratic system”, the one we have until now, things are run in the interests of a minority.
target: Dan nu sistem demokratik ki nu ena, se lentere minorite ki prime.

input: You hear people saying, “We won the majority.
Our demands will become a reality!”
People say it, but they don’t realize the irony.
target: Dimunn pu rakont u sa, me li pa futi konpran.

input: When people mobilize behind their demands, when they struggle to make practical, real life gains that are in their own interests, they could, in fact, succeed.
target: Parski kan li finn mobilize otur bann revandikasyon, kan li pe lite pu li gayne an realite, dan lapratik seki dan so lentere, li pa gayn li.

input: This is a demand that has been won in many capitalist countries in the world, in Britain, Italy, France, Germany.
target: li enn revandikasyon ki finn fini deza gayne dan plizyer lekonomi, dan plizyer pei dan lemond, dan Langleter, dan Litali, dan Lafrans, dan Lalmayn.

input: In many countries, the working class movement has succeeded in imposing on the capitalist economy that when a worker can’t get work, when a young person is looking for a job, he or she has to get an unemployment benefit in order to live.
target: Dan buku pei, muvman travayer inn dir kan nu somer, kan nu perdi plas, u travayer ki pa gayn travay, bann zenn, pu zot viv zot bizen enn minimem e ena enn alokasyon somaz dan sa bann lekonomi-la.

input: We should always bear in mind that it is not government or the boss who out of their generosity give us things.
target: Sa usi fode pa kwar ondire ki bann guvernman u bann patron ki’nn “donn” sa.

input: These are demands that, after World War II the capitalists knew they had to concede otherwise they would end up without a capitalist system at all in those countries!
target: Se bann revandikasyon ki apre 2yem Ger Mondyal inn bizen done parski si pa ti donn sa, pa ti pu ena sistem kapitalist dan sa bann pei-la!

input: Sometimes the capitalists and their political lackeys agree to concessions on certain demands in order to avoid losing everything.
target: Parfwa kapitalist e so bann politisyen, zot dakor dan serten moman zot dakor pu sede lor serten revandikasyon pu zot pa perdi tu, pu zot pa perdi plis.

input: It is always the balance of forces between you, as the working class, and them as the capitalists, that determines whether your demands will be met.
target: Se tuzur ki rapor de fors ena ant u ek kapitalis, ant kapitalis ek travayer, ki pu deside si u bann revandikasyon pu satisfer.

input: It doesn’t just depend on whether you’ve got a good trade union negotiator, a clever lawyer, a good judge, as to which concessions the capitalist will make to your demands.
target: Se pa enn kestyon u ena enn bon negosyater, enn bon avoka, enn bon ziz, ki pu deside vremem ki konsesyon kapitalist pu fer.

input: It depends on your capacity to organize, and on the strength of your organization and also on its independence from the capitalists.
target: Li pu depann lor u kapasite pu organize, e lafors u lorganizasyon, e so lindepandans depi kapitalis.

input: It also depends on what your strategy is, what program you have and where it is leading you.
target: E li depann usi lor ki u stratezi, ki u program e kot u pe ale.

input: People who are already members or supporters of a political party, workers who go to political meetings, already know all this.
target: Pu enn mamb ubyen senpatizan enn parti politik, pu enn travayer ki vinn bann renyon politik, li fini konpran tusala.

input: However, the ideological manipulation that I referred to earlier (on things like private property and elections) makes this kind of knowledge of where your interests lie difficult to acquire.
target: Me li pa fasil, presizeman akoz sa manipilasyon ideolozik-la kuma mo fek mansyone lor propriete prive, lor eleksyon.

input: Without going into too much detail, just think for a moment of the amount of brainwashing we get through the newspapers and TV?
target: San rant dan bann gran detay, eski u pe mazinn u, atraver lagazet, atraver reklam, atraver TV.

input: There are so many sources of division and so much intentionally spread confusion that many workers, hundreds of thousands, in fact, who don’t manage to discern where their own interests lie within the capitalist system, nor to realize the danger that capitalism represents for them.
target: Ki kantite divizyon e konfizyon ena pu enn travayer, pu santenn de milye travayer kot anfet napa konpran kot zot lentere ete dan sistem kapitalist e ki danze sistem kapitalist-la reprezante pu zot?

input: For these reasons, it is often only when people are actively struggling on the basis of demands that they themselves find sensible and reasonable as well as in their own interests, demands that they come to actually see clearly and to understand in practice and agree to stand up for when confronted with the inevitable resistance they meet, only then do they find themselves in a position to oppose this bourgeois ideology.
target: Se akoz samem ki, kan enn dimunn pe lite pu bann revandikasyon ki li truve fer sans, ki li truv li rezonab, me sirtu ki li truve li neseser pu so prop lentere; se atraver kan li mobilize lor la, e dan lapratik li konpran e li dakor pu konfront sa rezistans ki pu gayne kan pu mobilize ek pu organize pu gayn satisfaksyon bann revandikasyon, lerla ki li opoz sa ideolozi la.

input: It is not only workers who need to be rallied. Nor just the unemployed that happen to have a free day to be present. Nor is it just numbers. We’ve seen from the Kaya rebellion in 1999 that numbers, however huge, are not enough. There needs to be unity, not just in the sense of everyone is at the same place at the same time, but unity in our heads. By that, I mean unity on the question of what program there is in our heads and on the questions of how and when we can make progress on our demands.
target: Li pa simpleman zis travayer tusel, li pa zis somer ki nanye a fer, nu’nn truve par examp dan Lemet Kaya an Fevriye 1999, lenomb li napa ase. Bizen ena enn linite, pa sinpleman, pa zis tu ansam, me enn linite dan nu latet, enn linite lor ki program dan nu latet, dan ki fason, dan ki moman pu kapav fer enn progre, amenn sa revandikasyon enn tigit pli pre.

input: This is the process that takes the most time in struggles.
target: Se sa ki dimann buku letan dan lalit.

input: It is also what needs the most experience.

Because people will not all have the same ideas on what to do and what not to do, for the simple reason that the workers’ movement, the trade union movement and the political movement are made up of many different organizations, and people with many different ideas. The ideas of one organization are not the same as those of another.
target: parski pa tu dimunn pu ena mem lide ki bizen fer e ki pa bizen fer parski muvman travayer, muvman sendikal, muvman politik li ena plizyer lorganizasyon, plizir lide.

input: They can even be diametrically opposed.
target: Lide enn lorganizasyon pa parey kuma enn lot, parfwa li le kontrer.

input: And even in the development of the program itself, as I mentioned, it isn’t a question of sitting and writing something.
target: E, mem pu devlop sa program-la, kuma mo ti dir, pa zis nek ekrir.

input: You can’t content yourself to draft something and show people and ask them if they agree or don’t agree.
target: simpleman kontant u ekrir li ek montre dimunn e dimann li si li dakor ubyen li pa dakor.

input: The program must be constantly, permanently discussed, convincing new people of its pertinence, and being convinced by other peoples’ ideas which, after discussion, get incorporated. But what is important and takes time and experience is to constantly be in discussion with the organizations that agree to struggle on the basis of the demands in the program.
target: Li enn program ki an permanans pe diskite e pe konvenk, pe pran lide lezot dimunn, pe met ar u lide, me sirtu pe kominike ar bann lorganizasyon ki dakor pu lite pu bann revandikasyon ki ena dan program-la.

input: What exactly is a program of demands, and how does it function?
target: Seki vedir fonksyon sa revandikasyon la.

input: It contains analyses of how we understand the capitalist system, and it involves communicating this understanding not only to the most advanced sections of the working class, who understand a lot already and who have a highly developed political consciousness already, but to the greatest number of workers and the greatest number of other people who suffer because of the capitalist system.
target: Li pu kontenir analiz, konpreansyon ki u ena lor sistem kapitalist e u kapav kominik u konpreansyon pa simpleman a bann travayer ki finn pli konpran, a travayer ki ena enn konsyans politik, me a enn pli gran nomb dimunn parmi travayer e parmi lezot dimunn dan sosyete ki zot usi, zot sufer depi sistem kapitalist.

input: This is the aim of a program of demands.

But, as you fight for these demands, and you get the kind of resistance we have just mentioned from the government and the capitalists and particularly from the pro-capitalist press, you have to, as part of your program, have the capacity to justify it in the face of criticism and resistance against it, and to convince more and more people during the course of the confrontations, that these demands are what in reality represent the solution to our problems.
target: Me letan u pe lager pu sa bann revandikasyon-la, letan u pu gayn rezistans kuma nu fek diskite avan depi guvernman, e depi kapitalist e sirtu depi lapres ki pro-kapitalist, pu bizen ena kapasite pu zistifye, pu konvenk ankor plis dimunn ki sa bann revandikasyon-la, sa pu nu li reprezant solisyon a nu problem.

input: And at this point, something very important happens. The people who have already mobilized behind the demands, find that the more they mobilize, the more explanations they have to develop, the more debates they win, the more resistance hardens against these demands, and this means you have further opportunities to argue in favour of your demands.
target: E la, enn zafer enportan arive, dimunn ki mobilize otur sa bann demand-la, pli ena mobilizasyon lor la, plis ena explikasyon, plis ena deba, plis ena rezistans usi ki vinn depi ladverser kont sa, la li vinn byen posib, pu explik ankor nu bann revandikasyon.

input: You won’t win demands that are against the political strategy of your adversaries if you allow the government and the bosses to win during the course of these confrontations.
target: Pa pu gayne si li kont sa bann dimunn-la zot stratezi politik, si nu pu permet guvernman, patron gayne, dan konfli.

input: The demands are ours, and it is us that mobilize behind them.
target: Se nu revandikasyon, nu mobilize pu zot.

input: And this is the kind of consciousness that develops during the course of a number of conflicts.
target: E, se sa konsyans ki devlope apre, apre plizir konfli, ki li enn konsyans ver enn konsyans revolisyoner.

input: It is the consciousness that some kind of revolution will be necessary. People begin to realize, in the course of the struggle that it will have to be us, ourselves who put into practice our demands.
target: Pu ki sa bann revandikasyon-la realize fode numem ki met zot an pratik.

input: If we say to the bosses, “OK, give us unemployment benefit, give us, say, Rs3,000 a month”.
target: Si nu pu dir patron, “Abe korek donn nu alokasyon somaz, donn nu Rs3,000 par mwa”.

input: What will you learn in practice?
You can negotiate with Finance Minister Sithanen 20 times, and on the 21st time around, you will find that the Special Mobile Force fires on you if you persist.
target: U pu negosye 20 fwa avek Sithanen, 21em fwa u pu truv SMF tir kut bal lor u si u pe persiste.

input: He’s said no to your demand, and you are persisting.
target: Inn dir u non, u pe persiste.

input: If you become too threatening, then he will take very serious measures to prevent you making your demands.
target: Si li truve u pe vinn tro menasan, lerla li pu pran mezir byen grav pu li anpes u fer u revandikasyon.

input: This realization is something that has to be reached collectively if you are to win gains in your interests.
target: Bizen ariv sa konpreansyon dan enn fason kolektif pu u gayn seki dan u lentere.

input: You can’t count on the government or on the bosses for your demands.
target: U pa pu kapav kont lor guvernman, ni lor patron.

input: As people realize this, this is what makes the masses of the people stand up for the program.
target: Lerla li posib ki lamas dimunn dakor pu gard sa program-la.

input: So we have to persist with our demands, and it is possible that the masses of the people will rapidly develop an understanding. Sometimes in history, the speed with which people develop an understanding is must faster than you expect. People just come to the conclusion, collectively, that now is the time to abandon past hollow hopes placed in the government and bosses.
target: Nu bizen persiste avek nu bann revandikasyon, ek kapav lamas dimunn devlop enn konpreansyon byen rapid, ena fwa li vinn pli rapid ki u ti pe atann (dan listwar nu finn truv sa), la finn ariv ler pu nu al dir zot merd.

input: If we want a truly good education system, or if we want a truly good service in the hospitals, if we want to create employment, we can’t just sit around and expect the Mauritius Employers’ Federation to invest.
target: Si nu anvi gayn vremem ledikasyon gratis, si nu anvi gayn bon sistem dan lopital, si nu anvi kree lanplwa, nu pa pu kapav atann ki MEF investi.

input: They are lying to us. In fact, they have lied to us for far too long.
target: Zot pe kuyonn nu e zot inn tro kuyonn nu.

input: This is why it is so important that all past experience is accumulated, and that workers coming into the mobilization for the first time keep in mind all that’s happened in past struggles.
target: Akoz sa mem ki li inportan ki lexperyans pase akimile, ki travayer ki rant dan enn mobilizasyon, ki rant dan nuvo konba, nuvo travayer li gard antet usi seki inn traverse dan lepase.

input: Which demands have already been put forward?
target: Ki bann revandikasyon ti met dibut?

input: Why was the past struggle for the demands lost?
target: E kimanyer inn bizen sede, setadir bann defet.

input: Because past defeats are important because they bear lessons for us today and for the future.
target: parski dan bann defet usi ena buku kitsoz pu aprann.

input: Why did the big 1971 general strike not bring the fall of the repressive government that voted the Public Order Act and that postponed elections?
target: Kifer gran lagrev 1971 pa finn debus lor met deor sa guvernman represif ki ti met POA, IRA e finn ranvoy eleksyon?

input: Especially as the MMM had extraordinarily wide support in the country.
target: Purtan MMM ti ena enn lafors extraordiner dan pei.

input: We have to remember that the MMM won a by-election, controlled all the Municipalities in Mauritius, and in the 1976 General Election, it won 34 seats out of 70 in Parliament, almost half of Parliament.
target: Ena pu rapel, MMM ti eli dan eleksyon parsyel, MMM ti pe kontrol tu minisipalite Moris, dan eleksyon zeneral 1976, li ti gayn 34 syez lor 70 dan Parlman, preske lamwatye Parlman.

input: Why did this not end in the taking of power and a socialist government?
target: Kifer sa finn debus lor enn priz puvwar, lor enn guvernman sosyalist?

input: There are important reasons why not.

When you mobilize behind socialist demands and demands in favour of the poor, these demands cannot be satisfied by a group of people, like a political party saying, as its strategy, “What you do is you vote for me, and then I’ll do this for you!”
target: Seki u pe lite pu bann revandikasyon sosyalist, bann revandikasyon dan lentere dimunn mizer, li pa enn zafer ki enn grup dimunn, enn parti politik nek dir “U vot mwa, mo pu fer sa  pu u!”

input: These demands will only be met when the people, the workers themselves through their organizations, whether clubs, associations, unions, or political parties like Lalit or Muvman Premye Me, realize that it is only through their own struggle and their own mobilization that their demands will be able to be met.
target: Sa pu arive kan dimunn, travayer limem atraver so lorganizasyon, ki li mamb enn lorganizasyon sendikal, ki li mamb enn parti kuma Parti Lalit, ki li mamb enn parti kuma Muvman Premye Me, li realize ki so lalit limem, so mobilizasyon ki pu kapav debus lor satisfaksyon so bann revandikasyon.

input: Socialist power will not be brought about by a group of people sitting in Parliament and voting a law.
target: Sa puvwar sosyalist ki nu pe rod amene la, li bizen amene par travayer limem, kan li pe lite pe rod so drwa. Li pa kapav amene par dimunn ki asiz dan Parlman vot enn lalwa.

input: Of course, Parliament can vote laws.
target: Enn Parlman, li kapav vote lalwa.

input: They can for example vote to introduce unemployment benefit, but they will only do it if you are mobilized strongly enough outside of Just as they might five years later revoke the same law and do away with unemployment benefit. If the bosses and government see that the workers’ movement has perhaps weakened, that the capitalist system is heading for some crisis, that profits are falling, that bankruptcies are on the rise, then they will stop unemployment benefit.
target: Parey, kapav dan enn lot lokazyon, 5 an apre, li pu retir li. Letan li truv muvman travayer pe febli, letan so sistem an kriz, letan so profi pe diminye, li pe fer fayit, li pu retir li.

input: And that is, in fact, exactly what is happening right now.
target: Dayer nu pe viv li zordi.

input: What the workers’ movement of the past had won, when today’s workers try to defend rights acquired in the past, the Prime Minister Ramgoolam says that in Mauritius all acquired rights have been lost.
target: Seki muvman travayer inn gayne. Kan travayer pe dir bizen protez nu drwa aki, Ramgoolam dir Moris inn fini perdi tu drwa aki.

input: That’s what he says in the newspaper.
target: Kumsa ki li reponn dan enn lagazet.

input: He says, “What acquired rights are you talking about? The Labour Act, Severance Allowance, tax-free lump sums?”
target: Li dir ”Ki drwa aki u pe rode, u pe rod Labour Act, u pe rod Severenns Alawenns, u pe dir pa taxe u lempsom?'.

input: He announces that acquired rights are over.
target: Li dir drwa aki inn disparet.

input: The whole of Mauritius, he announces, has lost acquired rights.
But notice that some rights have not been lost at all, for example the bosses still have the right to exploit people, the right to make profits, these are still acquired rights for them!
target: Enn drwa pa finn perdi, drwa patron kontiyn explwate, drwa kontiyn fer profi, sa ankor aki sa!

input: This is the important thing about crises like the one we are facing: You, unlike the bosses, lose all your rights.
target: Sa ki problem-la dan bann kriz kumsa: U, u perdi tu drwa.

input: Whether there’s a crisis or not, the bosses’ rights continue unchallenged.
target: Tu drwa ki patron ti ena avan kriz, li ankor ena drwa, kriz pa kriz.

input: You can be humiliated, you can even die of hunger, and they will go on keeping their same living standards.
target: U kapav imilye, u kapav mor defen, li, li pu kontinye gard mem nivod vi.

input: They will go on changing their Mercedes every year or two.
target: li pu kontinye sanz so Mersedes tule banane, tule 2 banane.
Li pu kontinye parey, kriz pa kriz.

input: This is what Ram [Seegobin] was explaining just before me. How they want you to bear the entire brunt of a crisis, which is of their making, it is a crisis in their system.
target: Sa ki Ram [Seegobin] ti pe dir avan mwa, tultan se u ki bizen kan ena kriz, so kriz, so sistem, se u ki bizen sarye fardo.

input: A Program of Demands, to continue, must always start with the working class movement in its existing, present state.
target: Enn program revandikasyon li bizen avan tu pran muvman travayer dan leta dan lekel li ete.

input: For example, today the working class movement is on the defensive. Right now Public Sector workers are mobilizing, rising up in protest, making demands.
target: par examp la li lor defansiv, la travayer dan Servis Piblik u pe truv travayer, fonksyoner pe mobilize, pe proteste, pe revandike.

input: And it seems that on some questions, like the tax on the lump sums, Sithanen is making concessions.
target: E lor serten kestyon, par examp lor tax lor lempsom, li paret Sithanen inn sede.

input: The question is why does this happen like this?
Because there was a problem, then the federations took the issue to the Minister, then workers demonstrated, then there were negotiations, and yet everything went back to how it was before.
target: Parski ti ena enn problem, bann federasyon sendikal inn amenn problem ek minis, inn manifeste, inn negosye, apre return parey.

input: Mobilization dies down as demands are supposed to have been met, even though you didn’t win them all.
target: Mobilizasyon rekile parski sipoze inn gayn enn sertenn satisfaksyon, pa finn gayn tu.

input: And then the merry-go-round just continues.

A transitional program aims to stop this phenomenon where mobilization ends abruptly after concessions. A transitional program continues to give direction to workers even after certain demands have been met.
target: Me enn program tranzisyonel, li pa aret muvman-la la. Li tuzur montre direksyon mem si donn u satisfaksyon lor enn revandikasyon, li pa vedir ki u lentere global antan ki enn klas inn sovgarde ek sa.

input: It shows that the interests of workers as a whole have not been assured by the concession.
target: Parski, mem alokasyon somaz, u lentere se pa pu pas u lavi tus alokasyon somaz.

input: You need an economy that creates jobs and that gives a guarantee that everyone has a job and a house and a certain standard of living.
target: Bizen enn lekonomi ki kapav kree lanplwa, ki kapav garanti u lanplwa. Ki kapav garanti tu dimunn lanplwa, tu dimunn enn sertenn kalite delavi, tu dimunn lozman.

input: When you get one concession, it does not mean you have got these things.
target: Kan gayn enn ti zafer li pa vedir sa.

input: This is why the very way that you organize the demands in a transitional program, the way you present them, is special.
target: Akoz samem bann manyer organiz, u manyer prezant bann revandikasyon dan enn program tranzisyonel, li enn tu.

input: The demands form part of a whole. You don’t just tick one demand off your list, and go back home.
target: Li pa simpleman enn zafer, ki kan gayne, nu kapav met dan pos nu al lakaz.

input: By contrast, a revolutionary organization that mobilizes on the basis of demands in a transitional program is completely different.
target: Tandi ki enn lorganizasyon revolisyoner ki mobilize lor demand dan enn program tranzisyonel li dan enn lot sityasyon.

input: It understands that working peoples’ problems will not be resolved in the interests of working people so long as politicians like Sithanen or Bérenger are in power, or so long as the bosses still control the factories, the banks and everything else they control.
target: Li konpran ki pu rezud problem travayer dan lentere travayer, pa pu kapav fer sa tan ki ena politisyen kuma Sithanen, kuma Berenger, opuvwar. Tanki patron pu ankor kontrol lizinn, pu ankor kontrol labank, patron kontrol tu.

input: A revolutionary organization has understood that the experience of history has shown that this is just not possible.
target: Li, li finn konpran dan lexperyans listwar, li pa posib.

input: But, however difficult, you have to work with the trade union organizations, work at convincing them that your program is in the interests of workers’ demands, because you need support from the trade unions and you often have to work with the leaders they happen to have.
target: E purtan, bizen travay, bizen fer konpran, si u enterese vremem pu defann lentere travayer pu sa revandikasyon aksepte, u pu bizen gayn kolaborasyon, sutyen e konpreansyon sa bann dirizan ki ekziste deza dan klas travayer.

input: So, you will work at this, in the knowledge that it will never ever happen that all the union leaders at the same time agree with you.
target: Zame pu arive kot tu dirizan pu dakor ar u.

input: But what is interesting in the nature of a transitional program is that as you mobilize around it, the unions throw up new leaders.
target: Me seki enteresan avek lalit otur enn program tranzisyonel, tuzur nuvo dirizan lev latet.

input: We saw that in the August 1979 strike.
target: Nu finn truv li dan Lagrev Ut 1979.

input: In fact, you see it all over the world when there is mobilization.
target: Nu pu truv li atraver lemond net.

input: During the course of the struggle around a transitional program, you will have workers who didn’t even know they were leaders of the union movement, because they had never been elected to the committee before.
target: Atraver lalit, enn dimunn ki li pa ti mem kone li enn dirizan parski zame li pa finn eli dan enn bord sendika.

input: If you tell one of them they’re a leader, they will laugh.
target: Si u pu dir li, li enn dirizan, limem li kapav riy u.

input: They will say they are a worker who has understood things.
target: Li pu dir u li enn travayer ki finn konpran.

input: But you will notice that he is someone who can make proposals at the level of his neighbourhood, at his worksite or in the union.
target: Me u pu truv li fer bann propozisyon dan so kartye, dan so lizinn, u dan so sendika.

input: He might indeed get into trouble with the President of the union, “What are you talking about? You get locked up for that kind of thing!
target: Li kapav gayn lamerdman ek prezidan sendika, “Ki to pe koze twa? Ena ferme ladan. Ki to pe dir nu al okip lizinn? Ena ferme, rayot pu vini.”

input: And this is how, in history, you do find that you can take power through mobilization, and not just take power by some coup d’etat or through a guerrilla war which then gets declared “socialism”.
target: E se sa dan listwar, li fason non selman u gayn puvwar me u gayn puvwar atraver mobilizasyon klas travayer, e pa atraver ku deta ubyen atraver gerila, u pran puvwar e lerla u kwar sa se le sosyalism.

input: Through mobilization that involves action by the workers themselves on the basis of their demands that respond to today’s pressing problems and, at the same time show you that your interests will not be taken care of or even maintained without addressing the biggest of all problems that workers have.
target: Me atraver aktivite, atraver lalit bann travayer zot mem lor bann revandikasyon ki reponn problem zordi me ki montre pu ki u lentere pa zis prezerve me konserve ek avanse enposib pu evit sa pli gro problem ki tu travayer ena la.

input: How to take economic power from the hands of the capitalist class?
target: Kimanyer ras puvwar ekonomik depi lame  klas kapitalist?

input: I want to thank Ram for his introduction, on who I am, and on the topic we are going to talk about.
target: Mo pu kumanse par remersye Ram pu so introdiksyon lor mwa ek lor tem ki nu pu koze zordi.

input: Although I am hoping to stick quite closely to the notes that I made so that Lindsey can translate and sum up my notes, I do have to start with two small digressions.
target: Otan ki posib mo pu sey swiv mo bann not, pu ki Lindsey kapav tradir ek rezim mo bann pwen. Me mo pu bizen kumans ek 2 ti detur.

input: Already I’m disrupting my arrangement with Lindsey!
target: Ala mo pe deza kumanse par sanz mo laranzman avek Lindsey!

input: I think there is an important thing that may be we don’t talk about enough and which I thought was important to throw in at the beginning so that maybe we can come back to it later.
target: Ena enn laspe inportan lor lekel nu pa met ase lanfaz e ki mo pu introdir dan kumansman-mem mo diskur. Me, mo pu revinn lor la apre.

input: I think that the party, in particular, (and I want to talk more about this at the end of the talk), has to prepare itself psychologically.
target: Mo panse ki enn parti bizen prepar li sikolozikman pu sa moman-la.

input: I mean that it prepares itself not just theoretically, in terms of looking at its objectives, its analysis of the situation, but also in terms of the psychology of its militants.
target: Kan pe koz preparasyon mo pa pe koz zis ki parti bizen prepare teorikman, anterm so bann lobzektif, so analiz sityasyon, me usi prepar so militan sikolozikman pu sanz vites.

input: Party militants need to realize that they are looking, throughout the period, at a historical period that will test their energy, their adaptability, the speed with which they respond;
target: Militan parti bizen realize ki nu pe anbark dan enn peryod istorik kot tutolong sa peryod-la, so landirans, so kapasite pu adapte, pu sanz vites, pu aprann, aprann dan nuvo fason, nuvo fason pu fer kitsoz.

input: their preparedness, basically, to come to terms with the fact that there are new ways of learning, there are new ways of doing things, and that inasmuch as it is important that we go through the crisis with all the preparation that is needed, it is also very important that we understand that crises are very new situations, and they require new kinds of energies.
target: Kumsa nu pu dan enn pozisyon pu rant dan perod kriz avek otan preparasyon neseser. Li inportan ki nu realize ki enn kriz li prodir enn nuvo sityasyon ki exziz nuvo kalite lenerzi.

input: In fact, the biggest problem in crises has tended to be the political parties of the working class.
target: Anfet, pli gran problem dan enn lepok kriz se bann parti politik.

input: And I’m not talking about political parties which are reformist, those that are abandoning the working class.
target: Isi mo pa pe koz bann parti politik reformist, bann ki pe abandonn klas travayer.

input: Those are immaterial to this issue.
target: Bann parti reformist pa relevennt dan sa kontex-la.

input: But I’m talking about the difficulties that the revolutionary parties have in coming to terms with the need for a shift in their own psychology.
target: Isi, mo pe koz lor difikilte ki militan parti revolisyoner ena pu fer fas a shift ki neseser dan zot prop sikolozi.

input: Not in their parties’ analyses – because they spend a long time preparing their politics, reading about and grounding themselves; but it’s the shift in the psychology that’s necessary during crises, because of the way a whole new tempo of struggle develops, the way in which things are posed differently.
target: Sa pena pu fer avek analiz zot parti parski zot finn pran buku letan pu prepar zot politik, zot program, lir buku e konpran; me li sirtu konsern sanzman sikolizik ki neseser dan lepok kriz, presizeman akoz ena enn lot tempo, presizeman parski kriz exziz enn diferan manyer zoz ek ziz evennman.

input: We know that the biggest fight in the Russian Revolution was fought within the Central Committee of the Bolshevik Party.
target: Nu kone ki pli gran “lager” dan Revolisyon Ris ti alinteryer Komite Santral Parti Bolshevik.

input: It was about whether: should we move with the mass, should we slow the mass down, what should we do?
target: Li ti lor eski parti pu buz avek lamas, ubyen eski pu ralanti lamas, setadir ki pu bizen fer?

input: As luck has it, the Russians resolved that problem, and they managed to catch up with the mass and move in step with it.
target: Avek lasans, bann revolisyoner Ris ti resi rezud sa problem-la. Zot resi ratrap lamas e buz ansam avek li.

input: The Communist party of Germany, the KPD, on the other hand, faced the same problem, and was killed by its paralysis in the face of major shifts within the working class.
target: Par kont, kan Parti Kominis Alman ena pu fer fas mem problem, li ti paralize kan lamas pe galup divan tro vit.

input: So I think these two points are a kind of preface to our discussion: much as we are talking about the problems facing the working class in crises, it is important that we be mindful of the fact that we are talking about potentially exciting political periods.
target: Alor seki mo pe dir li kumsidire enn prefas: kan nu pe koz defi divan klas travayer dan lepok kriz, nu bizen konsyan ki pe koz enn lepok ki osi potansyelman byen pasyonan.

input: If you are a social justice activist, if you are for socialism, crises are exciting periods where new energies are unleashed.
target: Si u kwar dan zistis sosyal, si u anfaver sosyalism, lepok kriz li enn moman intans ki zener nuvo lenerzi.

input: All the tiredness of meeting after meeting evaporates, and new energies are released.
target: Ena liberasyon inkrwayab lenerzi, kreativite. Lurder dan bann renyon fonn, nuvo lenerzi libere.

input: Crisis of expectations among all classes.
target: Kriz-la vinn bulvers tu atant dan tu klas.

input: Now, the importance of a crisis and why it has to be treated as a special situation is certainly that the crisis represents a very profound change for all sections of society.
target: Lenportans enn kriz, e rezon kifer bizen tret li kuma enn sityasyon exsepsyonel, se ki enn kriz li reprezant enn sanzman profon pu tu diferan seksyon dan sosyete.

input: The second thing is a point Ram has already made in his introduction; around this concept of understanding this new totality of things affected.
target: Dezyem zafer se anfet enn pwen ki Ram ti fer dan so introdiksyon; otur sa konsep pu konpran nuvo “totalite kitsoz afekte”.

input: That is, that an economic crisis affects everything as a totality.
target: Setadir kimanyer enn kriz ekonomik li afekte tu dan so totalite.

input: Usually, when not in times of crisis, in our normal everyday life, our very lives get compartmentalized by the way capitalism functions and the way capitalism is institutionalised: We go to “work”, come back, and then we close the door.
target: Normalman, dan enn peryod kot pena kriz, nu lavi ordiner tulezur li konpartimantalize dapre manyer ki sistem kapitalist fonksyone e dapre manyer ki kapitalism institisyonalize. Nu al “travay”, nu return lakaz, e lerla nu ferm laport.

input: Then when we go out, and later close another door, and then we go to “associations” that we are in, a sport club or something like that.
target: Apre, nu sorti, nu ferm enn lot laport enn lot konpartiman, nu al dan nu “lasosyasyon” dan lekel nu mam, li kapav enn klib spor ubyen kiksoz kumsa.

input: The fact is that all these compartments, behind our backs, so to speak, are related, are connected to each other, in quite fundamental and interesting ways.
target: Me tu sa bann konpartiman la zot inter-konekte enn dan lot, dan enn fason koze deryer nu ledo, dan bann relasyon fondamantal ek interesan.

input: During a crisis, all these connections suddenly become visible.
target: Pandan enn kriz, tu sa bann inter-koneksyon expoze, tu sa bann relasyon vinn vizib.

input: What were issues that were hidden from us, because we made assumptions about our pensions, for example, or we made assumptions about our relations to our partners, we made assumptions about all kinds of things.
