target: Ki ti realite ki pa ti vizib kan nu ti atann, par ekzamp, ki nu pu normalman tus nu pansyon kan nu gayn 60 an, ubyen kan nu ti ena tu kalite atant dan nu relasyon avek nu konzwen, ubyen nerport ki lot asompsyon nu ti fer?

input: suddenly what happens is that capitalism as such almost comes to the fore, as it were, in the crisis.
target: Enn sel ku, kan kriz tape, li expoz realite kapitalist ki ti kasyet. Kapitalism vinn anavanplan.
Tu lyen ki ti pe kasyet vinn vizib.

input: Sometimes Parliaments and other powerful institutions are taken up by the crisis.
target: Ena fwa Parlman e lezot institisyon pwisan sibir kriz-la.

input: They can be paralysed by it.
target: Zot kapav paralize par sa kriz-la.

input: Because the connections between these economic and social, these political and cultural issues suddenly become apparent to us.
target: Parski koneksyon ant lekonomi ek le sosyal, ant politik ek kiltirel, enn sel kut vinn kler, vinn vizib pu nu tu truv li.

input: So, the important thing is that, although as a matter of shorthand we talk about an “economic crisis”, we should be mindful of the fact that an economic crisis can never really unfold in one compartment (called “economic”) in society.
target: Alor, li inportan, mem si dan koze nu apel li enn ‘kriz ekonomik’, nu konsyan ki enn kriz ekonomik li pa kapav derul dan enn sel konpartiman (ki apel “ekonomik”) dan sosyete.

input: If it is serious and deep enough – and I think that the crisis that is unfolding in Mauritius is showing signs of being quite deep – then we will have the entirety of society thrown into crisis.
target: Si li enn kriz profon ek grav – e mo panse sa kriz dan Moris pe montre tu siyn ki li pu enn kriz ase grav – lerla savedir ki sosyete an antye pu rant an kriz.

input: So every time we talk about an “economic crisis”, it is important that we are mindful of the fact that the economy is a social relationship, it is not a production of mere “things”, but it is how we relate to society, how the power balance is organised.
target: Alor sak fwa nu koz “kriz ekonomik”, nu bizen konsyan ki lekonomi, li anfet enn relasyon sosyal, li pa zis prodiksyon “kitsoz”, me li anglob tu nu relasyon, tu nu lyen avek sosyete, li kimanyer “balans defors” organize.

input: And that power balance, in strategic terms, is what holds the players in society together.
target: An term stratezik, li sa “balans defors” spesifik ki tini tu akter dan sosyete ansam.

input: When we talk about what Lalit is doing at the moment, with a program of economic alternatives; in order for such a program to be able to respond to the totality of the crisis it cannot be restricted merely to what the bourgeois press understands as the “economy”.
target: Kan nu koz lor seki Lalit pe fer asterla avek so Program pu enn Lekonomi Alternativ, enn tel program, pu ki li kapav risponns a totalite kriz dan so globalite, pa kapav limit li a seki lapres burzwa konpran par “lekonomi”.

input: The bourgeois theorists always try to keep that compartmentalization.
target: Bann ideolog burzwa tultan pe gard sa separasyon, sa konpartimantalizasyon.

input: They say there is a small problem in sugar, textiles is in difficulty, but let’s leave all the other things in place.
target: Zot dir ena inpe problem dan disik, textil an difikilte, me selman anu gard tu lezot kitsoz anplas.

input: By doing that, they are creating areas, almost fortifications, where you cannot challenge them.
target: Kan zot fer sa, zot pe anfet morsle larealite pu ki zot gard serten “sitadel” kot u pa kapav chalenj zot.

input: Now I want to talk a little bit about what constitute the main elements of what we should conceive of or think about, when we talk about an economic program that wants to put an alternative view of society, an alternative approach to resolving the crisis.
target: Asterla mo pu koz enn but lor ki konstitye eleman mazer enn program ekonomik ki viz pu met divan enn vizyon alternativ sosyete, ki viz enn lapros alternativ pu rezud kriz.

input: I’ll go through my points quickly then, and I’ll make a few remarks on some of the issues raised in the Lalit paper and then talk more about some of the general questions of strategy afterwards.
target: Mo pu kumans par prezant mo bann pwen an-gro, e lerla mo pu fer enn-de komanter lor enn-de bann pwen ki Lalit finn suleve, e apre sa mo pu koz lor bann kestyon zeneral konsern stratezi.

input: I think in the first instance, (and this is undertaken in the Lalit paper), we speak of one having to provide a coherent analysis of the economic problems of the country, of the socio-economic structure, of the sources of the crisis.
target: Premye dabor, kuma dan papye Lalit, mo osi mo pe koz an term propoz enn analiz koeran lor problem ekonomik dan pei, lor striktir sosyo-ekonomik, lor lasurs sa kriz-la.

input: In this case you are talking of the crisis in the sugar industry, of the textile industry.
target: Dan sa ka presi Moris la, nu pe koz enn kriz dan lindistri sikriyer, dan sekter textil.

input: More importantly, I think when we are talking about the economy, we are talking about a whole set of class relations.
target: pli inportan, nu pe koz lor lekonomi, setadir nu pe koz lansanb relasyon de klas.

input: The issue is that, in the course of such an analysis, we have to isolate, identify and underline the class relationships that underlie such an economy: how are the various social classes aligned in the way that they make possible the accumulation of capital, which is the primary concern of the capitalists.
target: Pu kapav fer sa analiz-la, nu ena pu izol, idantifye e suliyn relasyon de klas ki ena andan dan lekonomi. Kimanyer, dan ki fason diferan klas sosyal aliyn zotmem pu rann li posib akimil kapital, ki, apre tu, se preokipasyon prinsipal bann kapitalist?

input: In other words, to provide a criticism of political economy. Political economy is not about just production; it is about the class relations that underpin it.
target: Andotmo nu pe propoz enn kritik lor lekonomi politik. Lekonomi politik li pa inikman konsern prodiksyon; li konsern osi relasyon de klas ki tini prodiksyon.

input: Classes and strata to defend the program.
target: Klas ek kus ki pu defann sa program.

input: The second issue is that such a program has to quite clearly identify for us the classes that underpin this whole program of the revolutionary party.
target: Dezyem kestyon ki Program-la bizen adrese se li bizen idantifye byen klerman ki bann klas ki pu tini sa program-la an antye.

input: In other words, a program cannot be an appeal to society in general.
target: Enn lot fason met li, enn program li pa kapav fer apel a sosyete an zeneral.

input: We have to try and make clear who does this program speak to?
target: Mo pu revinn lor sa pwen plitar. Nu bizen etablir klerman “a kisannla sa program-la adrese”?

input: Which are the class forces that have got to be there to defend this program, that are going to go out on to the streets and fight for it, and if necessary, are going to put up the barricades to defend this particular program?
target: Ki bann lafors deklas ki pu dibut pu defann enn tel program, ki lafors deklas pu pare pu desann dan lari deryer sa program-la, ek si neseser, pare pu met barikad pu defann enn tel program.

input: So our analysis must reveal these classes.
target: Alor nu analiz bizen devwal sa bann klas-la.

input: Now generally we say socialism is presumed to be in the interests of the working class.
target: Suvan nu dir sosyalism li dan lintere klas travayer.

input: And it is important for the way that we conduct our struggle.
target: E li inportan pu fason nu pu amenn nu lalit.

input: But at different moments in history, at different times and in different places, different sections of the working class, different strata within the middle classes, or within the peasantry, these different strata and sections, constitute almost what are advanced or leading sectors within a struggle for change.
target: Me dan diferan moman dan listwar, dan diferan lepok, dan diferan plas, diferan seksyon klas travayer, diferan kus dan klas mwayenn, ubyen dan peizannri, sa bann seksyon ek kus, vinn lavangard dan lalit pu sanzman.

input: What is important here is that while the proposition that the program rests on the working class as a whole is true, (which is of crucial importance because in the struggle it is in the interests of the class as a whole that concern us), in our analysis we need to see how the different strata within the working class are aligned;
target: Li inportan isi ki nu kler ki enn tel program li repoz lor klas travayer.

input: and in what way can we therefore say what sections we expect to move in the direction of our program.
target: e li lentere klas travayer an antye ki konsern nu, kan nu pe koz program.

input: So we need to identify the social classes and the strata within the society that constitute the social basis of our programme.
target: Me selman, pu nu analiz, nu bizen konpran kimanyer bann diferan seksyon, diferan kus dan klas travayer, aliyn zot mem.

input: Who then are the primary social forces that will defend this program, but also who will be other allies around this program?
target: Ki bann lafors sosyal prinsipal ki pu defann sa program-la, me osi, nu bizen gete ki bann lezot alye ki pu ena otur enn tel program?

input: Which are the other classes that we must speak to?
target: Ki bann lezot klas nu bizen konvenk?

input: Must our program speak to the small producer?
target: Eski nu program bizen konvenk bann ti prodikter?

input: Must our program speak to the small petty bourgeoisie?
target: Eski nu program pu sey ralye tit-burzwazi?

input: Or does our program only speak to the worker, who is exploited in particular ways in the course of the production process?
target: Ubyen, eski nu program bizen adres li zis a klas travayer, ki sibir explwatasyon dan prosesis prodiksyon antan ki travayer?

input: Is there a peasantry in our country?
target: Eski ena enn peizannri dan nu pei?

input: And does our program speak to the peasantry?
target: Si ena enn peizannri, eski nu program pe adres li a peizannri?

input: What about the attitudes of the intelligentsia?
In other words we must have an analysis of the totality of social classes, and of where our program is positioned relative to these social classes.
target: Setadir, nu bizen ena enn analiz de tu bann klas dan sosyete. E kimanyer nu program pozisyonn li par rapor a sakenn sa bann klas-la.

input: Is the bourgeoisie’s block breaking up.
Another thing, of course, is that a crisis is a shake-up in the relations of the entire society.
target: Byen sir enn kriz li enn bulversman dan relasyon dan sosyete an antye.

input: Now as socialists sometimes we tend not to pay a lot of attention to the bourgeoisie – except in terms of how its actions affect us negatively.
target: An tan ki sosyalist, ena fwa nu ena tandans pa pran burzwazi kont kuma bizen – apar kan so azisman fer nu ditor.

input: For questions of strategy, it is quite crucial that we begin to look a little more closely at how is the hegemonic block organized.
target: Pu rezon stratezik, li neseser ki nu konpran exakteman kimanyer blok ezemonik konstitye.

input: The ruling class might be just the bourgeoisie proper.
target: Klas dirizan parfwa li zis burzwazi kom tel.

input: Again we will find that when we talk about Mauritius, there is an understanding that given all the sections of the ruling class, the bourgeoisie proper, there are certain strata which are quite dominant in there i.e. within the bourgeoisie.
target: Nu pu truve kan nu pe koz Moris, ena enn serten lakorite ki parmi tu seksyon klas dirizan, setadir burzwazi limem, ena serten seksyon ki vreman dominan ladan.

input: These ones determine its structure, political culture, even determine its habits, habits of how it responds to things, how it does things and in that sense, its political culture.
target: Se sa seksyon-la ki pu determinn so striktir e mem determinn so labitid, kimanyer li reazir, kimanyer li azir, e dan sa sans-la, determinn so kiltir politik.

input: This gives us an understanding of the internal configuration of the bourgeoisie as a class, as well as the relationship it has with other sections of society.
target: Sa ed nu pu konpran konfigirasyon intern andan burzwazi kuma enn klas, so striktir osi byen ki so relasyon avek lezot seksyon sosyete.

input: The bourgeoisie never really rules alone.
It’s too isolated to rule alone.
target: Li pu tro izole si le reyne tusel.

input: It normally rules in blocks of alliances with other classes.
target: Alor normalman li reyne atraver enn blok bann diferan lalyans avek lezot klas.

input: Either Labour can make up one such block.
target: Swa “Travay” kapav konstititye enn tel blok avek burzwazi.

input: Organized Labour sometimes, in other countries, enters into an alliance, supports the party of the bourgeoisie.
target: Klas travayer organize ena fwa, dan ena pei nu finn truv li, rant dan lalyans pu sutenir parti burzwazi.

input: Sometimes the peasantry, sometimes other different sections of society which do not belong to the bourgeoisie join its ruling block.
target: Ena peizannri, ena fwa lezot seksyon dan sosyete ki pa apartenir a burzwazi, zwenn blok dirizan.

input: It is important that a program understands the way the ruling block is constituted, and the place of the bourgeoisie within that block.
target: Li inportan ki enn program konpran kisannla konstitye “blok dirizan”, e ki plas burzwazi ena dan sa blok-la.

input: Power relations that will need to change.
Now we will look briefly at the changes within the political power relations that are necessary for a program to be realized.
target: Nu pu get ki sanzman a-lenteryer rapor defors politik ki neseser pu ki program-la vinn vre.

input: Sometimes there’s a call, “Let’s get together, let’s put a program together, a set of demands that we will draw up together,” but what we need to ask also is what assumptions are we making about the nature of the power relations that need to be changed in order for these demands to be realized.
target: Ena fwa, ena enn lapel, “Anu zwenn ansam, anu fer enn program, ansam dres enn seri demand”. Me nu bizen konsyan osi ki kalite asompsyon nu pe fer lor nesesite pu rapor defors sanze pu ki nu bann demand-la vinn vre.

input: Now trade unions, in many instances, for historical reasons, they sometimes suffer from the problem that they imagine that they can achieve demands without any changes in the power relations.
target: Zordi, bann sendika dan buku ka, pu bann rezon istorik, zot fer erer kwar ki zot kapav gayn zot bann demand san sanz okenn balans de fors, san sanz relasyon puvwar.

input: I know that South African trade unions get very aggrieved when their demands are ignored. Because their analysis does not try to look at what kinds of changes in power relations are necessary in order for their program to be realized.
target: Mo kapav dir ki dan Sid Afrik, sindika byen ofanse kan pa pran zot revandikasyon kont.

input: Sometimes unions go into blocks and alliances without a clear understanding of what this is all about, and it tends, as someone has put it, to all end in tears.
target: Parski zot analiz pa amenn zot adres kestyon balans defors ki neseser pu satisfer zot demand. Ena fwa sindika fer blok, regrupe dan bann fron san byen konpran seki zot pe fer e byen suvan sa fini an larm.

input: Because you hit against this wall.
target: Li fini an larm parski u pe anfet tap kont sa miray apel balans defors-la.

input: So, it is important to understand the changes necessary in power relations, implied by a program.
target: Alor li byen inportan nu konpran exakteman ki sanzman dan relasyon puvwar ki pu neseser pu tini enn tel program.

input: The practical measures must be discussed also: what practical measures are we talking about.
target: Bann mezir pratik usi bizen diskite. Ki kalite aksyon nu pe fer referans?

input: And lastly, this program must spell out a political strategy of mobilization.
target: E dernyerman, program-la bizen donn detay ki stratezi politik pu mobilizasyon.

input: Because an economic program becomes a shopping list, if it is not underwritten by a concept of how political mobilization is necessary to make it realizable.
target: Parski enn program ekonomik vinn enn “karne rasyon” si li pa baze lor lefet ki mobilizasyon politik neseser pu met sa program-la an pratik.

input: The program must include the development of such a political strategy, and it must identify the forces that are going to move that strategy forward.
target: Program bizen inklir devlopman enn tel stratezi politik, e li bizen kler ki bann lafors sosyal pu buz sa stratezi divan.

input: Without that, what we clearly have is not a program but a shopping list.
target: San sa, li pa enn program me zis enn plan.

input: We find that within a lot of working class forces, like trade unions, they imagine that it is just enough to have a list of demands, without spelling out a strategy for their realization.
target: Nu truv sa byen suvan repete dan lorganizasyon klas travayer kuma sindika. Zot panse ki li sifi pu dres enn lalis demand, san donn detay ki stratezi neseser pu fer enn tel program vinn vre.

input: Now by way of illustration, I will just make one or two points, to update what we understand as important considerations in the way we develop, and discuss and refine our program.
target: Alor pu ilistre, mo pu pran enn-de pwen, pu rafinn seki nu truv inportan dan manyer ki nu devlop, diskit, pofinn nu program ki anglob lekonomi dan so antye.

input: I’ve taken these observations on the program to look at, although clearly much more discussion has already taken place in Lalit around statements in the program.
target: Mo finn pran sa bann obzervasyon dan program Lalit pu nu gete ansam, mem si mo kone finn ena buku deba deza dan Lalit otur sak pwen dan sa program-la.

input: Showing the centrality of sugar and textiles.
target: Nesesite demontre Rol Santral Disik ek Textil.

input: The first thing, by way of example, is to open up discussion about the need for the program of the party or the movement to make clear the centrality and importance of sugar and textiles in Mauritius.
target: Dabor bizen ena deba lor nesesite pu Program-la, ki li pu parti-la ubyen enn muvman pli larz, rann li byen kler pu tu dimunn ziska ki pwen Disik e Textil ena enn rol inportan dan Moris.

input: There are historical reasons for the position of sugar in the economy and so on.
target: Ena bann rezon istorik ki explik pozisyon disik okipe dan lekonomi.

input: The challenge, and what we need to demonstrate, is how they relate to other strata in society, and to demonstrate that the crisis of the sugar industry and textile industry constitutes a crisis of Mauritian society as a whole.
target: Defi ki ena e seki nu bizen demontre, se kimanyer disik ek textil zot liye ar lezot kus dan sosyete. Bizen montre kimanyer kriz dan lindistri sikriyer ek textil konstitye enn kriz dan sosyete Moris an antye.

input: Now this is not always self-evident.

Especially in the light of the fact that bourgeois ideologues like to defend their project by saying, for example in South Africa, “Don’t be ridiculous, the textile sector has been under assault for the past 10 years.”
target: Sirtu ki bann ideolog burzwa tultan pe defann zot proze. Par exanp, dan Sid Afrik, u pu tann zot reponn, par examp, “Ase badine, pena naryen nuvo, sekter textil tultan an kriz depi dernye 10 an!”

input: They say, “Our textile sector is just not competitive enough; we should move towards other competitive sectors, IT, we should do something or something else.”
target: Ubyin zot pu dir, “Nu sekter textil pa ase konpetitif, nu bizen buz ver lezot sekter pli konpetitif kuma IT; nu bizen buz ver lezot sekter”.

input: It becomes imperative for us to demonstrate that the organic relationships within the Mauritian economy are of such a nature that the crisis of sugar and textiles is a crisis of the Mauritian economy.
target: Li esansyel pu nu pruve kimanyer natir relasyon organik alinteryer lekonomi Moris li tel ki kriz dan disik ek textil vedir kriz lekonomi Moris antye.

input: It’s not a crisis of a part of the Mauritian economy; it is not because we want to deal with the special interests, and the special problems of a section of the working class. What we are observing, what we are looking at, is an unfolding generalized crisis.
target: Sa kriz-la li pa enn kriz enn but lekonomi Moris; li pa nonpli akoz nu ule get zintere partikiliye ek problem spesifik enn seksyon partikilye dan klas travayer.

input: Therefore an analysis of the position of these industries, and their interconnections with other industries becomes quite crucial, and needs to be made a much more visible part of our program.
target: Me seki nu pe obzerve, seki nu pe truve divan nu, se enn kriz zeneralize ki pe deferle. Donk enn analiz lyen sekter disik ek sekter textil ar lezot sekter vinn krisyal. E sa analiz-la bizen byen pli evidan dan nu program.

input: Also what is crucial, is that equally from the side of the bourgeoisie in Mauritius, if the crisis of the sugar industry is the crisis of the rest of the bourgeoisie, then we can expect that we are dealing not with the responses of the sugar oligarchy or the textile bosses, but we are dealing with the responses of the entire bourgeoisie.
target: Li osi krisyal pu nu konpran ki si kriz lindistri sikriyer vedir kriz leres burzwazi Mors, lerla nu kapav atann ki nu interese pa zis ek risponns oligarsi sikriye ubyen patron textil, me risponns depi burzwazi an antye.

input: Now the crucial point about this here is that when the bourgeoisie responds to crisis, obviously each section responds in ways that are consistent with its own interests.
target: Pwin inportan isi se ki, kan burzwazi reazir a kriz, li kler ki sak seksyon burzwazi pu reazir pu defann lintere so prop sekter.

input: Now, in the main, the bourgeois parties are not in the habit of acting collectively.
target: An gro, bann parti politik burzwazi pena labitid azir kolektivman.

input: It is in their own nature to act for their particular interests, unless they are forced by the development of the class struggle to act in the interests of other classes.
target: Li dan zot natir pu azir pu zot prop lintere partikilye, omwen devlopman lalit de klas fors zot azir dan lintere lezot klas.

input: So this analysis becomes quite crucial; for instance, analysis of the bourgeoisie in its relationship to other classes with which it has ruled as a block.
target: Donk li vinn krisyal pu analize, par ekzanp, ki relasyon burzwazi ena ar lezot klas avek lekel li finn reyne kuma enn blok ziska ler.

input: Will the small planters stay in ruling block?
target: Eski planter pu res dan blok dirizan?

input: Now, it would be instructive to look at the evolution of Mauritian society and the sugar oligarchy.
target: Li pu vo lapenn get evolisyon sosyete Moris ek oligarsi sikriye.

input: An important political block that has reproduced the hegemony of the sugar bosses is the relationship the bourgeoisie has had with small planters: the small petty bourgeoisie in agriculture.
target: Enn blok politik inportan ki finn reprodir ezemoni disik, li finn evolye atraver relasyon ki burzwazi finn ena avek ti planter, setadir tit-burzwazi agrikol.

input: That is quite a crucial relationship, because it must now face the crisis of this industry.
target: Sa li enn relasyon kle parski aster li pe bizen fer fas evolisyon dan sa lindistri-la.

input: The critical point in history was when the organizations of this stratum, this class of small planters, staked its claim on the sugar industry, and reached an accommodation with the sugar oligarchy.
target: Enn moman kritik dan listwar ti kan bann lorganizasyon sa kus sosyete-la, sa klas ti-planter, finn met divan zot demand a lindistri sikriyer, e zot truv enn terin dantant avek oligarsi sikriye.

input: This accommodation allowed the sugar oligarchy to continue exercising its hegemony in the post-independence period.
target: Se sa terin dantant ki finn permet oligarsi sikriye kontiyn exers so ezemoni pandan peryod post-lindepandans.

input: Now, this particular issue, therefore, needs to be developed in an understanding of the way the crisis unfolds.
target: Donk, bizen devlop nu konpreansyon sa relasyon deklas la amezir nu konpran manyer kriz la pe deferle.

input: The fundamental question we need to ask is whether the crisis is re-organizing the historical block, or whether the historical block will be left unchanged.
target: Kestyon fondamantal ki nu bizen poze se eski kriz-la pe re-organiz sa blok istorik-la? Ubyin eski blok istorik-la pu res intak?

input: In other words, what will be the basis of the political hegemony of the sugar bosses in this country?
target: Andotmo, ki pu subasman ezemoni politik patrona disik dan pei?

input: Up to now, it has exercised it through partnerships with the historical working class, through the Labour Party, which in the analysis of Lalit’s paper, was seen to have been taken over by the small planters.
target: Ziska ler zot finn exers zot ezemoni anpartnarya avek klas travayer istorik, atraver Parti Travayis, ki dapre analiz Lalit, ti’nn vinn su kontrol ti-planter.

input: Now that was a crucial political moment which allowed the production of a particular form of class rule in which the sugar bosses were able to extract all kinds of concessions that it did.
target: Sa ti enn moman politik desizif ki finn etablir enn form partikilye enn reyn de klas kot patrona disik ti kapav extrer tu kalite konsesyon, ki dayer li finn fer.

input: I think, just to tie up this section, many of us are aware that, as this crisis begins to make itself felt, there are already underfoot within the bourgeoisie attempts to preserve the hegemonic block under new conditions.
target: Buku dant nu konsyan ki, amezir sa kriz-la pe morde, ena tantativ deza amars alenteryer burzwazi pu sey prezerv sa blok ezemonik su nuvo kondisyon.

input: For example, we know that the State has started to act.
target: Par exanp, nu kone Leta fini kumans azir.

input: With the impending collapse of the sugar industry, it has already tried to put aside money, to lock the small planters into some ongoing relationship with the sugar barons particularly.
target: Avek menas kolaps lindistri sikriyer, li finn deza sey met lamone dekote pu amar ti planter dan enn relasyon kontini ar baron sikriye.

input: We can see here how the state is underwriting the infrastructure of the small producer in the face of the impending crisis - and I think that people in Mauritius have commented on the absurdities of this arrangement whereby the State is going to pay money to bring into cane cultivation more land, to de-rock these areas, and all other kinds of actions kind.
target: Nu kapav truve isi, e dimunn Moris finn komant lor la, absirdite sa laranzman-la, kot fas-a kriz ki pe menase, Leta pe depans kas pu met plis later su kiltir kann, pu fer diroking e pu fer lezot kalite aksyon, ki pu donn garanti infrastriktir ti-prodikter fas a kriz.

input: Now it is quite clear that, if you leave aside the immediate economic interest of certain sections of the people as you interpret their needs, it is quite clear that there is also an attempt here to preserve the hegemonic block in a particular way.
target: Si nu met dekote lintere ekonomik imedya serten seksyon popilasyon amezir nu interpret zot bezwin, li ase kler ki ena osi enn tantativ pu prezerv blok ezemonik dan enn fason presi.

input: Whether they preserve it or not, is going to be a matter for history to tell, as the crisis unfolds.
target: Eski zot pe prezerv li u pa, sa se listwar ki pu dir, amezir kriz-la deferle.

input: But I think just as an illustration of how there are attempts to preserve this block, and for us, as a Left party, we need to understand and to analyze these attempts.
target: Me, parey kuma nu pe get kimanyer ena tantativ pu prezerv sa blok-la, pu nu, antan ki enn parti de gos, nu bizen konpran ek analiz sa tantativ-la.

input: And of course with the intention of intervening in the way that block either fractures or is able to be maintained.
target: E byensir, avek lintansyon pu intervenir dan manyer ki sa blok-la swa kase swa mintenir limem kuma enn blok.

input: Restructuring of dominated classes under crisis.
And of course, equally important is an analysis of how is the crisis re-structuring the dominated classes.
target: Seki egalman inportan se pu analiz manyer kriz-la restriktir bann klas oprime.

input: The working class is not always “the” working class.
target: Klas travayer li pa tultan “la” klas travayer ki nu kone zordi isi.

input: It does not always exist nor is it preserved in exactly the same form as it has been in the past.
target: Li pa tultan existe dan enn sel form ni li pa res exakteman tel ki li ti ete dan lepase.

input: It changes with changes in the development of capitalism.
target: Li sanze avek sanzman dan devloplman kapitalism.

input: It changes with the development of new sectors of production.
target: Li sanze avek devlopman nuvo sekter prodiksyon.

input: It changes as old sectors close, new sectors emerge.
target: Li sanze amezir ansyen sekter ferme, nuvo sekter emerze.

input: And those sectors might not be organized or structured in a way that they used to be in the old sectors.
target: E sa bann sekter-la kapav pa organize ubyen striktire dan mem fason ki dan ansyen sekter.

input: They might have a very different relationship to the bourgeoisie.
target: Zot kapav ena enn relasyon byin diferan ar burzwazi.

input: And therefore a concrete analysis of how the crisis is re-organizing the social weight of the different sections of the working class and the implications that this has for strategy, for the forms of organizing, for the kinds of traditional practices that we have inherited from past instances of struggle.
target: Donk enn analiz lor kimanyer kriz-la pe re-organiz pwa sosyal diferan seksyon klas travayer, ek inplikasyon ki sa ena lor stratezi, lor form lorganizasyon, lor kalite protokol tradisyonel ki nu finn erite depi bann lalit avan.

input: This is an important exercise for the party to undertake.
target: Sa li enn travay inportan ki Parti ena pu fer.
Stratezi Parti ek diferan kalite Kriz.

input: I would now like to talk about some of the considerations in the development of working class strategy, of the strategy of the political party in times of economic crisis.
target: Mo ti pu kontan koz lor serten pwen ki bizen gard antet kan pe devlop enn stratezi pu klas travayer, kan pe devlop stratezi le parti dan lepok kriz ekonomik.

input: I would like to begin by saying that it’s common sense - and it’s true and valid - that we think of the crisis as a “problem”.
target: Li lozik, ek li tutafe vre, pu truv kriz-la kuma enn “problem”.

input: And the crisis is a problem.

target: Dimunn ena pu fer fas tu kalite difikilte.

input: But from the view of the capitalist system as a whole it is not “a bad thing” or an “alien phenomenon”, so to speak.
target: Me depwendevi sistem kapitalis, kriz-la pa enn “move zafer”, uswa kit “drol fenomenn”.

input: It is important for us to understand that under capitalism, crisis also occupies a very different place.
target: Li inportan pu nu konpran ki su reyn kapitalism, kriz ena enn lot sinifikasyon.

input: For capitalism, crisis is also a way in which the system self-regulates.
target: Pu kapitalism, kriz li osi enn kalite oto-reglaz dan sistem-la.

input: It is the necessary “oil” that facilitates the working of the system.
target: Li kuma sa dilwil ki fer masinnri sistem la rul byen.

input: It even cleanses the system of old or antiquated sectors, propels the development of new sectors and technologies.
target: Li mem netway vye sekter perime, ek li pus ver devlopman nuvo sekter ek nuvo teknolozi.

input: Crisis, in the words of one historian of economic ideas, represents capitalism’s moment of “creative destruction”.
target: Kuma enn istoryen lide ekonomik ti dir, “kriz” reprezant kapitalism so moman “destriksyon kreatif”.

input: As Marx said, capitalism is a kind of anarchy.
target: Marx ti dekrir kapitalism kuma enn espes anarsi.

input: All the various producers do not consult each other about how much they are going to produce, they do not consult each other about what they produce, when they will produce it, where they are planning to sell it to.
target: Tu bann diferan prodikter na pa kordine avek lezot prodikter pu kalkile ki kantite pu prodwir, ki pu prodwir, kan pu prodwir li, ar kisann-la pu vann seki zot pu prodwir.

input: In other words, they plan their own production very carefully within their enterprise, through the most sophisticated planning systems.
target: Alor zot planifye zot prodiksyon minisyezman dan zot lantrepriz atraver bann sistem planifikasyon byen sofistike.

input: And then, in society, these individual plans are integrated in an anarchic fashion.
target: Lerla, dan lasosyete, sakenn sa bann plan prodiksyon la integre enn dan lot avek lezot plan prodiksyon dan enn fason anarsik.

input: In other words, you throw your shoes into the market, and then you wait and see what happens.
target: Kumadir pe avoy sulye ki u finn prodir lor marse lerla atann, gete ki pu arive.

input: If you sell them fine, if not, bad luck and you go somewhere else.
target: Si li reysi vande, byen bon.

input: Then you cut your losses, look for something else to do, or for another market.
target: Lerla aksepte lapert, rod lot zafer pu fer, uswa rod enn lot marse.

input: Now, the point is that Capitalism, because of this anarchy, has to continually re-establish its balance.
target: Pwin ki mo pe fer, seki kapitalism ena pu retablir so balans sak ler akoz sa anarsi la.

input: And therefore every so often, even in bourgeois economic literature it has now become accepted that crises are a normal part of capitalism.
target: Alor, detanzantan, mem dan literatir ekonomik burzwa, zot tu aksepte ki kriz li enn zafer normal alinteryer kapitalism.

input: And so in bourgeois economics, when you learn about economics, you learn about the business cycles which means basically an acceptance that it is in the very nature of the capitalist economy to have crises, to have these periodic breakdowns.
target: Kumsa mem ki dan ekonomiks burzwa, kan u pe aprann ekonomiks, u aprann lor bann sik biznes. Seki vedir ki zot admet ki li dan natir lekonomi kapitalis pu ki ena kriz, ki ena sa bann brekdawn la detanzantan.

input: It is also important for us to appreciate these kinds of crises as a mode of self-regulation of the system, because it leads us to ask, as the first point of departure in planning our strategy, as to what kind of economic crisis are we looking at?
target: Li osi inportan ki nu konpran ki sa bann kriz la zot konsidere kuma enn oto- reglaz dan sistem la, parski se kan nu finn konpran sa, ki nu kapav poz sa kestyon ki permet nu prepare pu nu stratezi:  Ki kalite kriz pe deferle?

input: Is this particular crisis one of capitalism’s normal modes of self-reproduction?
target: Eski sa kriz la li enn sa zar kriz ki normalman gayne dan kapitalism kan li pe reprodir limem?

input: Because these modes of self reproduction can be quite useful to it, in the sense that they can allow the closing down of an industry and the opening up of a new industry.
target: Parski ena fwa sa bann kriz la li kapav itil dipwendevi kapitalism dan lesans ki li permet ki ferm enn lindistri ki pa marse, ek uver enn nuvo ki pu marse.

input: This can lead to a major shift in the allocation of labour forces within capitalism as different industrial sectors get reorganized to come out of the crisis period.
target: Sa kapav amenn enn siftaz dan alokasyon mindev alenteryer kapitalism amizir diferan sekter indistriyel re-organize pu sorti depi dan kriz.

input: The question we are asking is, “Is this a crisis of self regulation”?
target: Kestyon ki nu pe poze se:  Eski li enn kriz kot kapitalism pe oto-regle so sistem?

input: In other words, if I borrow from the way Gramsci described it, “Is this crisis conjunctural?”
target: Les mo servi parol Gramsci ki finn poz sa kestyon la byen:  Eski sa kriz la li enn “kriz konzonktirel”?

input: Or is this crisis what Gramsci called “organic”?
target: Uswa eski sa kriz la, li seki Gramsci ti dekrir kuma enn “kriz organik”?

input: In other words it’s got a much deeper historical character, and it goes far beyond the normal modes of self-reproduction of capitalism as a social system.
target: Setadir, li ena enn porte istorik plis profon ek li al buku pli lwen ki oto-reglaz normal dan kapitalism antan ki enn sistem sosyal.

input: Gramsci distinguishes between these two forms of capitalist crisis: Conjunctural or Organic.
target: Gramsci ti fer enn distenksyon ant de kalite kriz kapitalist: kriz konzonktirel ek kriz organik.

input: The conjunctural crisis gives rise to what he called day-to-day criticisms from people.
target: Kriz konzonktirel li formant kritik ki li ti apel kritik “de-zur-an-zur”.

input: In other words, when these problems happen within society we see a focus of the criticism on the political leadership, on the personalities within the political leadership, you know in South Africa we would see this is a case of “mismanagement” of the economy.
target: Setadir ki kan sa kalite problem la arive dan lasosyete, nu truv kritik la santre lor lidersip politik, lor bann personalite dan lidersip politik, e dimunn ena tandans kwar, kuma buku dimunn dir dan Sidafrik, ki la, ena enn lekzanp “maladministrasyon” lekonomi.

input: In other words, the consciousness of the dominated classes discerns between a major crisis and this kind of crisis which is cyclical, leads to a minor realignment within the system, leads to what the bourgeois economists call “frictional unemployment”, when workers move from one sector and they are absorbed into another.
target: Savedir konsyans bann klas ki domine par klas kapitalis konn fer ladiferans ant enn kriz mazer ek so lot kalite kriz ki vini dan enn sik ki amenn enn ti re-aliynman dan sistem la; ki amenn seki ekonomis burzwa apel somaz “frictional” kan travayer buz depi enn sekter ki pe ferme ek rant dan enn lot.

input: So, in such an instance the crisis is conjunctural. (This doesn’t mean that it might not be important.)
target: La, kriz la li konzonktirel. (Sa pa vedir ki li pa inportan).

input: Now discerning between the two types of crisis is important for a political party.
target: Li inportan pu enn parti konpran ladiferans ant sa de kalite kriz la.

input: The second kind of crisis is, of course, of a much more fundamental character.
target: Dezyem kalite kriz, li buku plis fondamantal.

input: Systemic crises, also called “organic” crises, give rise to “socio-historical criticism” (Gramsci), whose subject is a wider social group, and goes beyond the public figures involved and the top leaders.
target: Kriz sistemik, ki osi apel kriz “organik”, li formant kritik sosyo-istorik ki viz enn grup sosyal pli gran, e depas kritik kont de-trwa personalite politik sipa lider.

input: People will no longer say “It’s just Berenger who’s the problem, must replace him with Sithanen, or somebody else”.
target: Dimunn nepli dir koze kuma “Berenger ki problem la. Bizen ranplas li par Sithanen, sipa enn lot”.

input: They begin to discern that this is a much deeper systemic problem that is facing them.
target: Dimunn kumans rekonet ki sa problem la li buku plis profon ek li enn problem sistemik.

input: They begin to realize that all the parties of the bourgeoisie have been unable to do anything.
target: Dimunn kumans realize ki tu parti burzwa pa finn kapav fer nanye.

input: They have been tested, tested over and over again.
target: Finn teste zot tu, enn apre lot, ek nanye pa finn marse.

input: People begin to see that it is the interest of the oligarchic groups that are at stake.
target: Dimunn kumans remarke ki se plito lintere bann grup oligarsik ki ankestyon.

input: And that this group is just greedy.
target: ek ki sa bann grup-la zot rapas.

input: And the criticism begins to swing over from day-to-day problems, from day-to-day concerns with personalities, to a much more historical criticism.
target: Ek kritik ki ena kumans sanze depi kritik “de-zur-an-zur”, kritik kont tel ubyen tel personalite, e li vinn enn kritik buku plis istorik.

input: Crises of that kind may last for extended durations, say, decades.
target: Sa kalite kriz la li kapav dire pandan lontan, kapav mem plizyer deseni.

input: This is important when we are organizing on the grounds of an organic crisis; we need to gauge the tempo and the synchronization of that crisis.
target: Sa li inportan kan nu pe organize kan enn enn kriz organik; nu ena pu ziz vites kriz la e kimanyer li sinkronize.

input: The important issue is that the fairly extended period of the crisis can pass through periods of calm, where things appear to have been resolved, and then problems start up again.
target: Seki inportan ladan se ki sa bann moman kriz ki kapav al long, etann lor letan, zot kapav travers sertin moman kot ena akalmi. Tu paret kumadir finn rezud, lerla ep, ala problem refer sirfas.

input: But the fact that it is of exceptional duration means that incurable structural contradictions have revealed themselves, reached their maturity.
target: Me lefet ki kriz la li kontinye lor enn peryod letan eksepsyonelman long, li vedir ki bann kontradiksyon striktirel inkirab dan sistem la vinn expoze divan lizye tu dimunn. E li finn mir.

input: Here it is important for us to establish as a point of departure whether our analysis is suggesting that the crisis is of a conjunctural or more systemic kind.
target: Li inportan ki nu etablir dabor sipa nu analiz pe dir ki kriz-la li konzktirel uswa li sistemik.

input: This is because there is a whole range of implications for strategy.
target: Li inportan parski sa pu ena enn seri inplikasyon lor nu stratezi.

input: Now, how will we establish if the crisis is conjunctural or systemic?
target: Kuma nu kone sipa kriz la li konzonktirel uswa sistemik?

input: Firstly, for me, it is a question of dialectics, so to speak.
target: Premyerman, pu mwa, li kumadir enn konbinezon dyalektik.

input: On the one hand, there is the mass work of the party, and this is quite fundamental.
target: Enn kote, li depann lor travay de mas parti, ek sa, li fondamantal.
Lot kote, li depann lor travay teorik.

input: The party cannot establish, a priori, while sitting in a room having discussions that a crisis is systemic or isn’t - just through theoretical analysis or its critique of the political economy.
target: Parti la ni pa kapav deside ki kalite kriz li ete par zis asiz dan enn lasal e baz li pirman lor analiz teorik, uswa lor kritik lekonomi politik.

input: Nor can it do so by only doing mass work.
target: Ni li pa kapav zis fye lor travay de mas tusel.

input: Of course, even there, there is another dialectic - of the party’s own interaction with the masses.
target: Byin sir, mem la, ena enn lot dyalektik ki rant ladan: parti so lyin avek lamas.

input: The party doesn’t just act like political scientists do, read up, and then go home to supper.
target: Parti, li pa azir kuma syantis politik fer: etidye enn-de liv lerla al lakaz.
Parti, li fer travay de mas.

input: In its mass work, it promotes perspectives of the world; it helps promote the ideology of socialism, discerns the immediate interests of the working class, and imposes on the agenda for debate the kinds of issues that the earlier sessions spoke about.
target: Dan so travay de mas, li kontribiye dan donn dimunn diferan fason pu get lemond. Li kontribiye pu promuvwar ideolozi sosyalis. Li ena kapasite pu truv lintere imedya klas travayer, ek li met lor azanda pu deba tu sa bann diferan tem ki nu finn tande dan bann sesyon avan.

input: On the one hand we have dealt with the important element of establishing and confirming the validity of our analysis that the crisis is deeper than usual, that people feel it is deeper than usual.
target: Enn kote, nu finn get sa pwin inportan pu etablir ek konfirm validite nu analiz ki kriz la plis profon ki dabitid, ek ki anmemtan dimunn santi ki li pli profon ki dabitid.
Nu ena pu demontre sa osi.

input: On the other hand, of course, the party has inherited a whole period of work and a whole set of tools of analysis, with which to analyze the evolution of social classes in society, and the place of different industries within that society, and the importance of the fractures taking place in the sugar industry, and the processes going on in tourism.
target: De lot kote, byin sir, Lalit, antan ki Parti, ena enn long leritaz travay ki li finn fer lor enn seri lane ek li finn devlop enn seri zuti danaliz pu kapav konpran evolisyon diferan klas sosyal dan lasosyete, ek konpran rol diferan sekter dan sa sosyete-la, ek analiz linportans sa fraktir dan lindistri sikriyer, mitasyon dan turism.

input: That analysis is then brought together with this process of mass work, and this abstracting of the interpretive diagnosis going on within the working class. In this way the party, through this historical process of testing, is able to establish the peculiar character of the crisis.
target: Sa analiz la, kan met li ansam avek travay de mas ek sa manyer ki dan Parti nu kapav konseptyaliz dyagnoz ek interpretasyon de kifer pe ena sa kriz-la dan klas travayer, kumsa mem ki nu kapav etablir natir partikilye sa kriz la, par sa prosesis istorik pu teste.

input: It is on these grounds that it will design its strategies in the long run.
target: Li lor sa baz la ki Parti konseptyaliz so bann stratezi a-lon-term.

input: It goes without saying that once an organic crisis begins to unfold, its form of existence is a series of conjunctural crises.
target: Natirelman, enn fwa enn kriz organik finn kumans deferle, form ki li pran se enn seri kriz konzonktirel.

input: I think in South Africa, from our own experience, South African society, in general, experienced a very profound historical crisis, which first broke out visibly at the end of the 1960’s.
target: Mo krwar ki dan Sidafrik, baze lor nu prop lexperyans laba, ti ena enn kriz istorik byin profon. Li ti fer so aparisyon ver lafen bann lane 1960.

input: It found its expression most strongly in two major strike waves.
target: Sa ti reflete dan sa 2 gran muvman de grev a-lepok.

input: One in Namibia, where there was a major strike (1971), the other in South Africa the Durban strikes (1973).
target: Premye-la ti dan Namibi, kot ti ena enn gran lagrev. Dezyem-la ti koni dan Sidafrik kuma “bann lagrev Dirban”.

input: Another major rupture was that of 1976 (Soweto students’ uprising); we went on to a major crisis in 1980-83, and further on to another one in 1985, which was followed by a chain of other crises in the “Homelands” at the tail end of the 1980s, at the beginning of the 1990’s.
target: Lot gran muvman protestasyon ti an 1976, lerla ena enn gran kriz dan bann lane 1980, ek lerla enn lot dan bann lane otur 1985, ek enn seri lezot kriz dan Homlennds ek lezot landrwa alafin bann lane 1980, kumansman bann lane 1990.

input: This was a sign of a cycle of sustained crisis in the social structure.
target: Sa ti enn siyn ki ena enn sik kriz kontinyel dan striktir sosyal.

input: When therefore one says that the crisis can extend for decades, this is not an exaggeration.
target: Kan dimunn dir ki enn kriz kapav etann pandan plizyer deseni, pa pe exazere nanye.

input: The important point is, when the crisis that we characterize as an organic crisis begins, it leads to a chain of conjunctural crises.
target: Pwin inportan ladan se ki enn kriz ki nu apel “organik” kan li demare, li al ver seri kriz konzonktirel ki ansene enn deryer lot.

input: It is not just one long crisis.
target: Li pa zis enn long kriz.

input: It goes from one upsurge to a time of calm, to another upsurge and another crisis, as the different social classes are taking stock of their different solutions in the upturns, and especially in times of calm.
target: Li demar ek enn sulevman, li rant dan enn akalmi, lerla ena lot sulevman, ek enn lot kriz amezir diferan klas sosyal met an-viger zot prop solisyon pu sorti dan kriz ki arive sirtu dan lepok akalmi.

input: One can then observe the very deep dialectic between the organic crisis and its waves of conjunctural crises.
target: Alor nu remarke ki ena dyalektik byen profon ant kriz organik-la ek so seri kriz konzonktirel ki li amene.

input: And the important point again is that the role of the party is to keep in the minds of the working class the continuity of the crisis.
target: Seki inportan osi, se pu konpran ki rol Parti se pu fer klas travayer realize ki se enn mem kriz ki pe kontinye.

input: Because every time the ruling class will present it as a new set of “disturbances”, or another act of violence or another example of unrest or some new agitators.
target: Parski sak ler, klas dirizan pu prezant sak sulevman kuma enn seri “nuvo kalite dezord”, uswa enn nuvo kalite akt de vyolans, uswa enn nuvo band azitater.

input: So the importance of the party is that throughout, through its insight and experience, it is able to keep an understanding of the continuity of those sources of “unrest”.
target: Alor linportans enn Parti se ki tut-o-long, akoz so kapasite danaliz ek so lexperyans, Parti-la kapav expoz manyer tu sa bann diferan “bulversman”-la ena mem lasurs.

input: The party has the role of pointing to the fact that all these different problems are pointing to a crisis, to an organic crisis.
target: Parti-la so rol se pu demontre kimanyer tu sa bann problem la pe expoz lefet ki ena enn kriz organik.

input: I think on the grounds of this unfolding of the organic crisis, two key things can, or need to be done.
target: Mo panse ki lor baz sa kriz organik ki pe deferle-la, ena 2 zafer inportan ki kapav fer.
Pu konpran kot lalit-la so sant pe buze.

input: The first one, an important task for the party, is to analyze, and to work closely with the masses, and to be able to discern any shift in the general composition of the revolutionary forces.
target: Premye zafer ki enn Parti kapav fer kan li pe travay pros ar lamas se pu li kapav idantifye nerport ki shiftaz dan konpozisyon zeneral bann lafors revolisyoner.

input: A South African example: In the 30-35 year period, an interesting feature of that period was the way that the centre or epicentre of the revolutionary outbreaks kept shifting from one part of the working class to another one.
target: Les mo donn enn legzanp depi Sid Afrik:  Dan sa lepok 30-35 an kot ti ena sulevman dan Sid Afrik, seki ti interesan se manyer ki sant sa bann sulevman revolisyoner ti shifte depi enn seksyon klas travayer a enn lot.

input: In the very beginning you have as front-runners, the university students.
target: Dan kumansman, seki ti divan-divan ti etidyan liniversite.

input: At that time, the revolutionary forces were exhausted, were defeated, there was fear in the country, then you have the first outbreak of popular dissent against apartheid amongst the university students.
target: Sa lepok-la, bann diferan lafors revolisyoner ti’nn epwize, ti’nn sibir defet, ti ena laper dan pei. Lerla-mem etidyan liniversite organiz premye sulevman popiler kont sistem aparteid.

input: You saw the formation of the South African Students’ Organisation (SASO) as one of the important landmarks, the student's organisation, which organised in the tertiary institutions.
target: Samem ki amenn nesans SASO, organizasyon etidyan onivo sekter ledikasyon tersyer, e sa reprezant enn turnan mazer.

input: The next important event represents a major shift in centre of gravity to the factories.
target: Prosenn evennman inportan ki vini reflet enn shiftaz sant sulevman buz ver sekter indistriyel.

input: The 1973 strikes, which changed everything completely.
The strikes reversed almost a decade and a half of repression against the trade union movement.
target: Li finn ranvers sa represyon ki ti ena kont muvman sindikal pandan plis ki 15 an.

input: Suddenly, workers were bold enough to organise their own unions, and to strike.
target: Enn sel kut travayer finn gayn kuraz neseser pu organize zot prop sindika, pu fer lagrev.

input: About 100,000 workers come out in Durban and this lead to the birth of many of the modern trade unions.
target: Dan Dirban, anviron 100,000 travayer finn mobilize dan lagrev e finn donn nesans plizir nuvo kalite sindika modern.

input: That was the second kind of shift, to a second stratum.
target: Sa se dezyem kalite shiftaz alinteryer klas travayer, kumadir lor enn dezyem nivo.

input: The next wave broke out in education, but not in the tertiary institutions which was the case in the first wave, but in schools, in 1976.
target: Prosenn vag sulevman ti vini an 1975. Sann kut-la, li pa vini depi etidyan dan tersyer, me plito depi kolez mem.

input: What we saw, and this is instructive, is the shift in the centres of gravity within the working class - the working class was not just one block.
target: Seki nu finn truve, e sa finn anseyn nu buku, se ki klas travayer li pa enn sel blok, ek sant gravite a-linteryer klas travayer li tultan pe buze.

input: It is important, both from the point of view of analysis and obviously from the point of view of the positioning of the party itself, in the context of the unfolding crisis, to keep a close eye on these shifts as they develop.
target: Pu bezwen analiz, li inportan konpran konfigirasyon zeneral klas travayer. E natirelman osi, kuma parti-la pu pozisyonn limem amezir kriz-la deferle pu ki li kapav sirvey sa bann shiftaz-la depre.

input: The important lesson from South Africa about this is that first of all there were groups on the Left that, through a theoretical schema, decreed the primacy of the industrial working class.
target: Leson inportan ki nu anprann depi lekzanp Sid Afrik, se ti ena grup dan lagos ki ti servi enn model teorik ki ti truv klas travayer indistriyel kuma lafors pli santral.

input: So every time these waves broke outside of the industrial proletariat, they were unable therefore to be in contact with the revolutionary parts of the working class, and to inform other classes, and to keep the historical continuity of the change in the tide of the revolution.
target: Alor a sak fwa ki ti ena sulevman andeor sekter indistriyel, sa bann grup dan lagos-la pa ena lyin neseser avek sa seksyon revolisyoner klas travayer pu ki zot kominik a lezot seksyon ek klas sa kontinite istorik dan diferan vag revolisyoner.

input: The important lesson is that one cannot decree in advance which section of the working class will come into action.
target: Leson inportan pu retenir ladan, seki u pa kapav dekrete odepar ki seksyon klas travayer pu vinn an-aksyon avan. Zordi, dan limedya, li kapav vre pu dir ki burzwazi pe santre so latak dan Lindistri Sikriyer.

input: Now, it can be the case that the immediate attack by the bourgeoisie takes place in the sugar industry, but that may not tell us that the first wave of opposition will emerge in that sector. Our ability to establish where that next wave breaks is a test of the party’s capacity. But the party cannot decree.
target: Me sa pa vedir ki premye vag sulevman pu kumanse laba dan sa sekter la. Nu kapasite pu predir kot prosenn vag sulevman pu sorti, li enn test kapasite ki parti-la ena. Me parti pa kapav dekrete par limem kot sulevman-la pu sorti.

input: The second issue of course is the party’s own penetration into the working class, in its various strata.
target: Dezyeman, nu ena pu konsider lyen parti-la avek klas travayer, avek diferan kus klas travayer.

input: Another point is an analysis of the internal structure of the working class, and how that is being changed as the organic economic crisis unfolds in time.
target: Ena osi pu analiz striktir intern klas travayer, e kuma li pe sanze amezir ki nu travers enn kriz ekonomik sistemik.

input: It is important so that the party isn’t always playing catch-up.
target: Li inportan ki parti-la pa tultan par deryer klas travayer, pe bizen galupe pu ratrape.

input: I don’t think the party can ever catch up with the working class; in upturns, the working class is always that much faster.
target: Mo pa krwar ki parti kapav zame ratrape. Dan bann lepok mobilizasyon, klas travayer li tultan pli divan.

input: And the important point is that, if you do get left behind, don’t get paralyzed.
target: Ek la, ena enn pwen inportan: si u finn res par deryer, pa res paralize anplas.

input: Try and keep close enough to the working class to be able to catch up.
target: Sey koste ase pre avek klas travayer pu ki u kapav ratrape.

input: A similar kind of analysis and interaction needs to take place concerning the way a crisis is re-organizing the ruling block.
target: Dan mem fason, li neseser ena enn analiz ek konpreansyon lor manyer kriz la pe re-organiz blok klas dirizan.

input: I want to spend some time on this.
target: Mo ti pu kontan al inpe plis an-detay lor sa.

input: At certain times, in the evolution of the crisis, we find that certain elements of the historical bloc, in order to resolve their own disagreements within the block, begin to organize outside the ruling block.
target: Ena fwa kan kriz-la pe evolye, sertenn konpozan “blok klas dirizan” detas zot e re-organize andeor blok la pu rezud dezakor a linteryer sa blok la.

input: Normally you could have an apparently very quiet historical period, a lull within this long-term organic crisis, and then suddenly a fight begins to break out, which then exposes a very soft under-belly to the crisis.
target: Normalman, u kapav gayn enn lepok ki paret byin trankil depi andeor, kumadir enn akalmi dan sa kriz organik a-lon-alenn-la. Lerla, enn sel ku konfli eklate e sa expoz enn pwin feb dan kriz kapitalis-la.

input: Old thieves, as they say, are falling out.
target: Komdi koze bann vye konper, voler pe kas bann.

input: In their attempt to shore up their own positions, they begin to organize outside.
target: Pu sap zot pozisyon dan blok klas dirizan, zot kumans organize andeor blok istorik-la.

input: So crises are not only triggered because the working class is under pressure, but the crises are sometimes triggered by re-organization of the ruling block.
target: Alor, kriz pa zis deklanse akoz klas travayer su presyon me ena fwa li osi deklanse par re-organizasyon ki ena alinteryer klas dirizan.

input: The crisis’ vigour and tempo can also be determined by the internal re-organization of the ruling block.
target: Sa re-organizasyon ki ena a-linteryer klas dirizan kapav osi determinan pu lanpler ek ritm kriz-la.

input: Especially, as I said, when a section of the ruling block attempts to organize outside the ruling block; for example, when we discussed how the Labour Party got captured in a sense by the planters in the 1950s.
target: Sirtu, kuma mo finn dir, kan enn seksyon klas dirizan sey organize andeor sa blok-la. Par ekzanp, kan dan enn sertenn sans, Parti Travayis ti finn akapare par bann planter dan bann lane 1950.

input: But the important thing about the problem is that the planters, through the Labour Party, had to reach a new historical accommodation with the sugar oligarchy, so that these classes could continue to act together, under a new balance of forces within the ruling block.
target: Seki inportan ladan, se lefet ki planter ti rant dan enn laranzman istorik avek oligarsi Lindistri Sikriyer pu sa bann klas-la kapav kontiyn azir ansam, me dan enn nuvo rapor de fors a-linteryer blok klas dirizan.

input: It happens sometimes that these parts of the block can’t identify together anymore.
target: E parfwa li arive ki diferan seksyon sa blok istorik la nepli truv ki zot kapav mars ansam.

input: As I think, when we get nearer 2009, when the whole issue of the money for sugar comes up.
target: Kuma mo krwar pu arive kan nu apros lane 2009, kan kestyon lamone disik suleve.

input: When the crunch of the crisis comes up, we might find that the traditional parties of the ruling block are not able to contain the contradictions within that block.
target: Kan kriz-la mir, nu kapav gayn enn sityasyon kot bann klas ki ti alye tradisyonelman nepli kapav kontenir kontradiksyon ki pe al suleve a-linteryer sa blok klas dirizan-la.

input: And in those moments you find out that the structure of these parties, of one of the parties within that block, requires support, and therefore it begins to fish outside the usual support for the ruling block, and look for possible allies in the re-organization of the ruling block.
target: E dan sa moman la u pu truve ki striktir sa bann diferan konpozant dan blok istorik klas dirizan, uswa enn konpozant ladan, pu bizen rod sutyen, alor li kumans rod sutyen andeor sa blok klas dirizan la e li kumans rod  nuvo alye potansyel dan sa prosesis re-organizasyon klas dirizan.

input: Now, it’s crucial for the revolutionary party to be sensitive to these movements between the ruling classes, without of course accommodating itself to them.
target: Zordi, li inportan pu bann parti revolisyoner konn rekonet kan pe ena sa bann muvman a linteryer klas dirizan, san, natirelman, fer okenn konpromi ar zot.

input: As we see in South Africa at the moment, what the Zuma affair really comes down to is the fact that the structure within the ruling block (of ANC-SACP-COSATU) finds labour wanting to latch on to one part of that block, as a way of resolving its own crisis.
target: Nu truv sa pe arive zordi dan Sid Afrik, se sa sinifikasyon skandal Zuma. Nu pe truv travayer sey kol avek enn seksyon blok dirizan ANC-SACP-COSATU kuma enn mwayen pu rezud so prop kriz.

input: And now the crucial political character of the party comes in.
target: Alor kot nu ete la, li krisyal pu Parti asim so rol politik.

input: Its implantation in the mass, the nature of its program, both prevent it from just becoming attached as a support to one or other elements of the ruling classes.
target: So lankraz dan lamas ek natir so program, tulede anpes li amare avek enn u lot konpozan sa blok istorik klas dirizan.

input: It is quite important that the party of the working class is able to anticipate, and understand and intervene decisively in the political debate within the society, a debate that is unleashed by these conflicts in the ruling class, and to have the structures in its own party that permit this debate.
target: Li byen inportan ki Parti ki reprezant klas travayer ena kapasite pu antisipe, konpran ek intervenir dan deba politik, deba ki provoke par konfli a linteryer klas dirizan, ek pu ki striktir dan Parti organize pu permet sa kalite deba la.

input: So in terms of strategy, the question of how this structure in the party enables debate becomes an important part of the strategy.
target: Sa kestyon lor kimanyer striktir Parti permet sa kalite deba vinn kitsoz ki inportan kan nu pe get stratezi.

input: Now, there are two last things I would like to talk about, before coming to my concluding remarks.
target: Avan mo konklir ena enn dernye zafer lor ki mo pu koze.

input: In the development of the strategy of the Revolutionary Party, there are 2 issues, which become quite important especially when there’s a crisis of an extended character, and society goes through this chain of struggles.
target: Premyerman, dan devlopman stratezi enn parti revolisyoner, ena 2 kestyon ki inportan pu nu gete, sirtu kan nu pe al ver enn kriz prolonze. Setadir enn kriz ki pu pran plizyer lane pu deferle, e ki pu travers dan enn seri mayon lalit ki pu ena dan sosyete an zeneral ek dan lalit dan klas travayer an partikilye.

input: The first one has to do with the issue of the tempo of the crisis.
target: Premye kestyon ki poze, se tempo kriz la.

input: I will talk about that very shortly.
target: Mo pu koz lor la dan enn ti mama.

input: The second one is what I call the problems of synchronization of the crisis.
target: Dezyem se seki mo apel kestyon sinkronizasyon kriz la.

input: The crisis is not always moving in step.
target: Kriz la pa tuzur avans dan mem ritm.

input: I think we can see sometimes how these issues play themselves out in the course of actual history.
target: Mo panse nu bizen get lexperyans listwar pu konpran linportans sa kestyon la.

input: Firstly, let us talk about the tempo of the crisis.
target: Premye, anu koz lor ‘tempo kriz la’.

input: One is obviously talking here about the pace at which the crisis unfolds.
target: La, nu pe koz klerman lor ki vites kriz la pe deferle.

input: It appears that in periods of organic crisis, you have both periods of very slow development of the crisis and of swift movement.
target: Dan lepok kriz organik, ena moman kot kriz-la buz lant ek ena lot moman kot li buze dan enn rit akselere.

input: The crisis can sometimes develop a step at a time, when there are no major breakouts of any major struggles, and there’s a bit of defensive action in this or that corner.
target: Kriz la parfwa kapav devlop staz par staz, si pena okenn lalit mazer ki intansifye li enn kut, ek nek ena enn-de aksyon defansiv parsi-parla.

input: Again this slow tempo can punctuate a period of upsurges.
target: Li mem kapav paret ki nu pe al ver lafen enn kriz. Sa ralantisman ki gayne dan lepok kriz, kapav gayn li ant diferan peryod sulevman.

input: The period in South Africa from the 1960s to the early 90’s is filled up with alternating tempos in the class struggle.
target: Si nu pran Sid Afrik dan peryod lane ’60 ziska lane ’90, sa tempo lalit de klas finn alterne ant ralantisman ek akselerasyon.

input: Periods where there was very little organizing taking place, the revolutionary forces are exhausted, they are retired, and suddenly periods of enormous acceleration in the class struggle when just about everyone is prepared to join an organization.
target: Ti ena moman kot ti ena byen tigit mobilizasyon, kot lafors revolisyoner ti epwize e ti an-retre, e ti ena moman kot ena enn akselerasyon egi dan lalit de klas kot preske tu dimunn pare pu dibute ek zwenn enn lorganizasyon.

input: No one is scared of the police.
target: La, personn pa ti per lapolis.

input: Everyone wants to put a barricade in the street.
target: Sakenn anvi met barikad lor sime.

input: That goes on for months, and then suddenly they go back again to normal life.
target: Sa kapav al kumsa pandan plizyer mwa, ek lerla, enn sel ku, tu return kuma avan, dimunn repran zot lavi normal.
Savedir tempo lalit de klas li alterne.

input: So, the issue of the tempo is, of course, important to us because the whole range of different tactics is appropriate to each period characterized by a different tempo of struggle.
target: Alor, li byen inportan pu nu get kestyon tempo, akoz  li determinn ki taktik pu apropriye pu sak tempo.

input: The working class reacts differently in the different phases.
target: Klas travayer reazir diferaman dan diferan tempo.

input: Sometimes it will take you months to try to explain a certain demand, and then suddenly the working class will understand directly.
target: Parfwa li pran nu plizyer mwa pu nu sey explik enn demand, ek ena fwa, demand-la vinn kler pu dimunn enn sel ku.

input: “This is all old stuff,” they will tell you, “We know that already! We are looking for more new things.”
target: “Sa enn vye zafer sa” zot pu dir, “nu deza konn sa! Nu pe rod kitsoz pli nuvo”.

input: We find again that sometimes it takes years of organizing in schools and universities, and suddenly there’s a spark and we find that we cannot keep up – with the demands for literature, demands for speakers, and so on.
target: Parfwa, li kapav pran plizyer lane pu organize dan lekol ek liniversite. Ep, enn ku ena komsidire enn etinsel ek apenn kapav reponn lapel pu furni ankor plis literatir de gos, ankor plis orater.

input: So we see that new ways of learning, new ways of doing politics correspond to different phases of the struggle.
target: Alor, ena nuvo fason aprann, nuvo fason fer politik ki koresponn a diferan faz tempo dan lalit.

input: And I think again, importantly, and this again makes the party crucial, is that from one successive wave in this alternating tempo to the next, there are important changes in the psychology of the working class.
target: E, parski depi enn tempo a enn lot, ant sa 2 vag-la, dan sa moman ant sanzman vites tempo, ena sanzman inportan dan sikolozi klas travayer, e la, Parti ena enn rol inportan.

input: The working class creates new organizations and they begin then to sustain them.
target: Klas travayer kree nuvo organizasyon e zot kumans sweyn zot lorganizasyon.

input: So these are never the same.
target: Ki vedir zame form lorganizasyon pu res parey.

input: And I think there are important debates and discussions in the history of revolutionary strategy.
target: Ena deba e diskisyon inportan dan listwar stratezi revolisyoner konsern sa kestyon la.

input: And with the Russians again, to whom we owe so much, though they are impoverished nowadays, there was a whole debate on what we call the theory of the “offensive”.
target: Ankor enn fwa nu turn ver Larisi, ki ena telman buku pu anseyn nu, malgre ki azordi li finn apovri. Laba, lepok avan Revolisyon Ris, ti ena enn gran deba  lor “teori lofansiv”.

input: We see a whole group within the party, which kind of believes that once the first wave of the crisis breaks out, it’s a one-way street now, and the party is on the offensive all the time.
target: Ti ena enn grup dan Parti ki ti krwar ki kan ena premye sulevman kont kriz, pena bare, li pu swiv enn sel sime wann-we, e zot ti krwar Parti pu res lor lofansiv kontinyelman.

input: And I think there is the need for a lot of debate about the fact that the crisis is extended, and that the existence of a crisis does not always imply that the working class is ready everyday to have a march in the streets.
target: Mo panse ki bizen buku deba lor lefet ki kriz-la pu dire lor letan. Nu bizen konsyan lefet ki ena kriz pa otomatikman vedir klas travayer pu pare pu desann lor lari tulezur.

input: In fact you might have to go back to much slower tempos of political work within and between the waves in the struggle.
target: Ena fwa, u bizen ralanti travay mobilizasyon politik ant enn vag lalit ek enn lot, uswa mem pandan enn vag lalit.

input: That was also important in the civil war period in Russia as well, with the White Army, and so on, because the theory of the “offensive” was transferred from the theory of the offensive in revolution into the civil war.
target: Kestyon sanzman dan tempo ti vinn inportan dan peryod Lager Sivil dan Larisi otur size White Army, kan ti servi teori “lofansiv” e finn transpoz li depi larevolisyon ziska lor kestyon Lager Sivil.

input: It also became important and was unfortunately the source of many defeats in Europe in the 1930’s where the working class was ordered, when this group dominated the Comintern, to be on the offensive against the bourgeoisie., and told that this is the last fight against the bourgeoisie, and will be an all out fight.
target: Sa kestyon sanzman dan tempo li ti re-suleve dan bann lane 1930 kan klas travayer ti gayn lord par tandans dominan dan Comintern a-lepok pu al lor “lofansiv” kont burzwazi.

input: So this indicates the importance of the dialectics in the kind of interchange in tempo in the class struggle.
target: Alor sa montre linportans dyalektik dan sa kalite sanzman tempo dan lalit de klas.

input: I think I will talk briefly about the second problem, that is, the problem of synchronization, in the development of the class struggle.
target: Mo pu koz inpe lor sa dezyem kestyon, setadir kestyon sinkronizayon dan devlopman lalit de klas.

input: Now it is also an interesting and very difficult problem for the parties of the working class.
target: Sa li enn problematik interesan, me byen konplike pu bann parti klas travayer.

input: And when comrades discuss this, we think it found its sharpest expression in the “July Days” in Petrograd in the Russian Revolution.
target: Kan nu pe diskit e reflesi lor sa kestyon sinkronizasyon, lekzanp “July Days” dan Petrograd pandan Revolisyon Ris, li enn lekzanp frapan.

input: Now what are the important issues?
In a period of an extended struggle, one that goes on for decades, or even for months, in a very intensive period, we get all the problems of tempo and so on.
target: Dan enn peryod byen intans ki etale lor letan, lor plizyer mwa ubyen mem plizyer deseni, ena tu sa kestyon kuma tempo, tusala.

input: But there is another problem, which is very systemically rooted in the very nature of the working class, - which is that the working class’s different sectors and different strata experience capitalism and the crisis differently.
target: Me ena enn lot kestyon fondamantal, ki anrasine dan natir klas travayer li-mem: klas travayer dan diferan sekter e diferan kus klas travayer, zot lexperyans lavi su reyn kapitalist e lexperyans lavi pandan kriz-la, sakenn diferan.

input: And they sometimes have very different traditions of organizing; they have different strengths, and different psyches of combativity.
target: E parfwa zot ena diferan tradisyon organize; zot lafors diferan e zot lespri konbativite diferan.

input: Some will take to the streets, as they are always “hot-headed”, they’re always ready to fight; at any suggestions of the bourgeoisie that they are going to temper with their rights, they take to the streets immediately.
target: Ena ki pu desann lor sime, parski zot tuzur vif, zot sofe brit-brit, zot tuzur pare pu lager; mwenn muv burzwazi pu tus zot drwa, tutswit zot desann lor sime.

input: Others are much slower and take much longer.
target: Ena lezot seksyon u kus klas travayer ki pli lant e zot pran plis letan pu azir.

input: And what this produces then, as the crisis unfolds, is the difficulty of synchronization between these different sections we are talking about.
target: E rezilta tusala, kan kriz-la pe deferle, se kimanyer pu sinkroniz sakenn sa diferan seksyon dan klas travayer.

input: What is important for this synchronization to occur?
Sometimes, it is one section of the working class taking a solo attempt on the ruling class and staffing the barricades alone.
target: Parfwa, ena enn seksyon klas travayer ki desid pu marse tusel kont klas dirizan e zot al met barikad zot tusel, an-solo.

input: And they get mowed down, one by one, and this is where demoralization translates to the other sectors.
target: E kan zot gayn koyne, enn par enn, enn par enn, li demoraliz lezot seksyon klas travayer.

input: In the historical problematic, I mentioned the July Days, it became quite a major issue because comrades realized that the future of the revolution was at risk.
target: Mo ti mansyonn lekzanp “July Days” dan Revolisyon Ris, parski sa ti zisteman vinn enn gran problem ki bann kamarad a-lepok ti realize ti pu met lavenir larevolisyon anperil.

input: Because the more militant sectors in Petrograd wanted to go and take power, and the peasantry was not prepared, other sections were not interested, and the danger emerged that the more militant sections would be able to be mowed down in isolation from the other sections.
target: Dan moman kot seksyon travayer plis militan dan Petrograd ti ule azir e pran puvwar, dan sa mem moman-la, peizannri pa ti ankor pare pu buze, ek lezot seksyon klas travayer pa ti ankor interese.

input: A kind of the repeat of the experience of the Parisian working class in 1871 where it rose up in isolation from other social classes, because there were no other social forces that were able to take part in the revolution at that time.
target: Sa ti reprezant enn danze parski amezir seksyon travayer pli militan sibir defet, zot izol zot mem depi lezot seksyon klas travayer. Li ti komsidire enn repetisyon de seki ti ariv klas travayer Paris kan li fer sulevman li tusel dan bann lane 1870, san sinkronize avek lezot klas sosyal parski pa ti ena lot lafors sosyal ki ti pu kapav alye avek klas travayer Paris dan sa lepok la.

input: So now again, when we talk of the different considerations of strategy, the issue here is what is the authority of the party in being able to facilitate an almost approximate kind of synchronization?
target: Alor aster, kan nu pe debat diferan laspe stratezi, kestyon prinsipal isi se eski Parti ena ase kredibilite ki permet li pran linisyativ pu sey amenn sa senkronizasyon-la?

input: Theoretically or otherwise, even with a party’s growing, deepening authority within the working class, it is not an easy task.
target: Teorikman, mem si lidership Parti ena rekonesans a-linteryer klas travayer, li pa enn travay fasil.

input: The party often has to struggle hard to hold the working class, to hold back those who want to act too fast alone, to keep the working class together.
target: Parti-la bizen amenn enn gran konba pu li kapav tini klas travayer, pu kal bann ki anvi azir tro vit e azir tusel, pu Parti kapav gard klas travayer ini.

input: Another issue is how do we respond when these different sections of the working class take these solo attempts?
target: Enn lot kestyon se kimanyer nu bizen reazir kan diferan seksyon klas travayer fer sa kalite tantativ-la tusel?

input: And what does this say about the capacity of the party to emerge with prestige.
target: E ki nu reaksyon vedir anterm kapasite Parti pu reysi sorti dan sa take-la avek kredibilite.

input: The difficulty is, at the time, do you say, “Ah, we have got nothing to do with it! We told you not to do this now! You won’t listen!” and then leave them to their devices?
target: Problem-la se sa: eski u dir, “Ayo, nu pena naryen pu fer avek sa! Nunn dir pa so ler pu fer sa! Zot pa finn ekute!” lerla les zot debruye par zot mem?

input: Or do we deal with the problem as they dealt with it in July in Russia, working out to what extent we march with them, even as they head to extreme instances of defeat that they can suffer?
target: Ubyen eski nu diyl avek problem-la parey kuma ti fer pandan “July Days” dan lepok Revolisyon Ris. Savedir nu sey zize ziska ki pwen nu kapav mars avek sa seksyon klas travayer ki pe mars tusel, mem si zot pe al ver enn defet kle kot zot kapav sufer buku dega?

input: So to come to some of the most important issues of political debate: What do you do when there is a riot?
target: Alor pu revinn lor enn-de kestyon pli inportan dan deba politik : ki pu fer kan ena enn lemet?

input: This is the historical problematic that we have to deal with in this context.
target: Se sa kalite problematik istorik  ki nu bizen diyl dan sa kontex-la.
Dernye zafer lor lekel mo pu koze se eski li posib ki ena enn kriz katastrofik e final?

input: The final thing I want to talk about is this: Is there such a thing as the final and catastrophic crisis, one out of which the bourgeoisie can never emerge?
target: Eski li posib ena enn kriz de enn tel lanvergir ki burzwazi pa pu kapav sirviv?

input: Lenin said that there are no absolutely hopeless situations from which the bourgeoisie cannot emerge.
target: Lenin finn dir, e li tutafe vre, ki pena okenn sityasyon dezespere kot burzwazi nepli kapav sirviv.

input: It has deep reserves in the whole international block that looks after it, that is entrusted with its welfare.
target: Li ena sutyen totalite blok internasyonal an-rezerv pu okip so sirvi.

input: There is also the fact that it is the one class that has access to the largest part of permanently available resources, and to ideologues who are defending its attitudes and its ideology, defending the system until the last.
