Declaration of Grande Riviere on Chagos.

The Conference on Diego Garcia & Chagos held at Grande Riviere, Port Louis, Mauritius, bringing together 150 participants from 30 October to 2 November 2010, reached consensus that we will keep the following struggles firmly bound together, never bartering one against the other:
target: Konferans 30 Oktob a 2 Novam 2010, ki finn reyni 150 dimunn Gran Rivyer, finn tom dakor ki nu pe viz anmemtan:

input: - the struggle for the complete decolonization of the Republic of Mauritius, the dismantling of the British Indian Ocean Territories colony, and the re-unification of the country,
target: - pu dekoloniz Repiblik Moris konpletman, demantel BIOT, ek re-inifye pei.

input: - the struggle for the closing down of the US military base on Diego Garcia, and its ecological clean-up by the US.
target: - pu ferm baz militer USA Diego Garcia, e fer netwayaz ekolozik.

input: - the struggle for the right of return and full reparations for all Chagossians,
target: - pu asir drwa de retur ek ful reparasyon pu tu Chagosyen,

input: And that to advance these aims, and given that there are some actions that can be set in motion only by the State of Mauritius,
target: e ki, pu ariv a sa, etan done ki se selman Leta Moris ki abilite pu met an mars sertenn linisyativ, nu angaz nu pu met presyon lor Leta Moris pu li azir dan lapratik:

input: we commit ourselves to putting pressure on the Mauritian State towards its acting in practice so as:
target: - Pu organiz enn vizit deta formel lor bato Trochetia par enn delegasyon ki inklir an personn Prezidan Repiblik, Premye Minis, ek Lider Lopozisyon, lor Chagos (inklir Diego Garcia) sa parti teritwar "Mauritius" ki definir kom tel dan Konstitisyon pei.

input: - To organize a formal State visit on the Trochetia ship to Diego Garcia and the whole of Chagos, which is part of Mauritian territory defined as such by the Constitution, and that the State delegation should include the President of the Republic, the Prime Minister, and the Leader of the Opposition;
target: - Pu met enn ka Lakur Internasyonal Lazistis (ICJ) La-Haye atraver inskripsyon imedya de enn Rezolisyon dan sa sans la ek mintenir li lor azanda prosenn Lasanble Zeneral UN an 2011.

input: - To enter a case in the UN International Court of Justice at the Hague through at once inscribing a Resolution to this precise effect on the agenda for the next UN General Assembly due in 2011, and continuing to ensure that the Resolution is not later withdrawn from the agenda;
target: - Pu inskrir enn demand formel pu inspeksyon UN su Trete Pelindaba, osito ki so mekanism vinn an viger plitar sa lane la.

input: - To make a formal demand for UN inspections under the Pelindaba Treaty, as soon as the mechanism for doing so comes into force later this year.
target: - Pu servi tu bann linstans UN ki posib pu sinnyal klerman suvrennte Moris lor Chagos an antye, ek danze ki baz militer Diego Garcia reprezante.

input: - To use all other UN bodies and procedures possible for actions that indicate a clear statement of Mauritian sovereignty over Chagos, and that expose the danger the military base represents.
target: E, anmemtan, nu angaz nu, dan kad deba aktyel lor reform elektoral ek sanzman konstitisyonel, e fas a vize inperyalis ek kapital prive lor bann diferan lil ek teritwar Moris, pu travay ver donn enn form konkre pu Chagosyen form parti dan "set-up" demokratik Republic of Mauritius, antan ki Leta Arsipel;

input: And, at the same time, in the context of the present debate on electoral reform and Constitutional amendment, and in response to imperialist and private capitalist interests clearly targeting Mauritian Islands and land, to work towards giving concrete expression to the Chagossians' participation in the democratic set-up of the country;
target: e pu amand Konstitisyon pu anpes instalasyon tu baz militer lor teritwar Moris dan lavenir;

input: and to amend the Constitution so as to outlaw the setting up of any military bases on any Mauritian territory in future;
target: Ki nu pu evre ver met anplas enn Sant Syantifik pu rekey temwayaz, met ansam dokimantasyon, pu gard vivan listwar ek kiltir Chagos;

input: That we will work towards the setting up of a Scientific Centre that gathers testimony about Chagos, collects documentation on Chagos, so that the history and culture of Chagos are kept alive;
target: E ki, dan kad tu sa bann demand la, nu fer apel a Prezidan Repiblik, dernye temwen vivan, pu li vinn delavan, temwayn an piblik seki finn pase dan negosyasyon pre-Lindepandans ki ti fer dan Lancaster House;

input: And that, in the context of these demands, we call on the President of the Republic, the last living witness to the pre-Independence negotiations held at Lancaster House to come forward to give public testimony;
target: E pu ki nu avans sa 3 koz mansyone dabor dan sa Deklarasyon la, osi byin ki tu demand spesifik ki nu finn elabore answit, nu pu batir enn larz sutyen nasyonal ek internasyonal.

input: And that in order to advance the three causes stated just following the first paragraph above, as well as the specific demands then enumerated in this Declaration, we commit ourselves to building up broad support on a national and international level.
target: E nu deleg sis dimunn, susiyne, pu zot remet sa Deklarasyon Gran Rivyer la a Minis Zafer Etranzer e pu zot rann li piblik.

input: And we delegate six people, the undersigned, to present this Declaration of Grande Rivière to the Minister of Foreign Affairs, and also to make the Declaration public.
target: Kominike Ledikasyon pu Travayer lor so pri Internasyonal UNESCO 2004 lor literesi.

input: Communique of Ledikasyon pu Travayer for its 2004 UNESCO Literacy Prize.
target: LEDIKASYON PU TRAVAYER GAYN PRI INTERNASYONAL UNESCO 2004 LOR LITERESI.

input: 2004 UNESCO LITERACY PRIZE AWARDED TO LEDIKASYON PU TRAVAYER.
target: Ledikasyon pu Travayer (LPT) finn gayn International Reading Association Literacy Award 2004, enn pri ki UNESCO atribye a bann lorganizasyon ki pe kontribye dan enn fason sinifikatif dan lalit pu ki tu dimunn konn lir ekrir byin.

input: The 2004 International Reading Association Literacy Award, has been awarded to Ledikasyon Pu Travayer(LPT), a prize that UNESCO awards to organisations that are contributing in a significant way in the struggle to promote literacy for all.
target: Ki sa pri-la vedir pu LPT?

input: What does this prize means for LPT?
target: Sa pri-la reprezant enn rekonesans internasyonal pu travay ki LPT pe fer depi 28 an.

input: This award represents an international recognition for the work done by LPT for 28 years.
target: Dapre kominike UNESCO date Mardi 18 Me, li ekrir ki LPT finn gayn sa pri-la "pu so travay montre adilt lir-ekrir, sirtu parmi fam, pu so respe kontex kiltirel e pu itilizasyon langaz maternel".

input: According to a UNESCO Press release dated 18th May 2004, it is mentioned that LPT has been awarded this prize "for its adult literacy programme, which places emphasis on women, its respect for cultural context and the use of mother languages".
target: Dezyeman nu panse ki sa pri-la li donn enn valer spesyal sa travay montre lir-ekrir limem. Li vinn rekonet linportans pu ki sa zuti literesi-la vinn aksesib a tu dimunn.

input: Secondly we think that this award attributes a special value to the work of promoting literacy itself. It recognises the importance of making literacy accessible to everyone.
target: Sa li koresponn a UNESCO so kanpayn "ledikasyon pu tu dimunn".

input: This correspond to UNESCO campaign "Education For All".
target: E dan LPT nu finn tultan promuvwar ledikasyon kuma enn drwa.

input: And in LPT we have always been promoting education as a right.
target: Sa pri-la li osi enn form rekonesans kontribisyon ki fam finn ena dan LPT.

input: This award is a form of recognition of the contribution of women in LPT.
target: LPT finn pran nesans depi muvman kontestasyon ki ti ena Me 1975 kot tifi kolez ti divan-divan.

input: LPT was born in the wake of the student protest movement of May 1975 where college girls were in the forefront.
target: Depi ki nu ekziste bann mamb fam finn ena enn lapor konsiderab dan tu laspe nu travay e dan lavi intern nu lasosyasyon mem.

input: Since our foundation our women members have made a significant contribution in all aspects of our work and in the internal life of our organisation itself.
target: Ki li dan nu kur lir-ekrir, ki li dan kur lantrennman profeser u dan nu aksyon anfaver rekonesans langaz maternel dimunn Moris.

input: Whether it is in our literacy courses, our teacher training sessions or in the struggle for the recognition of mother languages in Mauritius.
target: Sa pri-la li enn rekonesans pu nu persistans e konsistans dan servi langaz maternel pu montre adilt lir ek ekrir.

input: This award is the recognition for our persistent and constant work in the use of mother languages in adult literacy.
target: Nu ti tultan teti lor sa size-la. E nu ankor tuzur parey.

input: We are known for being obstinate on this issue and we are still like that.
target: Zordi sa pri-la pe vinn donn nu rezon pu lefet ki nu finn mintenir sa prinsip de baz, ki tu dimunn anprann pli byin dan zot langaz maternel.

input: Today this UNESCO award is saying that LPT was right in maintaining this basic pedagogical principle that every person learns better in his or her mother language. No expert in education would say the contrary on this matter.
target: Pena okenn pedagog ki pu kontredir nu lorla.

input: Through this award UNESCO also wanted to draw world attention on the necessity to produce written materials in mother languages.
target: Atraver sa pri-la UNESCO finn ule osi atir latansyon lemond lor linportans prodir materyel ekri dan langaz maternel.

input: Today UNESCO is recognising the contribution of LPT in the production, publication and circulation of every kind of literature in the Kreol and Bhojpuri languages.
target: Zordi UNESCO pe rekonet kontribisyon ki LPT finn ena dan prodiksyon, piblikasyon e sirkilasyon tu kalite literatir dan langaz Kreol Morisyin e Bhojpuri.

input: every women and men, from villages, coastal areas and towns who have participated in our literacy courses all voluntary teachers who have organised, run and nurture our literacy courses and at the same time contributed in the development of the pedagogy that we are using now.
target: tu fam e zom, depi vilaz, lakot ziska lavil, ki finn partisip dan nu kur anprann lir-ekrir tu dimunn depi Moris e Rodrig ki finn swiv nu kur lantrennman profeser, nu kur anprann Kreol e lezot kur lor langaz  tu profeser volonter ki finn anim e tini nu kur lir-ekrir, e donn kudme dan devlop pedagozi ki nu pe servi.

input: All our members who year after year have been nurturing our association and have contributed to its development.
target: tu nu mamb ki lane apre lane finn sweyn nu lasosyasyon e kontribye dan so devlopman.

input: all our supporting members who have actively participated in our activities and supported our work.
target: tu nu sinpatizan ki finn partisip aktivman dan nu aktivite e sutenir nu travay.

input: all local and international organisations with whom we have cooperated and who supported our work.
target: tu lorganizasyon isi ek dan lezot pei avek lekel nu finn korpere e ki finn sutenir nu travay.

input: all writers, poets, artists, academics, journalists, teachers, students and other individuals in Mauritius, Rodrigues and other countries who have been associated with our work to promote our mother languages, for the right to education and for linguistic diversity.
target: tu ekrivin, poet, artis, akademik, zurnalis, edikater, etidyan e lezot individi dan Moris, Rodrig e lezot pei ki finn asosye zot a nu travay pu promuvwar langaz maternel, pu drwa a ledikasyon e anfaver diversite lingwistik.

input: We take note of all this human effort put together into the work and action for the mother languages of the people of the Republic of Mauritius to develop and flourish.
target: Nu salye tu sa zefor imin ki finn mete dan travay e aksyon anfaver devlopman e epanwisman langaz maternel dimunn Repiblik Moris.

input: UNESCO will give this prize to LPT on the 8th September 2004 on the occasion of International Literacy Day.
target: Sa pri UNESCO-la pe remet a Ledikasyon pu Travayer le 8 Septam 2004 dan kad Zurne Internasyonal Literesi.

input: Ledikasyon pu Travayer (Mauritius) has been awarded UNESCO's 2004 International Literacy prize.
target: Ledikasyon pu Travayer (Moris) gayn Pri Internasyonal UNESCO 2004 lor Literesi.

input: Ledikasyon pu Travayer (LPT) has been awarded UNESCO's 2004 International Literacy prize.
target: Ledikasyon pu Travayer (LPT) finn gayn Pri Internasyonal Literesi UNESCO 2004.

input: This prize is called The International Reading Association Literacy Award.
target: Sa pri-la apel Pri Lasosyasyon Internasyonal Lektir pu Literesi.

input: Ledikasyon pu Travayer won this award for its adult literacy work, which places the emphasis on women, its respect for cultural context and use of mother languages.
target: LPT finn gayn sa pri-la pu so travay montre adilt lir-ekrir, kot li finn met lanfaz lor ledikasyon fam, lor respe kontex kiltirel e lor itilizasyon langaz maternel.

input: UNESCO also mentions that Ledikasyon pu Travayer has also produced, printed and distributed books - including the Mauritian Creole dictionary - and reading materials covering every aspect of learners' lives.
target: UNESCO finn osi mansyone ki Ledikasyon pu Travayer finn pibliye, inprime e distribiye liv, inkli enn diksyoner Kreol ek materyo pu lektir ki kuver tu laspe lavi dimunn ki anprann.

input: This prize will be awarded on 8th September 2004 on the occasion of the World Literacy Day.
target: Sa pri-la pu remet a Ledikasyon pu Travayer dan kad Zurne Internasyonal Literesi le 8 Septam 2004.

input: Since 28 years Ledikasyon pu Travayer is undertaking the literacy work.
target: Ledikasyon pu Travayer pe fer sa travay montre lir-ekrir depi 28 an.

input: In the same time LPT, one among the pioneer organisations which is still promoting Mother tongue based Education LPT is dedicating this award to all participants, animators, members, supporting members, and all Associations and individuals in the Republic of Mauritius and abroad who are still struggling for the recognition of mother tongue.
target: Anmemtan LPT enn parmi bann pilye ki finn e pe kontiyn promuvwar langaz maternel dimunn. LPT pe dedye sa pri-la a tu zelev, profeser, mamb, sinpatizan e tu lasosyasyon e individi dan Repiblik Moris e ayer ki finn asosye zot ar sa lalit pu rekonesans langaz maternel.

input: In the context of the World Kreol Language Day Ledikasyon pu Travayer has sent this letter to the Minister of Education of Mauritius.
target: Dan kad Zurne Mondyal Langaz Kreol Ledikasyon pu Travayer finn avoy sa let la a Minis Ledikasyon, Moris.

input: 153 Main Road, Grand River North West,
target: 153 Main Road, Gran Rivyer Nord West,

input: Minister of Education, Hon. Steve Obeegadoo, Ministry of Education and Science, Phoenix.
target: Minis Ledikasyon, Minister Ledikasyon ek Syans, Phoenix.

input: We are writing this letter to you about the medium used in schools.
target: Nu pe ekrir u lor kestyon medyom lanseynman dan lekol.

input: We would like you to take this letter as a formal notice that your language policy is harming children.
target: U kapav konsider let-la kuma enn avertisman parski ou polisi lor langaz pe fer ditor bann zanfan.

input: You have been in charge of the Ministry of Education for the past three whole years now.
target: U finn ansarz Minister Ledikasyon pandan 3 an.

input: As the Minister in charge of education, you are responsible for children who go to school in Mauritius, Rodrigues, and Agalega.
target: Antan ki Minis ansarz Ledikasyon, u ki responsab zanfan ki al lekol Moris, Rodrig, Agalega.

input: In particular you are now legally even more directly liable for any harm that children come to, once education has become compulsory, and after your recent hard-hitting campaign to force parents to send their children to school.
target: An partikilye u legalman responsab asterla, apre ki ledikasyon finn vinn obligatwar e apre u kanpayn pu obliz paran avoy zot zanfan lekol.

input: Your Department therefore doesn't provide education only to parents who choose to send their children to school now, but actually compels parents to send their children to school, failing which you can bring criminal charges against them.
target: U Departman pa zis furni ledikasyon a paran ki swazir pu avoy zot zanfan lekol, me lalwa asterla obliz paran avoy zot zanfan lekol.

input: It is, thus, imperative that school does not do any harm to children.
target: Alor, fode pa lekol fer zanfan ditor.

input: If children do suffer harm from attending school, whether the harm is inflicted on purpose or through negligence, or even ignorance, and especially if the harm has long-term effects, it is you that will be liable for damages.
target: Si zame zanfan pe sufer ditor dan lekol, sirtu si ditor la li fer par expre ubyen par neglizans, ek sirtu si ditor la ena lefe a-lonterm, se u ki pu bizin pey reparasyon.

input: And more importantly, it is you that will have been responsible, and thus you who will have this harm on your conscience for the rest of your life.
target: E se u ki pu ena sa ditor la lor u konsyans.

input: Hence, this letter is to warn you that your politics on the medium of education amounts to no less than "linguistic genocide" being perpetrated in schools.
target: Alor, sa let-la se pu averti u ki u politik lor medyom lanseynman li ekivo enn zenosid lingwistik dan lekol.

input: And today, in the context of the World Kreol Language Day, we are making a formal and public appeal to you to stop killing children's mother tongues in school, through the politics of excluding Mauritian Kreol and Mauritian Bhojpuri from schools, thus forcing children to change from their own linguistic group to the group of another.
target: E zordi, dan kad Zurne Mondyal Langaz Kreol, nu pe fer apel a u pu aret tuy langaz maternel zanfan dan lekol atraver u politik exklizyon Kreol Morisyen ek Bhojpuri Morisyen depi lekol, kip e fors zanfan pou sanz depi zot grup lingwistik a enn lot grup.

input: We are formally making an appeal to you to stop making children suffer the severe mental harm that is provoked by the constant insinuation in schools that children's mother tongues are inferior, are of no use or are not real languages.
target: Nu pe formelman fer apel a u pu aret fer zanfan sufer dega mantal inestimab, par konstaman "donn sinnyal" dan lekol ki langaz maternel zanfan li inferyer, li pa itil ubyen li pa enn vre langaz.

input: This letter is to explain to you in detail the harm that you are causing to children in Mauritius.
target: Sa let-la se pu explik an-detay ditor ki u pe fer zanfan Moris.

input: This letter is to explain to you that everywhere in the world all linguists and all human rights activists agree with us when we accuse you of the crime of 'linguistic genocide'.
target: Sa let-la se pu explike ki partu dan lemond tu lingwist, tu militan drwa imen, pu dakor ar nu kan nu akiz u krim ki apel 'zenosid lingwistik'.

input: And once you have been formally informed by this letter, you cannot then continue the same harmful policies.
target: E, si zame u kontinye avek sa mem politik la, mem kan nu finn formelman inform u de u erer.

input: We are writing because maybe you don't know about the genocidal effects of your policies.
target: Nu pe ekrir parski pangar u pa kone.

input: May be in the future you will plead "ignorance".
May be the Government will plead ignorance.
We note that you had announced that you would decide about the use of mother tongue in school after consulting UNESCO.
target: Nu finn note ki u ti anonse ki u pu gete sipa pu servi langaz maternel dan lekol.

input: It depends, you announced, what UNESCO tells you is best.
target: Li depann, u ti anonse, seki UNESCO dir u.

input: Then in an interview in Le Mauricien of Saturday 27th September, you say that UNESCO says that the mother tongue/s must be used.
target: Lerla dan enn intervyu dan Le Mauricien Samdi 27 Septam, u finn dir ki UNESCO dir bizin servi langaz maternel.

input: All experts in the world have been saying this for a very long time now.
target: Tu exper dan lemond dir sa depi lontan.

input: Then, when UNESCO gives you this reply, you change your story. You now announce, in that same interview, that you will not listen to UNESCO.
target: Lerla, kan UNESCO finn dir u sa, u finn anonse dan mem inntervyu ki u pa pu ekut UNESCO kumsamem.

input: You will, instead have two small pilot projects, one school in Mauritius, one in Rodrigues with the maternal language.
target: U pu plito zis fer 2 ti proze pilot, enn lekol Moris, enn Rodrig avek langaz maternel.

input: This means that you intend to continue pretending, though UNESCO has informed you of the contrary, that you are unaware of the harm that school is doing to EVERY CHILD because of an erroneous policy on the use of the medium of education.
target: Alor, sa vedir u pe rod kontiyn pretann, malgre ki UNESCO dir u, ki u pa okuran ditor ki lekol pe fer TU ZANFAN, akoz pe servi medyom lanseynman ki pa bon.

input: The issue of what medium to use in school is not just a question of "Which medium will get children better test results".
target: Medyom lanseynman dan Lekol, li pa zis enn kestyon "Ki medyom pu fer zanfan gayn pli bon rezilta?"

input: Although we should put on record that clearly all studies in the entire world, as you well know, have already proved beyond all doubt that mother tongue instruction produces better results in all subjects, from science to additional languages, from subjects that involve creativity to subject that demand reasoning.
target: Klerman tu letid dan lemond, kuma u byen kone, deza pruve ki langaz maternel kuma langaz lanseynman, li prodir rezilta buku pli bon dan tu size pu tu zanfan, depi syans ziska bann langaz adisyonel, depi size ki inplik kreativite ziska size ki depann lor rezonnman.

input: We have a section on all this research later in this "Open Letter".
target: Nu ena enn seksyon lor tu sa resers la plitar dan sa "Let Uver"-la.

input: What is much more important in the use of mother tongue (and here we are speaking, in the first instance, of Kreol and Bhojpuri) is that it permits all children to develop their intelligence better.
target: Seki pli inportan, se itilizasyon langaz maternel (e isi nu pe koz, an premye lye, Kreol ek Bhojpuri), li permet tu zanfan devlop zot intelizans plis.

input: Their cognitive progress is very much faster and gets to a higher level (throughout the rest of their lives) if they learn through their mother tongue at school.
target: Zot progre kognitif li buku pli bon (pandan tut long lavi) si zot aprann atraver langaz maternel dan lekol.

input: It is not just a question of exam results.
target: Alor, li pa zis anterm rezilta lexame.

input: Human language is a natural capacity that all human beings have.
target: Langaz imen li enn kapasite natirel ki tu imen ena.

input: It is our means, par excellence, of understanding the world around us.
target: Li nu mwayen par-exselans pu nu konpran lemond.

input: Our linguistic capacity develops before we ourselves even realize it in small babies, and then during all their childhood, and on for the rest of their lives.
target: Nu kapasite lingwistik, li devlope depi avan nu mem realiz li dan enn ti-baba, e pandan tut so lanfans, e pandan so lavi net.

input: If we develop a child's mother tongue well, and if there is no policy forbidding or hampering this development, if the child becomes high-level literate, he or she will be able to operate up to a high level, he or she will be able to study to a high level, he or she will be able to make an academic contribution to a high level.
target: Si nu devlop so langaz maternel byen, e si pena kit politik ki vinn antrav so devlopman lingwistik, si li vinn letre ziska enn ot-nivo, li pu kapav fer refleksyon a enn ot-nivo, li pu kapav fer letid a enn ot-nivo, li pu kapav fer enn kontribisyon akademik a enn ot-nivo.

input: There is a world of difference between what in the education profession are called Basic Interpersonal Communicative Skills (BICS) and Cognitive Academic Language Proficiency (CALP).
target: Ena enn mond de diferans ant seki apel Basic Interpersonal Communicative Skills (BICS) ek Cognitive Academic Language Proficiency (CALP).

input: In Mauritius, most children, even those who get as far as University, show signs of having severe problems in cognition, that is to say in CALP.
target: Dan Moris, laplipar zanfan, mem seki ariv Liniversite, temwayn enn problem otur zot aprantisaz kognitif, setadir CALP.

input: A university lecturer attests to this difficulty with her students.
target: Ena profeser liniversite temwayn sa difikilte la avek zot zelev.

input: In a second or even third language, we cannot pretend to outstrip our development in our mother tongue.
target: Dan enn 2yem ek 3yem langaz nu pa kapav vreman "depas" nu devlopman dan nu langaz maternel.

input: And in school, you are responsible for systematically hampering the crucial natural development of children's intelligence through their own mother tongue.
target: E dan lekol, u pe sistematikman antrav devlopman natirel zanfan dan so prop langaz.

input: If we develop this capacity (i.e. high level cognitive and academic proficiency) in our mother tongue, then we will be able to become equally capable in other languages.
target: E si nu devlop sa kapasite-la dan nu langaz maternel, lerla nu kapav vinn egalman kapab dan lezot langaz.

input: This is what is called high-level bilingualism.
target: Se sa ki apel "bileng" a enn ot-nivo.

input: It means the mother tongue to a high level, plus another language that can develop to the same high level, too, that is to the level of CALP.
target: Langaz maternel a enn ot-nivo, plis enn lot langaz, ki, si langaz maternel a enn ot-nivo, kapav vinn a enn ot-nivo, li osi, setadir onivo CALP.

input: High-level trilinguals are those who have developed their mother tongue to a high level plus two other languages to the same high level.
target: Trileng vedir langaz maternel a enn ot-nivo plis de lezot langaz.

input: High-level multilingualism means the ability to operate at a high level in the mother tongue and then in many other languages almost as well.
target: Miltileng vedir langaz maternel a enn ot-nivo plis buku lezot langaz.

input: Your school system, M. Obeegadoo, is continuing making our children "demi-lingual".
target: U sistem lekol, M. Obeegadoo, pe fer zanfan kontinye vinn "demi-leng".

input: What do we mean by this "demi-lingual"?
You are making children suffer serious incapacity as a result of harming the natural development of high-level linguistic skills in any language.
target: U pe fer zanfan vinn inkapab debruye a ot-nivo dan okenn langaz.

input: What we are accusing you of is of preventing children from developing high-level cognitive and academic proficiency.
target: Seki nu pe akiz u se anpes zanfan gayn enn devlopman a-ot nivo dan ninport ki langaz.

input: If somebody is "mono-lingual" to a high level (that is, they have CALP only in Kreol or only in Bhojpuri), that person will still, theoretically, be able to get along in terms of cognitive and academic proficiency.
target: Si kikenn "ini-leng" a-ot nivo (setadir ena CALP an zis Kreol ubyen zis Bhojpuri), li pu kapav debruye anterm kognitif ek akademik.

input: But, more to the good, he or she can then become a high level bilingual or trilingual (CALP), provided that he has reached a high level in his or her mother tongue.
target: E, pli bon ankor, pu ki li kapav vinn bi-leng ubyen tri-leng a ot-nivo (CALP), fode li ena enn ot-nivo DAN SO LANGAZ MATERNEL osi.

input: In LPT, as far as we are concerned, we are in favour of all our children becoming high level multilingual.
target: Dan LPT, kanta nu, nu anfaver zanfan vinn milti-leng a ot-nivo.

input: If someone does not develop his linguistic skills in his mother tongue up to a high level, then, after formal schooling, it can take up to an additional nine years of formal education to compensate for the loss of the reduced development of the child who has been subjected to education not in his mother tongue.
target: Si kikenn pa devlop so skil lingwistik dan so langaz maternel ziska enn ot-nivo, lerla, apre lekol formel, li kapav pran ziska 9-an ledikasyon formel adisyonel pu sey konble seki finn perdi, kan finn redwir devlopman enn zanfan ziska nivo so konpreansyon enn langaz ki pa so langaz maternel.

input: We also accuse certain high up officers at the Ministry and at the MIE and some academics at the University of having a fawning attitude towards you as Minister of Education.
target: Nu osi akiz serten o-kad Minister ek o-kad MIE e akademik Liniversite konpleyzan anver Minis Ledikasyon.

input: They pretend that they think that Kreol and Bhojpuri are not good as the medium because they "get the signal" from politicians in power, like you, that this is what they must say to be in your good books.
target: Zot pretann ki langaz Kreol ek Bhojpuri pa bon pu servi kuma medyom, akoz zot "gayn sinnyal" depi bann politisyen opuvwar ki zot bizin dir sa.

input: But, when Prof. Derek Bickerton was here, at a seminar with high-up officers, all of them agree with him vocally that the only possible medium of instruction is the mother tongue.
target: Kan Prof. Derek Bickerton ti isi, kan li fer seminar ar bann o-kad, zot tu pretann ki zot dakor net ar li. Li dir bizin servi langaz Kreol kuma medyom.

input: The same thing when Prof. Tove Skutnabb-Kangas was here.
target: Kan Prof. Tove Skutnabb-Kangas ti isi.

input: All sorts of lecturers and top academics agree with her when she says that Kreol and Bhojpuri must be medium of instruction.
target: Tu profeser ek gran akademik pretann ki zot dakor ar li. Li osi dir bizin servi langaz Kreol kuma medyom.

input: When Dr. Neville Alexander was here, no linguistics academic in Mauritius challenged him, when he said we must use the mother tongue.
target: Kan Dr. Neville Alexander isi, la osi, okenn akademik lingwis dan Moris pa challenj li kan li dir bizin servi langaz Kreol ek Bhojpuri kuma medyom.

input: There is a simple reason for this.
target: Ena enn rezon byen sinp pu sa.

input: No linguist anywhere in the world can say in front of a panel of his colleague linguists, that it is advisable to use a language which is not mother tongue as medium in schools.
target: Okenn lingwis dan lemond pa kapav dir divan so bann koleg lingwis ki li konseyab pu servi bann langaz ki pa langaz maternel kuma medyom dan lekol.

input: The prejudice against the Kreol and Bhojpuri languages, that they are supposedly inferior languages, comes directly from colonial times, when the colonists and their academia, the civil servants and even the religious hierarchy, believed and spread the false belief that these languages are inferior.
target: Bann presize kumkwa langaz Kreol ek Bhojpuri inferyer, zot sorti lepok kolonyal, kan bann kolon ek zot akademya, zot servis sivil, mem zot yerarsi relizye, ti pe mintenir ki sa bann langaz la inferyer parski dimunn ki koz zot, zot inferyer.

input: Do you, Minister, still think this?
target: Eski u, M. le Minis, ankor pans sa u?

input: Or you just apply your politics as if you still think this?
target: Ubyen u zis aplik enn politik ki baze lor la?

input: Sir, imposing either totally or partially unknown (or erroneously grasped) languages as medium in education flies in the face of all established pedagogical principles that have been established and continue to be established.
target: M. le Minis, inpozisyon langaz inkoni ek malkoni kuma medyom anseynman dan lekol li al kont tu prinsip drwa imen ki finn etablir, e pe kontinye devlope.

input: No child's mother tongue is inferior to any other language.
target: Langaz maternel nu zanfan li napa inferyer a okenn lot langaz.

input: We say that your Department is, by the following policies and practices, giving the clear and harmful signal that Kreol and Bhojpuri-speaking children's language is inferior.
target: Nu dir ki u Departman pe donn sinnyal ki Kreol ek Bhojpuri zot inferyer.

input: Absence of any text books in either Kreol or Bhojpuri.
target: Labsans total text-book dan Kreol ubyen Bhojpuri.

input: Failure to teach even literacy and numeracy through Kreol or Bhojpuri.
target: Labsans lanseynman literesi ek nimeresi dan Kreol ubyen Bhojpuri.

input: Absence of books to read, failure to develop songs and games, in Kreol and Bhojpuri.
target: Labsans liv pu lir, labsans devlopman sante, zwe ek lezot zuti pedagozik dan Kreol ek Bhojpuri.

input: Absence of any examinations in Kreol or Bhojpuri
target: Labsans total lexame an medyom Kreol ubyen Bhojpuri.

input: Absence of Kreol and Bhojpuri as subjects in schools.
target: Labsans Kreol ek Bhojpuri kuma size dan lekol.

input: Tendency, because of your language policy, for teachers to transmit to children a feeling of disaffection for their parents' language.
target: Tandans, akoz u politik langaz, ankuraz profeser transmet a zanfan enn mepri pu langaz zot paran.

input: Failure to train teachers in how to use the children's own language so that children understand with any precision in class, and express themselves with the precision necessary.
target: Labsans antrennman profeser lor kimanyer servi langaz maternel pu ki zanfan gayn konpreansyon avek presizyon dan klas, e ki zanfan kapav exprim li avek presizyon dan klas.

input: Tendency for children to be forced into rote learning as a last resort, in the effort to continue to exclude Kreol and Bhojpuri.
target: Tandans fors zanfan pu anprann dan enn fason peroke, purvi li pa an Kreol ubyen Bhojpuri.

input: Tendency to flaunt all pedagogical principles by creating an immense and useless social distance between the child's home and the school, by imposing a language hierarchy.
target: Tandans al kont prinsip pedagozik pu redwir distans ant aprantisaz lakaz ek lekol.

input: Tendency to increase the trauma of school and to and cause moral damage to children, and this, in turn; works to hamper full development during schooling, and even long after a child has left school.
target: U pena traka si ena tromatism mantal ek moral lor zanfan, ki, a son tur responsab pu blok devlopman pandan lekolaz ek mem kan fini kit lekol.

input: Tendency to flaunt the basic pedagogical principle of starting with the known and moving to the unknown. Instead you encourage the ridiculous practice of using the unknown to learn the unknown.
target: U polisi al kont prinsip kumans avek seki koni, al ver linkoni. U fer zafer ridikil kot anseyn seki pa koni atraver linkoni.

input: Tendency to consciously increase the linguistic distance between teacher and books, on one hand, and the pupil, on the other.
target: U polisi, li konsyaman, ogmant distans sosyal ant profeser ek liv, enn kote, ek zanfan, lot kote.

input: Mr. Minister, you cannot just continue with the old colonial interpretation of language rights.
target: M. Minis Nepli kapav kontiyn avek interpretasyon kolonyal lor drwa lingwistik.

input: Your department must also begin to show a little respect for the science of linguistics, which has, for over fifty years now, proven that Kreol and Bhojpuri are the equals of any other language.
target: U departman bizin kumans respekte lasyans lingwistik ki fini pruve ki langaz Kreol ek Bhojpuri egal a ninport ki lot langaz.

input: If you do not, you are showing disregard for the elementary rights of the child.
target: Sinon, u pe antrav drwa elemanter zanfan.

input: Some aspects of linguistic human rights are even already in the Mauritian Constitution and in the International Human Rights Conventions, even if they are, so far, still in an embryonic form.
target: Serten sa bann drwa la deza inskrir dan Konstitisyon Moris ek dan bann Konvansyon International, mem si dan enn fason ki tuzur anbriyoner.

input: It is in the spirit of all the human rights legislation that all human languages are "equal".
target: Li dan enn lespri drwa imen ki tu langaz, depi lontan, finn deklare 'egal'.

input: This is independent of their written status, the number of people who speak them, whether they are spoken or sign languages, or any other factor whatsoever.
target: Sa li indepandan de si langaz-la ekrit ubyen non, indepandan de si zot oral ubyen siyn, indepandan de komye dimunn koz li.

input: We would like to point out that Kreol and Bhojpuri, incidentally, are amongst the "big" languages of the planet.
target: Dayer e Kreol e Bhojpuri zot parmi bann "gran" langaz dan lemond, enn zafer ki kapav.

input: It is in this spirit of human rights that we must stop the colonial prejudice that allowed education to be dispensed in languages the children do not speak naturally.
target: Se dan sa lespri drwa imen-la ki nu bizin aret bann prezize kolonyal e kumans dispans ledikasyon dan fason ki pli bon pu zanfan e ki pli bon pu limanite.

input: Through generations of heroic struggles against colonization and through the struggle for Independence, we have gained a number of Constitutional Rights.
target: Atraver lalit eroik lamas dimunn kont kolonyalism e dan prosesis lalit pu lindepandans, nu finn benefisye enn seri drwa konstitisyonel.

input: Section 12, for example, of the Constitution protects and guarantees our freedom of expression, which includes the right to receive and impart information and spread ideas and information without any interference. Using the wrong language is an impediment to free expression.
target: Seksyon 12 Konstitisyon protez e garanti nu liberte dexpresyon, ki inklir drwa pu resevwar linformasyon ek konesans e pu propaz lide ek linformasyon san okenn antrav.

input: Internationally, the struggle for children to be free to learn through their maternal language has, so far, culminated in Article 13 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.
target: Onivo international, lalit pu zanfan servi lang maternel dan lekol finn debus lor lartik 13 Konvansyon UN lor Drwa Zanfan.

input: This Convention, ratified by States including the Mauritian State (in 1990), assures children the right to education, and the freedom to seek, receive and spread information and ideas orally and in written and printed form without any discrimination.
target: Sa konvansyon ki bann Leta, ikonpri u guvernman, finn ratifye an 1990, asire ki drwa tu zanfan a ledikasyon respekte, e ki tu zanfan lib pu rod, resevwar e propaz linformasyon ek lide oralman, an ekri ubyen inprime, san okenn diskriminasyon.

input: Despite this, you continue in your discriminatory policy of blocking the children's use of their own language.
target: Malgre sa, u pe persiste avek u politik langaz ki atak devlopman mantal ek blok lintelizans nu bann zanfan lor enn baz diskriminatwar.

input: Sir, we remind you that in 1994, the United Nations Committee on Economic Social and Cultural Rights (ECOSOC) in its Report on Mauritius noted with concern that Kreol and Bhojpuri, the languages used by a vast majority of the population, were not being used in the Mauritian education system, and that the Government was actively discouraging the use of these languages in all its institutions.
target: M. le Minis, nu pu rapel u ki an 1994, linstans UN, Committee on Economic Social and Cultural Rights (ECOSOC) dan so rapor lor Moris ti note avek inkyetid ki Kreol ek Bhojpuri sel 2 langaz ki koze par gran mazorite popilasyon, pa pe servi dan sistem ledikasyon Moris e ki Guvernman pe aktivman dekuraz ki servi zot dan tu linstitisyon.

input: Are you going to continue to flaunt the concern of this august body?
target: Eski u pu kontiyn res parey mem, insansib a inkyetid ki finn exprime par enn gran linstans Internasyonal?

input: In 1996, the UN Human Rights Committee under the Convention on Civil and Political Rights in its Report on Mauritius recommended that measures be taken to at once begin to publish educational materials, especially for children, in the vernaculars, i.e. Kreol and Bhojpuri.
target: An 1996, Human Rights Committee UN ki tom su Konvansyon lor Drwa Sivil ek Politik, ti rekomande dan so rapor ki Moris pran mezir neseser pu pibliye materyel edikatif sirtu pu zanfan dan langaz vernakiler, setadir Kreol ek Bhojpuri.

input: Your predecessors did nothing about this - with the notable exception of Mr. Kadress Pillay, who in the first draft of his Plan, did address the issue, but later capitulated.
target: Ziska zordi ni u ni u predeseser pa finn get sa kestyon-la avek tu so serye neseser, apar M. Kadress Pillay dan premye draf so Plan, avan li kaptile.

input: Sir, you will remember that the May 1975 students strike was a rebellion whose main thrust was for the decolonization of education, and for the use of Kreol in schools.
target: M. le Minis, u pu devet rapel lagrev etidyan an Me 75 etidyan ti desann lor lari pu dimann dekolonizasyon ledikasyon, e pu dimann servi langaz Kreol dan lekol.

input: The strike did have one positive effect, when it directly brought in free secondary education, but otherwise the degree of colonization in education is still overwhelming, especially as concerns the medium of instruction.
target: Sa lagrev la finn debus direkteman lor ledikasyon gratis. Me viktwar la ankor res inkonple san dekolonizasyon sistem ledikasyon.

input: At the level of the African continent, the process of decolonization is more advanced. In 1987 the Language Plan of Action, initiated by the OUA (now incorporated into the African Union, one of its documents) spoke out for the use of African languages as official language and as medium in education.
target: Onivo kontinan Lafrik, prosesis dekolonizasyon finn pran diferan form. An 1987 Language Plan of Action, inisye par OUA (ki zordi finn vinn Linyon Afrikin ki finn adopte Language Plan of Action ek lezot rezolisyon OUA) koz anfaver itilizasyon langaz Afrikin kuma langaz ofisyel e kom veikil linstriksyon dan ledikasyon.

input: Mauritius, which is a signatory to the Language Plan of Action, has an undertaking, therefore to introduce Kreol and Bhojpuri as medium.
target: Pu Moris, ki siynater sa plan daksyon la, sa vedir ki ti bizin itiliz langaz Kreol ek Bhojpuri kuma medyom instriksyon.

input: But the Government has never respected its commitment.
target: Zame guvernman Moris finn respekte sa langazman la.

input: Today you are announcing the construction of schools all over the country, which is a good thing, and you are imposing compulsory education, while at the same time continuing the measure of forcing a foreign medium on Kreolophone and Bhojpuri phone pupils.
target: Zordi u pe anons konstriksyon lekol partu, u pe inpoz lekol obligatwar lor zanfan, me u pe ranvway desizyon lor kestyon itilizasyon langaz maternel dan ledikasyon.

input: Your actions make you act against the spirit of both the Constitution and the International Conventions adhered to by Mauritius. And of course, you continue to harm generations of children, generations of peoples.
target: Par sa manyer azir la, u konplis pu aplik enn politik lingwistik dan lekol ki pa konpatib avek lespri Konstitisyon e ki kont tu bann Konvansyon Internasyonal ki Moris finn adere. U konplis pu fer ditor imans a nu bann zanfan.

input: The State is, in fact, hindering our people in the natural expression of our languages, Bhojpuri and Kreol. It is this that makes the Government responsible, through the schools in particular, for a crime against humanity, the crime of linguistic genocide. That is what we are accusing you of, Mr. Minister.
target: Alor, Leta pe antrav enn lepep dan lexpresyon natirel so prop langaz, Bhojpuri ek Kreol, e Guvernman pe fer enn krim kont limanite. Ala seki nu pe akiz u, M. Minis.

input: Any authority or any individual in a position of power that hinders a people in the natural expression of his language, is responsible for linguistic genocide, and we will explain exactly how. There are two instances. Firstly, linguistic genocide is when the State forces children to abandon the language of their parents, through, for example, a wrong language policy at school.
target: Ninport ki individi avek puvwar ki antrav lexpresyon lib langaz natirel enn grup dimunn, li kupab de zenosid. Zenosid lingwistik se kan Leta obliz zanfan abandonn langaz so paran, par exanp atraver politik langaz dan lekol, ubyen kan li infliz ditor mantal lor tu bann zanfan ki koz enn langaz parktikilye.

input: Government is forcing children to acquire additional languages in a way that is called "subtractive", and it is this "subtracting" of the natural language of our people, that causes the Government to be guilty of "linguistic genocide".
target: Guvernman pe fors zanfan aprann dan enn fason "retire" (an Angle, dir sa "subtractively") e par fer sa, Guvernman li kupab de "zenosid lingwistik".

input: When we use the term "linguistic genocide", we are using United Nations definition on linguistic genocide, crime against humanity.
target: Kan nu dir "zenosid lingwistik", nu pe servi definisyon Nasyon Zini lor zenosid lingwistik, krim kont limanite.

input: Children are learning the language that school teaches at the cost of the mother tongue and this represent linguistic genocide, because it is removing a child from his or her group (Kreolophone or Bhojpuriphone linguistic group) and placing him or her in a different linguistic group (Francophone or Anglophone).
target: Donk zanfan aprann langaz ki lekol montre odetriman zot lang maternel e sa reprezant zenosid lingwistik, parski li enn travay ki evre dan sans pu tir enn zanfan depi enn grup (grup lingwistik Kreolofonn ubyen Bhojpurifonn) e met li dan enn lot grup lingwistik (Frankofonn ubyen Anglofonn).

input: Article II (e) of the United Nations Convention on Genocide reads: "Genocide is forcibly transferring children of a group to another group".
target: Lartik II (e) dan Konvansyon Nasyon Zini dir: "Zenosid se kan obliz zanfan enn grup transfer ver enn lot grup". Savedir

input: Government is forcibly transferring children from their own group to another linguistic group through education of children being dispensed in a dominant and foreign language, English and French, at the expense of their mother tongues, Bhojpuri and Kreol, as medium of education.
target: Guvernman pe obliz zanfan transfer depi zot prop grup a enn lot grup atraver politik lingwisitik ek kiltirel parski ledikasyon zanfan pe fer dan langaz dominan ek etranze, Angle e Franse, e napa dan zot lang maternel Bhojpuri e Kreol kuma medyom lanseynman.

input: Linguistic genocide means prohibiting the use of language of the people, either in every day life, or as concerns us in this letter, in schools, or prohibiting the printing, circulation or publication in the language of the people.
target: Zenosid lingwistik vedir anpes servi langaz enn lepep dan lavi tulezur, ubyen, seki konsern nu dan sa let-la, dan lekol, ubyen met antors a imprime, distribye, ubyen pibliye dan langaz sa lepep la.

input: Government is responsible for this "linguistic genocide" by refusing to prepare and publish books for school in Bhojpuri and Kreol.
target: Guvernman pe kontribiye dan sa "zenosid lingwistik" par refiz prepar ek pibliye liv lekol dan Bhojpuri e Kreol.

input: Government is prohibiting the use of Bhojpuri and Kreol by failing to make it an official language, while imposing other official languages in school.
target: Guvernman pe anpes servi Bhojpuri e Kreol par pa fer li vinn langaz ofisyel, anmemtan inpoz lezot lang ofisyel dan lekol.

input: Bhojpuri and Kreol do not have official status nor political status and are not used as the principal medium in education.
target: Bhojpuri e Kreol pena stati ofisyel, stati politik, e pa servi li kuma medyom prinsipal dan ledikasyon.

input: Last year, Ledikasyon pu Travayer invited a linguist of international reputation, Prof. Tove Skutnabb-Kangas, to give a Public Lecture on this theme, and this is what she said: "If a child does not learn in his mother tongue and is forced to learn in a foreign language (what you are doing), this will do serious mental harm to the child."
target: Lane dernyer Ledikasyon pu Travayer ti invit enn lingwis de renome internasyonal, Prof. Tove Skutnabb-Kangas, e ala seki li finn dir: "Si enn zanfan pa aprann dan so langaz maternel ek fors li pu aprann dan enn langaz etranze (se seki u pe fer), sa pu fer enn ditor mantal grav a enn zanfan.”

input: Now we are going to take three examples in Mauritius, our country, where many intellectuals congratulate themselves that "we are a country of multi-lingual people", but who would do better to admit that your policies are making us a "country of demi-lingual people".
target: Nu pran trwa temwaynaz dan Moris asterla, nu pei. Buku dimunn kontant zot dekrir Moris kuma "enn pei bann miltileng", me avek lantetman u Departman, nu plito "enn pei bann demileng".

input: We hope that these three brief testimonies will help you and your advisors understand the gravity of your error, Minister Sir.
target: Nu espere sa bann temwayaz pu ede u pu konpran gravite erer u ek u bann konseye pe fer, Misye Minis.

input: In my family we all speak Kreol, and my mother and father never spoke French or English at home.
target: Dan mo fami nu tu koz langaz Kreol, ek zame ni mo mama, ni mo papa pa finn koz Franse ni Angle dan lakaz.

input: My father never went to school. He is a thinking and intelligent man, who can hold conversation in Kreol, English and French.
target: Dayer mo papa pa finn al lekol ditu, e purtan li enn dimunn byen reflesi, byen intelizan. Li kapav tini enn konversayon an Kreol, Angle ek Franse.

input: As if he is an example of "additive" apprenticeship of languages.
I went to school in Richelieu Cité for my first two school years, and every thing went well.
target: Mo ti al lekol Site Richelieu pandan 2 premye lane lekol, e tu finn pas byen.

input: When my parents moved house to Port Louis, I had to change school.
target: Kan mo paran finn demenaze pu vinn res Porlwi, mo finn bizin sanz lekol.
Deza li enn bulversman pu sanz lekol, me li ti inevitab.

input: One day, in Standard 3, I felt sick at school hours.
target: Enn zour, dan 3yem, mo ti santi mwa malad enn sel ku dan ler klas.

input: I urgently needed to go to the toilet.
target: Mo ti santi mo anvi al twalet irzan.

input: When I went to ask the teacher permission to go to the toilet, she said no because I must address her in French.
target: Kan mo finn al dir mo profeser ki mo anvi al twalet, li finn dir mwa ki li pa pu les mwa ale, parski mo bizin adres avek li dan langaz Franse.

input: She told me that I would have to write 200 lines of "Je dois m'adresser a mon Miss an Francais."
target: Li finn anons mwa ki mo bizin ekrir 200 fwa "Je dois m'adresser a mon Miss an Franse."

input: That day, when I was not permitted to go to toilet, I defecated in my clothes.
target: Sa zur la, kan li finn anpes mwa al twalet, mo finn sufer enn tromatis terib, mo finn tata dan mo linz.

input: For the next year, I was bullied and mocked for two things: that my French was poor and that I had "tata dan lenz".
target: Ek pandan enn an dan klas, buku zanfan enpe meskin, finn res sikann mwa, enn parski mo pa koz Franse, ek de parski mo finn tata dan mo linz.

input: My father was very angry and wanted to take me out of school.
target: Mo papa ti telman ankoler ki li ti pe rod tir mwa lekol.

input: And sometimes, until today I wonder if that would not have been better for me, because I remained miserable at school right through to college.
target: E parfwa mo panse vomye li ti tir mwa lekol, akoz mo ti res byen malere dan lekol, ziska kolez.

input: I am, like my father, self-taught, really.
target: Mo osi, kuma mo papa, mo plito enn oto-didak.

input: In French,, when I was in Standard 6, the teacher (a man called Mr. I.D.) made us to this remarkable exercise, supposedly to develop our capacity to speak French with a good accent.
target: Dan klas Franse, kan mo ti dan 6yem, Profeser Franse (enn apele Misye I.D.) dan klas Franse, ti pe fer enn lekzersis pu swadizan devlop kapasite pu koz byen Franse avek enn bon aksan.

input: He made us put a pencil inside our mouths, cross-wise, like a horses' bit, and then read aloud.
target: Li ti dabor fer enn lekzersis ki konsiste ar pran enn kreyon papye, ek met li atraver nu labus, kuma enn brid, e lerla fer nu lir enn teks a ot-vwa.

input: With a pencil in your month like that you look like an animal being trained.
target: Kan u ena kreyon papye dan labus u vreman paret kuma pe dres enn zanimo.

input: It was terrible exercise, it was violence against children.
target: Sa ti enn lekzersis byen penib, li ti enn vyolans kont zanfan.

input: When I was in Standard I, my teacher told us that we must speak French so as to seek permission to go to toilet.
target: Kan mo ti dan fers, mo mis ti dir nu bizin koz Franse pu nu dimande pu al twalet.

input: This made me unhappy in class.
These three testimonies show, to what extremes this "mental harm" can go.
target: Alor, sa temwaynaz la montre ziska ki pwen, dan bann ka extrem, sa "ditor mantal" kapav ale.

input: But in fact, every day, when your policies serve to insult children's mother tongues, it, too, is extreme "mental harm" being caused.
target: Me anfet, tulezur, kan u insilte  langaz maternel enn zanfan, li enn "ditor mantal extrem", li osi.

input: Government is continuing to encourage English and French to be "killer languages" in Mauritius, instead of additional advantages.
target: Guvernman pe permet langaz Angle ek Franse res gran "langaz asasin" (killer languages) dan Moris.

input: English and French are the two biggest "killer languages" in the world.
target: Angle ek Franse zot bann pli gran "langaz asasin" dan lemond.

input: This is because of your policy to force children to learn these languages subtractively, i.e. at the cost of the mother tongue, rather than additively, i.e. in addition to the mother tongue.
target: Parski guvernman pe fors zanfan aprann "gran" langaz dan "gran" langaz, par system "retire", setadir odetriman lang maternel, plito ki dan enn fason "aditif", setadir anplis de lang maternel.

input: Now that we are making this grave accusation against your policies, it will be clear to you that we are going to step up our campaign for the use of Kreol and Bhojpuri in schools, and for other languages to be introduced additively, so that we can put an end to this linguistic genocide.
target: Avek sa akizasyon zenosid ki nu pe porte kont u, li evidan ki nu pu akseler nu kanpayn pu servi langaz Kreol ek Bhojpuri dan lekol pu lanseynman. E pu met fin a seki pe ariv istaz, avek ledikasyon obligatwar, enn zenosid lingwistik.

input: Research and studies on medium and schooling.
target: Resers ek letid lor langaz ek lekolaz.

input: Since 1953 UNESCO has publicly recognized that "It is axiomatic that the best medium for teaching a child is his (or her) mother tongue".
target: Depi 1953 UNESCO ti rekonet piblikman ki "li enn evidans ki meyer medyom pu servi pu montre zanfan li atraver so langaz maternel".

input: This UNESCO position is based on scientific research by expert pedagogues of international repute.
target: Sa pozisyon UNESCO-la li baze lor rezilta resers ki exper e pedagog onivo internasyonal finn fer.

input: Right up today, UNESCO has continued re-affirming this position.
target: Ziska zordi UNESCO ankor mintenir sa mem pozisyon-la.

input: Recent studies have again and again continued to confirm the UNESCO stand. All thinking experts are in agreement.
target: Buku letid pli resan finn konfirm seki UNESCO e seki tu pedagog ki reflesi ti pe deza dir anfaver servi langaz maternel pu montre.

input: Let us look at the major findings of the recent research.
target: Les nu get enn rezime konklizyon mazer ki kapav tire depi sa bann nuvo letid-la.

input: 1. All researchers agree that use of the mother tongue, especially in the first years of schooling, is unquestionably of benefit to the cognitive development of the child.
target: 1. Tu serser dakor ki kan servi langaz maternel pu montre zanfan, sirtu dan zot bann premye lane lekol primer, li benefik pu zot devlopman kognitif.

input: The conclusions of the research by Nadine Dutcher read: "The most important conclusion is that, when learning is the goal, including that of learning a second language, the child's first language should be used as the medium of instruction in the early years of schooling.”
target: Konklizyon pli inportan ki Nadine Dutcher finn tire dan so rapor lor bann lexperyans lor itilizasyon enn premye langaz (ubyen langaz maternel) ek enn dezyem langaz dan lekol, dir: " Kan u bi se pu montre, inkli montre enn dezyem langaz, bizin servi premye langaz zanfan kuma medyom lanseynman dan bann premye lane lekol ".

input: For optimum results, the first language should be continued as the language of instruction through primary school.
target: Pu enn rezilta optimal, bizin kontiyn servi premye langaz zanfan dan primer kan zanfan-la pe anprann enn dezyem langaz.

input: If feasible, the first language of the student should be included among the subjects in secondary school when the language of instruction has changed.
target: Si li posib, bizin inklir zelev so premye langaz kuma size dan segonder kan medyom lanseynman finn sanze.

input: The first language is essential for the initial teaching of reading, and for comprehension of subject matter.
target: Premye lang li esansyel pu introdir lektir, e konpreansyon konteni size ki pe anseyne.

input: 2. Many researchers openly claim, and they almost all agree implicitly, that mother tongue education gives the child self-confidence and a stable identity.
target: 2. Enn parti bann serser afirme klerman, e laplipar lezot rekonet inplisitman, ki ledikasyon atraver langaz maternel donn zanfan plis konfyans dan zot mem e dan zot idantite.

input: Children are known to participate more and with more enthusiasm in class if the mother tongue is used.
target: Zanfan partisip plis e avek pli buku lantuzyas dan klas si servi lang maternel.

input: The degree of personal assurance and critical engagement with teachers is greater.
target: Zot degre lasirans personel e zot langazman kritik avek zot profeser ogmante.

input: Studies in 64 different classes in Mozambique in 1997 and in two Provinces of Bolivia where children speak Quechua have confirmed this.
target: Bann letid dan 64 klas lekol dan Mozanbik an 1997 ek dan 2 Departman kot zanfan koz Quechua dan Bolivi finn demontre mem rezilta.

input: 3. Development at school in the mother tongue helps in the acquisition of new languages.
target: 3. Enn bon baz konesans dan langaz maternel fasilit aprantisaz lezot langaz.

input: The research shows that if children are forced to learn through a language that they are not at ease in or do not master, that they suffer immense disadvantages and that the disadvantage can almost never be compensated for later.
target: Dapre resers, si zanfan pe oblize anprann atraver enn langaz ki zot pa kone, zot ena enn gro dezavantaz e zot pa reysi ratrape apre.

input: The clearest study is that of David Ramirez in the USA.
target: Letid ki pli explicit lor la li seki David Ramirez finn fer dan Lamerik.

input: He did an eight-year longitudinal study, 1983 to 1991 in 51 different primary schools in the States of California, Texas, Florida, New York and New Jersey.
target: Li enn letid longitidinal lor enn period 8 an, ant 1983 a 1991. Sa letid-la konsern 51 lekol primer dan distrik California, Texas, Florid, New York ek New Jersey.

input: In all 2,000 students whose mother tongue was Spanish took part in the study, which also involved their parents.
target: Antou 2,000 zelev ki zot premye lang Espanyol ti partisip dan sa letid-la, inkli zot paran.

input: The aim was to compare three groups of children relative to how they were using Spanish and English in education.
target: Bi letid-la sete pu gete ki ariv bann zanfan, ki zot premye lang napa Angle, kan montre zot inikman an Angle ubyen kan servi Angle e Espanyol pu montre.

input: The primary schools where the studies were conducted were divided into 3 categories:
target: Bann lekol primer kot ti fer sa letid-la ti divize an 3 kategori:

input: (i) Where at school the children were taught entirely through English;
target: (i) lekol kot montre an Angle net;

input: (ii) Where at school the children had up to 40 minutes a day until the end of the second or 3rd year of primary school;
target: (ii) lekol kot montre dan langaz maternel mwins ki 40 minit par zur ziska lafen 2yem ubyen 3yem lane;

input: (iii) Where at school the mother tongue was used as medium for at least 40% of the time every day until the end of 6th year of primary school.
target: (iii) lekol kot montre dan langaz maternel pandan plis ki 40% lazurne ziska lafen 6yem lane.

input: This study showed that the longer the mother tongue was used, the better the child performed academically.
target: Rezilta sa letid-la demontre ki pli lontan u gard itilizasyon langaz maternel dan lekol pli li bon pu zanfan e pli zot performans bon.

input: Those who learnt through the mother tongue until the 6th Standard did much better than the other two groups, even in the English language itself. The children not only caught up with the Anglophone children, but tended to do better than them.
target: Zelev ki ti anprann dan zot langaz maternel  ziska 6yem pa zis zot ratrap byen vit lor nivo Angle seki ti anprann an Angle net, me zot nivo dan Angle mem (ki anfet zot dezyem langaz ) ti pli elve ki premye grup e so tandans ti pe kontiyne progrese.

input: Other studies in Haiti, for example show that Creolophone children who learnt through Haitian Creole in school developed a better competence in French, their 2nd language, than those who learnt through French, plus naturally they did better in cognition and other non-language subjects.
target: Lezot letid ki finn fer dan Haiti demontre mem zafer. Zelev Kreolofonn ki ti anprann dan langaz Kreol Haityin dan lekol, ti akerir otan kompetans dan 2yem langaz (dan sa ka-la, Franse) ki zelev ki finn expoze zis ar Franse, plis natirelman plis konpetans dan bann size apar langaz.

input: What the studies show is that the development of a child's mother tongue is more important for later acquisition of a second language, than using a second language for teaching.
target: Enn zanfan so devlopman dan so langaz maternel li pli inportan pu akizasyon enn 2yem langaz ki introdiksyon boner dan lekol, a dezyem langaz-la.

input: Many people used to think that using the medium of a second language (say English or French) was an advantage, and that the earlier this started the better.
target: Buku dimunn ti panse ki li enn lavantaz pu expoz enn zanfan a enn dezyem langaz dan lekol e zot ti panse ki pli li boner e pli li lontan u fer sa, pli li bon.

input: But all the studies only go to prove that this was a myth.
target: Buku letid finn vinn kas sa mit-la.

input: A famous study in Nigeria showed that children who speak Yoruba and who were taught through their mother tongue from 1st to 6th Standard do much better than the children taught through English, in all subjects, including in English.
target: Kuma letid ki finn fer dan Nigeria ki finn truve ki zelev ki koz Yoruba e ki finn anprann dan sa langaz-la depi so premye lane primer ziska sizyem ena pli bon performans dan tu kalite test aptitid dan dezyem lang, ki inklir Angle.

input: We read the same results from a study by the Guatemala National Program for Bilingual Education. Children taught in their mother tongue have a better performance in all subjects including second language learning.
target: Mem rezilta finn gayne dan Guatemala National Program for Bilingual Education ki finn montre kimanyer zelev ki ti anprann dan zot langaz maternel ti ena meyer performans dan bann test dan dezyem lang ki zelev ki ti anprann selman dan sa dezyem lang-la.

input: An example from Papua New Guinea
target: Enn lexanp depi Papua New Guinea

input: The population in Papua New Guinea is around 5 million, and it is the country, which has the highest number of languages in the world.
target: Popilasyon Papua New Guinea li anviron 5 milyon, e li pei ki ena pli gran nomb langaz dan lemond.

input: There are more than 850 different languages. Before, education was mostly through the medium of English.
target: Ena plis ki 850 diferan langaz. Oparavan, ledikasyon ti prinsipalman atraver medyom Angle.

input: But, there has been a great development, and during the year 2002, education in the pre-school, and the first two classes in school were made in 470 languages.
target: Me, finn ena enn gran devlopman, e ariv lane 2002, ledikasyon dan pre-skoler, e premye de klas dan lekol, ti fer dan 470 langaz.

input: Not 2, as we are asking, Kreol and Bhojpuri, but 470.
target: Pa 2, kuma nu pe dimande, Kreol ek Bhojpuri, me 470.

input: Papua New Guinea is not one of the richest countries in the world.
target: Papua New Guinea li pa parmi pei pli ris dan lemond, li.

input: They started this experiment in 1993, or 10 years ago.
target: Zot ti kumans sa lexperyans-la an 1993, setadir 10 banane desela.

input: I will read the results from David Klaus's study.
target: Nu pu sitr rezilta depi letid David Klaus.

input: Children become literate more quickly, and easily.
target: "Zanfan vinn letre pli vit, e pli fasilman.

input: They learn English very quickly and easily than their siblings did under the old English-medium system.
target: Zot aprann Angle pli vit e pli fasilman ki zanfan avan zot lepok ti fer dapre vye sistem medyom Angle.

input: Children including girls stay in school.
target: Zanfan, e sa inklir tifi, res lekol.

input: After the first six years, the children have an obligatory examination.
target: Apre premye sis banane, zanfan konpoz enn lexamen obligatwar.

input: In those provinces, which started first in 1993, children who had mother tongue media education had much higher results, in the end-examination, in English, than those provinces, which still taught, through the medium of English from Day I.
target: Dan sa bann provens ki ti kumans nuvo sistem premye, an 1993, zanfan ki ti ena langaz maternel kuma medyom ledikasyon ti tir pli bon rezilta dan lexame lafin lane, ki ti an Angle, ki bann zanfan provens ki ti ankor tuzur pe montre atraver medyom Angle depi premye zur lekol.

input: A comparison from neighbouring countries, Zambia and Malawi.
target: Enn konparezon 2 pei vwazin, Zambi ek Malawi.

input: There is an example from Zambia and Malawi, according to a study made by Edward Williams where there was a study with 1,500 children in grades I-VII, from 6 to 14 years.
target: Ena enn lekzanp depi Zambi ek Malawi, dapre enn letid ki finn fer par Edward Williams kot ti fer enn letid avek 1,500 zanfan dan grad I-VII depi laz 6 an ziska 14 an.

input: The study showed that all the Zambian children were educated through the medium of English. The study concludes that there was large numbers of Zambian children (all educated in English) have very weak or zero reading competence in 2 languages.
target: Letid-la finn demontre ki zanfan Zambi finn edike atraver medyom Angle. Letid finn konklir ki ena enn nomb inportan zanfan Zambi (tu edike an Angle) ena konpetans extreman feb ubyen mem zero konpetans lektir dan 2 langaz.

input: In Malawi the children were taught in various local languages, which were mostly there mother tongues.
target: Dan Malawi par kont zanfan ti anseyne dan plizyir langaz lokal, langaz maternel dan laplipar ka.

input: During the first four years of school they had English as a subject, and from fifth year they started learning all in English.
target: Pandan premye 4 lane lekol zot ti ena Angle kuma enn size, e depi sinkyem lane zot ti kumans etidye tu an Angle.

input: When Edward Williams compared their English language competence to that of the Zambian children, he could see that the Malawi students had a better test result in English that the Zambian students.
target: Kan Edward Williams konpar zot konpetans an langaz Angle avek zanfan Zambi, li truve ki zelev Malawi tit ena rezilta pli bon dan tes Angle ki zelev Zambyen.

input: Statistics on Languages usually spoken in Mauritius
target: Extracts of figures from official Census on language usually spoken at home in 1990 and 2000.
Sa bann sif-la pe montre imans nomb dimunn ki koz Kreol e Bhojpuri.

input: These figures show the extent of the use of Kreol and Bhojpuri.
target: An 1990 ena 70.6 % dimunn ki finn dir zot koz Kreol ubyen Kreol ek enn lot langaz lakaz. An 2000 sa sif-la finn vinn 80.5%.

input: Whereas in 1990, 70.6 % people said they speak Kreol or Kreol & another language, in 2000 80.5% said so.
target: An 2000 totalite dimunn ki dir zot koz Kreol e Bhojpuri li 93.2%; li ti 91.8% an 1990.

input: In 2000 those who say they speak Kreol and Bhojpuri has progressed from 91. 8 to 93.2%.
target: Ena zis 5% popilasyon ki dir zot abitye koz Angle, Franse ubyen enn langaz Oryantal lakaz.

input: Only 5% of the population even claims the high status languages English, French and Other Oriental Languages.
target: Ki Ledikasyon Pu Travayer pe demande.
Ledikasyon Pu Travayer, dir ki Minister Ledikasyon bizin aret asasinn lintelizans zanfan.

input: Ledikasyon pu Travayer, says that the Ministry of Education must stop murdering the intelligence of children.
target: Nu propoze ki Minister Ledikasyon enn fwa pu de bon kumans servi langaz maternel zanfan Kreol ek Bhojpuri kuma medyom lanseynman.

input: We propose that the Ministry of Education once and for all begins to use the mother tongue of children, Kreol and Bhojpuri, as the medium of education.
target: Ledikasyon pu Travayer pe propoz pu pran bann mezir pu permet enn introdiksyon gradyel Kreol ek Bhojpuri kouma enn medyom apartir 2004.

input: Ledikasyon pu Travayer is proposing that all necessary measured be taken for the gradual introduction of Kreol and Bhojpuri as medium from 2004.
target: Nu propoze ki, Minister Ledikasyon organiz bann gran "konkur nasyonal tradiksyon an Kreol ek Bhojpuri" tu bann liv lekol ki bann zanfan pu servi.

input: We propose that the Minister of Education organizes a series of "National translation Competitions" for all the textbooks used. Government must offer prizes of (Rs 100,000 or more) to the teacher who does the best translation of each text into Kreol and Bhojpuri.
target: Guvernman bizin ofer bann pri (Rs 100,000 ubyen plis) a profeser ki fer pli bon tradiksyon sak text an Kreol ek Bhojpuri.

input: We propose that the Minister of Education offers Kreol and Bhojpuri language as a subject as from when children go to primary school.
target: Nu propose ki Minis Ledikasyon ofer Kreol ek Bhojpuri kouma enn size kan zanfan al lekol primer.

input: Ledikasyon pu Travayer proposes that government recruit a group of professional linguists with experience to draft a full-length Mauritian Kreol grammar, and to continue to develop the scientific study of the Kreol language.
target: Ledikasyon pu Travayer fer demand ki Guvernman rekrit enn grup lingwis profesyonel avek expertiz pu dekrir gramer Kreol syantifikman ek pu kontinye develop lanseynman langaz Kreol.

input: We propose that government create a Department for the Study of the Kreol language, and another Department for the study of Bhojpuri at the University, MIE, MCA, MES.
target: Nu propoze ki guvernman met dibut enn Departman ki ena responsabilite pu fer bann letid ek resers lor langaz Kreol, ek enn lot pu langaz Bhojpuri dan liniversite, MIE, MCA, MES.

input: The fact that many teachers, through their trade unions have already taken a stand in favour of the introduction of the Kreol language as medium of instruction, the fact that many teachers already use the mother tongue when they are teaching children because it is most efficient means that the co-operation of teachers can be expected.
target: Lefet ki buku bann profeser, atraver zot sindika finn deza pran pozisyon anfaver introdiksyon langaz Kreol kuma medyom lanseynman dan sistem ledikasyon, lefet ki buku profeser deza servi langaz maternel kan zot pe donn zanfan leson parski li langaz ki servi dan lavi tulezur, sa vedir ki pa pu ena difikilte pu bann profeser fer zot travay avek vokasyon ek antuzyas.

input: This change will also permit parents to contribute to the education of their child.
target: Sa nuvo politik ki nu pe insiste pu pli bon pu zanfan, li pu natirelman osi permet paran kontribye plis dan ledikasyon zanfan.

input: In conclusion, we would like to draw your attention to another serious problem once schooling has become compulsory.
target: An konklizyon, nu ti pu kontan atir u latansyon lor enn lot kestyon byen grav, kan lekolaz finn vinn obligatwar.

input: Till today, there are many regions where there is only an RCEA primary school and no government school.
target: Zordizur ena tuzur buku landrwa kot ena zis enn lekol primer RCEA e okenn lekol Guvernmn.

input: This means, if we understand Government's position, that an education of a religious "specificity" is dispensed.
target: Setadir enn lekol ki furni enn ledikasyon ki, dapre Guvernman, li "spesifik" dan kote relizyon.

input: Once you make it legally compulsory for parents to send their children to school, how can you force parents in Tamarin or St Pierre (or any number of other areas) to send their children to have religiously "specific" education dispensed? This will, we are obliged to inform you, be another form of genocide, this time based on transferring children from one religious group to another.
target: La osi, si u, an tan ki Guvernman, kontiyn obliz paran Tamarin ubyen St. Pierre, par exanp, avoy zot zanfan dan enn lekol ki pe montre tu size dan enn fason "Katolik", sa osi, malerezman, li ekivo, dapre tu norm internasyonal, a enn zenosid. U pe fors zanfan kit zot grup relizyon, rant dan enn lot grup.

input: As you can see, once schooling becomes compulsory, you as Minister have additional responsibilities not to hard children.
target: U truve, kan lekolaz vinn obligatwar, u, antan ki Minis, gayn enn responsabilite anplis.

input: You are legally and morally bound to build secular schools in all areas.
target: U bizin konstrir lekol sekilye dan tu landrwa.

input: If not, you will be liable to pay reparations for genocide.
target: Sinon, u pu bizin peye, si ena reparasyon.

input: And, more importantly, you will be responsible for an immense harm done to children.
target: E u pu responsab enn ditor imans a zanfan.

input: You must, as from now, since we have made you aware of the problem of linguistic genocide, immediately make preparations to introduce the mother tongues as medium in schools.
target: E u bizin fer ledikasyon dan langaz maternel, pu evit perpetre enn zenosid lingwistik, par inpoz langaz inkoni ek etranze lor zanfan.

input: We hope that you will immediately start a process to put a stop to the persistence of these colonial policies, which have gone on too long.
target: Nu espere ki u pu tutswit kumans enn prosesis pu aret enn politik kolonyal ki finn dire pandan tro lontan asterla.

input: We wish to assure you that we in Ledikasyon pu Travayer will continue the fight for the liberation of children from the domination you are continuing to impose on them.
target: Antuka, u kapav sir ki nu, dan Ledikasyon pu Travayer, nu pu kontinye lite pu liberasyon zanfan depi sa dominasyon ki u pe kontinye inpoze.

input: A CYCLONE WARNING CLASS I REMAINS IN FORCE IN MAURITIUS.
target: ENN AVERTISMAN SIKLONN  KLAS I RES ANVIGER LOR MORIS.

input: THIRD CYCLONE BULLETIN ISSUED AT 16H30 ON SATURDAY 13TH APRIL 2013.
target: TRWAZIEM BILTIN SIKLONN KI FINN TIRE SAMDI LE 13 AVRIL 2013 A 04H00 TANTO.

input: RECENT OBSERVATIONS FROM THE METEOROLOGICAL STATION AT ST BRANDON INDICATE THAT IMELDA IS NOW PASSING AT ITS CLOSEST DISTANCE TO THE ISLAND.
target: BANN DERNYE OBZERVASYON DEPI STASION METEO ST BRANDON MONTRE KI IMELDA PE ASTER PAS A SO PWIN PLI PROS DE ST BRANDON.

input: THE HIGHEST GUST RECORDED WAS OF THE ORDER OF 139 KM/H.
target: PLI GRO RAFAL KI FINN ENREZISTE LABA LI 139 KM/H.

input: THESE OBSERVATIONS CONFIRM THAT MODERATE TROPICAL STORM IMELDA HAS INTENSIFIED INTO A SEVERE TROPICAL STORM AND WAS CENTERED AT 16H00 NEAR 16.6 DEGREES SOUTH AND 59.3 DEGREES EAST, THAT IS AT A DISTANCE OF 420 KM TO THE NORTH NORTH EAST OF MAURITIUS.
target: SA BANN OBZERVASYON-LA KONFIRME KI TANPET TROPIKAL MODERE IMELDA FINN INTENSIFIE EN ENN FORT TANPET TROPIKAL E LI TI SANTRE A 04H00 TANTO AN LATITID 16.6 DEGRE SID E LONZITID 59.3 DEGRE ES A ENN DISTANS DE 420 KM DAN NOR NOR ES DE MORIS.

input: IT CONTINUES TO MOVE IN A GENERAL SOUTHERLY DIRECTION AT ABOUT 05 KM/H.
target: LI PE CONTINYE BOUZE DAN ENN DIREKSYON DI SID A ANVIRON 05 KM/H.

input: ON THIS TRAJECTORY, IMELDA CONTINUES TO APPROACH MAURITIUS AND RODRIGUES AND REMAINS A THREAT TO THE ISLANDS.
target: LOR SA TRAZEKTWAR-LA, IMELDA CONTINYE APROS AR MORIS EK RODRIG E  LI RES ENN MENAS POU BANN LIL-LA.

input: THE PUBLIC IS ADVISED TO TAKE PRELIMINARY PRECAUTIONS.
WEATHER IN MAURITIUS WILL REMAIN CLOUDY TO OVERCAST IN GENERAL WITH RAINY PERIODS BECOMING MORE FREQUENT TONIGHT PARTICULARLY OVER THE HIGH GROUNDS.
target: LETAN A MORIS POU KUVER AVEK LA PLI KI POU FREKAN ASWAR SIRTU LOR BANN OTER.

input: WIND WILL BLOW FROM THE EAST SOUTH EASTERLY DIRECTION WITH A MEAN SPEED OF 30 TO 40 KM/H AND GUSTS OF THE ORDER OF 80 KM/H.
target: DIVAN POU SOUFLE DAN DIRELSYON ES SID ES A ENN VITES 30 A 40 KM/H AVEK RAFAL DE 80 KM/H.

input: SEA WILL REMAIN VERY ROUGH WITH SWELLS.
target: LAMER POU RES BIEN MOVE AVEK LAOUL.

input: THE PUBLIC IS ADVISED NOT TO VENTURE AT SEA.
target: PIBLIK KONSEYE PA AL DAN LAMER.

input: NEXT BULLETIN WILL BE ISSUED AROUND 05H00 HRS TOMORROW MORNING.
target: PROSENN BILTIN POU TIRE OTUR 05H00 DIME GRAMATIN.

input: A CYCLONE WARNING CLASS I REMAINS IN FORCE IN MAURITIUS.
target: ENN AVERTISMAN SIKLONN KLAS I RES ANVIGER LOR MORIS.

Be checkmate in a game of draughts.
Inauguration of a temple ini the Tamil.
Sacrifice in the name of Allah.
Long Indian shirt worn by men or women.
Spy on lovers during their social or sexual intercourse.
Measuring tool for right angle corners.

Dimunitive for nation as an ethnonym.

Shawl worn mainly by Muslim or Hindu women.
Small spherical cake covered in dessicated coconut.

Little bells worn around the ankles.

Ice made vith syrup and sold in a long and thin plastic bags.

Small sweet cake soaked in syrup.

Mr. Jones, of the Manor Farm, had locked the hen-houses for the night, but was too drunk to remember to shut the popholes.
target: Misie Jonns, propriyeter Baz Jonns, ti fini ferm poulaye pou lanwit me li ti sitan sou ki li ti bliye ferm tilaport anba.

input: With the ring of light from his lantern dancing from side to side, he lurched across the yard, kicked off his boots at the back door, drew himself a last glass of beer from the barrel in the scullery, and made his way up to bed, where Mrs. Jones was already snoring.
target: Lalimier so fanal ti pe balote agos-adrwat ler Misie Jonns ti pe trenn so lipie atraver lakour; ler li ti rant dan grannkaz, li ti avoy so bogi dan ler, vers enn lot gran ver labier, al dan so lasam kot Madam Jonns ti pe ronfle.

input: As soon as the light in the bedroom went out there was a stirring and a fluttering all through the farm buildings.
target: Kouma lalimier dan so lasam ti tengn, ti koumans ena enn ta mouvman ek bouzman dan bann diferan lakaz zanimo.
